title: SWP No. 010: William Barker, Jr.
content: SWP No. 10.1(Examination of [William Barker,Jr.] _barker_william_jr )[September 12, 1693 ]2nd Paper Sep't 92  Before [Maj'r Gidney] _gidney_bartholomew  [m'r Hawthorn] _hawthorne_john  [m'r Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  & [Cap't Higginsone] _higginson_john .The Examination and confession of [W'm Barker] _barker_william_jr  aged 14 yeares or  #[there]aboutHe is accused for exerciseing acts of witchcraft upon the bodyes  of [Martha Sprague] _sprague_martha  [Rose foster] _foster_rose  and [Abigail Martin] _martin_abigail , which he did not  deny but could not remember it.  He confesses now that he hath not been in the snare of the devil  above six dayes, That as he was goeing in the woods one evening  to look efter cowes he saw the shape of a black dog which looked  very fiercely upon him And he was much disturbed in his mynd  about it and could not sleep well that night  And betymes next morneing he mett with a black man (he calls him a black man be-  cause he had black cloaths and thinks he had a black skin) who  bid him set his hand to a book and serve him as long as he the said  [Barker] _barker_william_jr  Lived, which he promeised  And thereupon set his hand to the  book by putting his finger thereon, He saith the black man brought  red stuff along with him in an Inkhorn  And he the said [Barker] _barker_william_jr  dipt  his finger into it and therewith made a red mark on the paper He  confesses he was to doe any service the black man appoynted him  and was to have a sute of cloaths for it. he said further the black  man would have him baptised but he never was.  He saith further that Goody Parker went with him last night to  afflict [martha Sprague] _sprague_martha , And that he afflicts by clincheing his hands to-  gether. He now Saith he is sorry & hates the devill but yet struck  down the afflicted with his eyes,  And [martha Sprague] _sprague_martha  being re-  covered out of a fitt said that [Barkers] _barker_william_jr  apparition and Goody Parker  rid upon a pole. and was baptised at five myle pond,-- He now sayes  there was such a load upon his Stomack that he could not speak,  A litle after he owned he was baptised by the black man at five  myle pond and did also renounce his former baptisme, he knowes  Goody Parker to be a witch  And sayes the devil dipt his head into  the water & spoke these words that he the said [Barker] _barker_william_jr  was his  for ever and ever.   He said he could not think of his baptisme before,  And that the load that was upon his stomak is not so heavy as it was but just before  He #[said] still afflicted [martha Sprague] _sprague_martha  & shut her mouth but by layeing  his hand thereon opened it again. -- and afterwards confessed that  there were of his Company Goody Parker [Goody Johnson] _johnson_elizabeth_sr  [Samuel Wardwell] _wardwell_samuel  & his wife and two daughte'rs. And then could take the af-  flicted persones by the hand without doeing them any harme.[W'm Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr  Signed & owned the abovesaid  Examination & Confession.  before me[*John Higginson] _higginson_john  Just'e peace: The marke  X of  [William Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr  (Reverse) Confession of [William Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr   acused. Goody parker  [Goody Johnson] _johnson_elizabeth_sr   [Sam'll wardell] _wardwell_samuel .  his wife   & 2 Daughters  aflicted  [martha. Sprage] _sprague_martha  ( Suffolk Court Files, vol. 32, docket 2761, p. 103, Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, Judicial Archives, Massachusetts State Archives, Boston. )

title: SWP No. 010: William Barker, Jr.
content: SWP No. 10.2(Examination of [William Barker, Jr.] _barker_william_jr , Second Version )[+ September 1, 1692 ]1 Sep'r 92  Before [Maj'r Gidney] _gidney_bartholomew  [M'r Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  [M'r Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  [Jn'o Higginson] _higginson_john  Esq'rThe Exam & Confe'son of [Wm Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr  aged 14 Yeares or  their about He is accused for Exercising acts of Witchcraft Upon  the bodyes of [Martha Sprauge] _sprague_martha  [Rosse fostter] _foster_rose  & [abigall Martin] _martin_abigail  w'ch  he did not deny but Could Not Rememb'r it -- He Confesses now  that he hath not been in the Snare of the Divel above Six # [Years]   days, that as he was Goeing into the Woods one Evening to loeck  after Cows he Saw the Shape of a black dog w'ch looked Verry  fercly Upon Him & he was Much disturbed in his Mind about it  & Could not Sleep well that Night & betimes Next Morning he Mett  w'th a black Man (he Calls him a black man because he had black  Cloaths & thinks he had a black Skin) Who bid him Sett his hand to  his book & Serve him as long as he the s'd [Barker] _barker_william_jr  lived w'ch he pro-  mised And #[Soe] theirupon Sett His hand to this book by putting his  fing'r Thereon he Saith the black man brought Red Stuf along w'th  him in an Inkorn & he the S'd [Barker] _barker_william_jr  dipt his finger into it and ther  w'th Made a Red Mark on the paper He Confesses he was to doe any  Servis the black man appointed him # [to doe] & was to have Suite  of Cloaths for it he S'd further the black man would have him bapt-  ized but he Nevr was -- he Saith further that good'e Parker went  w'th him last Night to afflictt [Martha Sprauge] _sprague_martha  & that he afflicts by  pinching his hands Together he Saith  he Now is Sorry & hates the Divel but Yett Struck dwone the afflicted w'th his  Eyes -- and [Martha Sprauge] _sprague_martha  being Recovered out of a fitt S'd that [barkers] _barker_william_jr  apperition  & Good'e Parker rod Upon a pole & was baptized at 5 Mile pond -- He  Now Says there was Such a load Upon his Stomach that he Could  Not Speak a little affter he owned he was baptized by the black man  at 5 Mile pond & Renounced his former baptizime he Knows Good'e  parker to be a witch & Says the Divel dipt his head into the Watter  & Spook these words that he the S'd [Barker] _barker_william_jr  was his for Ever & Ever  He S'd he Could not think of his baptizime before & that the Load  that was Up[] his Stomach Is not Soe heavy as it was Just now He  Stil afflicted [Martha Sprauge] _sprague_martha  & Shut her Mouth but by laying his  hand Theron opened it again -- and afterwards Confessed that  ther ware of his Comp'a Good'e parker [Good'e Johnson] _johnson_elizabeth_sr  [Sam'll Wardwel] _wardwell_samuel   his wife & two Daughters & then Could take the afflicted  p'rsons by the Hand w'th out doeing them any harm[Wm Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr  Signed & owned the above S'd Exam'n &  Confession  before Me[*John Higginson] _higginson_john  Just'e peace The Marke   X of  [Wm Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr  ( Essex Institute Collection, Peabody Essex Museum, Salem. No. 24, 10r-v. )

title: SWP No. 010: William Barker, Jr.
content: SWP No. 10.3(Indictment of [William Barker, Jr.] _barker_william_jr  for Covenanting)[+ January 1693 ]Province of the Massachusetts  Bay in New England Essex ssAn'o RRs & Reginae Gulielmi & Mariae Angliae &c Quarto Anoq'e  Dom 1692The Ju'rors for o'r Sov'r lord & Lady the King & Queen p'rsent  That [William Barker Junio'r] _barker_william_jr  of Andvo'r in the County of Essex aforsaid  Sometime in the moneth of August last in the yeare 1692 aforsd  Att or in the Towneship of Andivo'r in the Country of Essex aforsd  Wickedly mallitiously & felloniously A Covenant with#[e] the Devill  did make & Signed the Devills Booke and by the Devill was Baptized  & before him Renounced his form'r Baptizme & promised to be the  Devills for ever and ever By which wicked & Diabollicall Covenant  the Said [William Barker] _barker_william_jr  is become A Detestable Witch Against the  peace of o'r Sov'r lord & Lady the King & Queen their Crowne  & dignity And the laws in that Case made & provided.(Reverse) William Barker Jun'r for Covenanting w'th the Devill  Billa vera  [*Robert. Payne] _payne_robert  foreman:  ponet Se  #[fled]  Not Guilty  Court at Ipwich  Ipswich 2'd Tuesday May 1693( Suffolk Court Files, vol. 32, docket 2761, p. 102, Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, Judicial Archives. )

title: SWP No. 010: William Barker, Jr.
content: SWP No. 10.4(Indictment v. [William Barker, Jr.] _barker_william_jr  for Afflicting Martha Sprague)[+ January 13, 1693 Province of the Massathutetts  Bay in New England EssexAnno RRs & Reginae Gulielmi & Mariae. Angliae &'c Quarto Annoq'e  Dom: 1692The Juro'r for our Sovereigne Lord & Lady the King & Queen  Presents  That [William Barker Junio'r] _barker_william_jr  of Andivo'r in the County of Essex  aforesaid - - -  Sometime in the moneth of August last in the Yeare 1692 aforesaid - - - And  Divers other Dayes & times as well before as after Certaine Detestable  Arts called Witchcrafts & Sorceries: Wickedly Mallishiously & fello-  niously hath used Practised & Exercised at &: in the Towne of  Salem -- in the County of Essex aforesaid upon and against one  [Martha Sprague] _sprague_martha  Allias [Martha Tyler] _tyler_martha  -- by which Wicked Artes the  Said [Martha Sprague] _sprague_martha  Alli Tyler the Day and Year aforesaid and  Divers -- other Dayes & times as well before as after was & is Tour-  tered Afflicted Tormented Pined & wasted against the Peace of our  Sovereigne Lord & Lady the King & Queen their Crowne & Dignity  and the Lawes in that Case made & Provided./(Reverse) William Barker Junio'r for bewitching [Martha Sprague] _sprague_martha   Billa vera  [*Robert: Payne] _payne_robert  foreman:  ponet Se  Not Guilty( Suffolk Court Records, Vol. 32, Case No. 2761, Page 103.Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, Judicial Archives, Massachusetts State Archives, Boston. )

title: SWP No. 010: William Barker, Jr.
content: SWP No. 10.5(Recognizance for [William Barker, Jr.,] _barker_william_jr  , and [Mary Barker] _barker_mary  by John Barker & John Osgood Sr.)[+ January 13, 1693 ]Memorandum That on the Thirteenth day of Jan'ry 1692  In the Fourth Year of the  Reigne of our Sovereigne Lord and Lady William and Mary by the  Grace of God of England &c King & Queen defenders of the faith  &c Personally appeared before [W'm Stoughton] _stoughton_william  Esq'r cheife Justice  of their Maj'ies Province of the Massachusets bay in New England  [Jn'o Barker] _barker_john  and [Jn'o Osgood] _osgood_john  both of the Towne of Andiver in the  County of Essex Husbandmen and acknowledged themselves to be  Joyntly & Severally indebted unto our sd Sovereigne Lord & Lady  and the Survivor of them their Heires & Successors in the Sum of one  Hundred Pounds to be levied on their or either of their lands & Tenni-  ments goods & chattles for the use of our sd Sovereigne Lord  & Lady the King & Queen or Survivor of them on Condition that  [W'm Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr  & [Mary Barker] _barker_mary  haveing stood Committed for Suspition  of Witchcraft shall make their personall appearance before the Jus-  tices of our sd Lord & Lady the King & Queen at the next Court of  Assizes and Generall Goale Delivery to be holden for the County of  Essex then & their to answer to all such matters and things as shall  in their Maj'ies behalfe be alledged against them and to doe & re-  ceive that which by the sd Court shall be then & there Injoyned  them and thence not to departe without licenceAttest  [*Jon'a Elatson] _elatson_jonathan  Cler (Reverse)  Recognizance of  [Jn'o Barker] _barker_john  &  [Jn'o Osgood] _osgood_john  {  for  for [W'm Barker Jun'r] _barker_william_jr   & #[[Mary Tyler] _tyler_martha ]  [Mary Barker] _barker_mary  May 10'th Apeared  ( Massachusetts Archives Collection, vol. 135, no. 105. Boston. )

title: SWP No. 100: Joan Peney
content: SWP No. 100.1(Complaint v. [Joan Peney] _peney_joan  & Statement of Bond to Prosecute )[September 13, 1692 ] [Zebulon Hill] _hill_zebulon  Complaineth in the behalfe of Our Sovereigne Lord and Lady William and Mary King and Queen Unto this Honorable Court now Assembled and Sitting in Salem this 13 day of September 1692./  Against one Goodwife [Piney] _peney_joan  wife of [] Piney  of the Towne of Gloster in the County of Essex for that shee the said [] [Piney] _peney_joan  Did on the Tenth and Eleventh Day of this Instant September Afflict, torture, and Torment, your Honours Complain't -- Daughter [Mary:] _hill_mary  by that Diabollical Art of Witchcraft, by which the said [Mary] _hill_mary  is in great Paine, and Torture, -- as well be made appear./[*Zebulon Hill] _hill_zebulon [20. Sept 1692: -- ] [Zebulon Hill] _hill_zebulon  Obliges himselfe to our Soveraine Wm & Mary King & Queen of England &c in the full & whole Sume of one hundred pounds Currant mony of New England The Condition is that the Said [Zeb'n Hill] _hill_zebulon  shall & will procecut the within mentioned Complaint against [] [Peney] _peney_joan  of Gloster to Effect. before me * [John Higginson] _higginson_john  Just'e Peace 20. Sept 1692: --  ( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 198, Rare Books & Manuscripts, Boston Public Library, Boston, MA.)

title: SWP No. 100: Joan Peney
content: SWP No. 100.2(Warrant for the Apprehension of [Joan Peney] _peney_joan  & Officer's Return)[September 20, 1692] To the sherife of the County of Essex his Deputy or the Constable  of Chebaco Complaint haveing ben made to us whose names are underwritten Justices of the Peace in the County of Essex by [Zebulon Hill] _hill_zebulon  of Salem against [Joan Peny.] _peney_joan  widow of [Thomas Peney] _peney_thomas  Late of Gloster for that she the Said [Joan Peney] _peney_joan  hath feloniously comitted Severall acts of witchcraft. on the Body of [Mary Hill] _hill_mary  of Salem Singlewoman. to her great hurt & Torment. the Said [Zb Hill] _hill_zebulon  haveing given sufficient bond for the procecution of the Said Complaint to Effect. These are therefore in their Majesties name to require you forthwith to Aprehend & seize. the Body of [Joane Peney] _peney_joan  widow as abovesaid & bring her. before their Majesties Justices of the Peace to be examined & proceded w'th according to law for w'ch this shall be your sufficient warant Dated in Salem this 20: September 1692: The. 21: of September 1692: I have seased the body of [wedowe peni] _peney_joan  and have brought hur to Salem by me[*John Chote] _choate_john  Constable of Ipswich[*Bartho' Gedney] _gidney_bartholomew [*John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john [*Jonathan. Corwin] _corwil_jonathan [*John Higginson] _higginson_john ( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 248, Rare Books & Manuscripts, Boston Public Library, Boston, MA. Boston, MA.)

content: SWP No. 100.3Fragment of the Examination of [Joan Penny] _peney_joan[+ September 21, 1692]She was bid to say the Lord's Prayer. title: SWP No. 101: Hannah Post
content: SWP No. 101.1(Examination of [Hannah Post] _post_hannah  )[August 25, 1692.] August the 25'th 1692.[Hannah Post] _post_hannah  of Boxford Examinaed before the Justices of Salem when she was a Coming into the Roome the afflicted persons Some of them ware afflicted & s'd She was Coming the Majestrets told her She was acused for hurting of two persons, but She Denyed that She had anything to do w'th the Divel, the Constable told her of Somthing She had owned tending that way the afflicted persons were afflicted by her looking on them. And were well again by her taking them by the hand yet she denyed that she was a Witch & s'd She never Signed the Divels book nor never was baptized by him She S'd She disowned that Ever She had ben at any of their Mettings, She disowned that she had been struck at -- Namely her aperition -- & that She had been almost Cripled by her aperition -- being Struck w'ch She after wards Owned also She afterwards Confessed that the Divel  had apeared to her Several times the first time in the Shape of a Pige but She S'd did not Speak to her but She was much harried in her mind with it & next apeared like a Catt afterward like a bird flying at the window of her Master Chamber wher She was at work & the bird Spoke to her promised her new Cloths if She would Serve & worship him & She did bargain to Serve him Soe long as She lived She s'd the Divel has Come to her Somtimes like a black Man & that She was baptized by the Divel at five Mile pond & that her Sister [Susanna Post] _post_susannah  & [Sarah] _bridges_sarah  & [Mary bridges] _bridges_mary_jr  were baptized there when She was, & She owned that She made a Marke w'th her finger in the Divels book & that the Marke was Red She also Showed her finger tep where it had been Cut & S'd She made the Red mark in the Divels book w'th the blood of that She owned She had been at Some of the witch Mettings & that She thought their meight be about 200 at the witch metting at Chandlers Garison at Andivor She also told of [of] the 2 [Jaxons] _jackson_john_sr  & [Jno Howard] _howard_john  of Rowly  that they ware witches & 13 of Ipswich as She heard them Say of [Abigal falkner] _faulkner_abigail  of Andiver now in prison & that [Martha Emerson] _emerson_martha  afflicted her there in the Room, & then She wuld goe Shake hands & beg pardon of the afflicted persons & not afflict them [Mary Post] _post_mary  at the Same time affirmd that She had Seen Church Clark [Goody Hutchins] _hutchins_frances  of Haverill & [Abigale forkner] _faulkner_abigail  of andiver & [Wilford] _wilford_ruth  & [Goody Eames] _eames_rebecca  & her Son [Dan'll] _eames_daniell  at a witch metting at andivor & that She knew them to be witches( Essex Institute Collection no. 24, 6r. Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, MA)

title: SWP No. 102: Mary Post
content: SWP No. 102.1(Warrant for apprehension of [Mary Post] _post_mary  & Officer's Return)[August 2, 1692] To the Constable  of Rowley Essex Whereas [Timothy Swan] _swan_timothy  of Andover, & [Mary Walcutt] _walcott_mary  & [Ann Puttman] _putnam_ann_jr  of Salem Village have this day appeared before me [Dudley Bradstreet] _bradstreet_dudley  of Andover one of their Majesties Justices of the Peace, for the County of Essex; and made complaint in writeing; That [Mary Post] _post_mary  of Rowley hath Sorely Afflicted them the s'd [Swan] _swan_timothy  , [Walcut] _walcott_mary  & [Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  by witchcraft &c contrary to the peace of our Sovereigne Lord & Lady King William & Queen Mary of England: and to the statutes in that case provided: And also s'd swan haveing given bond, according to Law, of twenty pounds in currant mony of New England for prosecution of s'd complaint to Effect, before the Worshi[pbar ]'l [Bartholemew Gedney] _gidney_bartholomew  , [John Hathorn] _hawthorne_john  , [J [Torn] n Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  & [John Higginson] _higginson_john  Esqs their Majesty[es] Justices of the Peace at [Torn] in the County of Essex.These therefore require you in their Majestyes name to Apprehend and Seise the body of [Mary Post] _post_mary  afores'd forthwith and her Safely convey to Salem, before the s'd worshipf'll [Barthol. Gedney] _gidney_bartholomew  . [John Hathorn] _hawthorne_john  &c Esq. there to be examined and proceeded with acco[rbar ]d to Law: for which this shall be your Justification. Given under my hand and Seal this 2'd day of August 1692 & in the fourth year of the Reighn of our Sovereign Lord & Lady William and Mary King & Queen of England, Scotland &c.[Dudley Bradstreet] _bradstreet_dudley  justice of the Peace by vertue of the above said warrant I have Seized the Body of [Mary Post] _post_mary  of Rowley & brought her to Salem beffore the abovesaid [Bartho Gidny] _gidney_bartholomew  [John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  [Jona' Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  &c Esq'rs[*Joseph jewett] _jewett_joseph Constable of Rowley. ( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 204, Rare Books & Manuscripts, Boston Public Library, Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 103: Susannah Post
content: SWP No. 103.1(Examination of [Susannah Post] _post_susannah  )[August 25, 1692 ]> [Susanah Post] _post_susannah  was examined before [Maj'r. Gedney:] _gidney_bartholomew  & other their Majest's Justices August 25 1692 The Justices told her she was acused for afflicting. [Martha Spreag] _sprague_martha  & [Rose Foster] _foster_rose  by witchcraft. When Susanah was Brought in before them: the afflicted: was greatly afflicted: [Mary Warin] _warren_mary  & was recovered by her touching withe her hand: her sister [Hannah Post] _post_hannah  s'd she was babtized: with her at five mile pond the afflicted persons. then charged her with afflicting them & that they saw her afflict #[&] but she Denyed it & s'd she knew not of it. Nor that she hade made a Covnant with the Devill.but after ward: she confessed she had bin in the Devils snare three years: the first time she saw him he was like a Catt: he told her he was a prince: & I was to serve him I promised him to doe it the next shape was a yellow bird: it s'd I must serve him: & he s'd I should live well: the next time he appeared like a black man that time he brought a book & she touched it with a stick that was Dipt in an ink horne & it made a red mark: & [Jno Jaxon sen'r] _jackson_john_sr  was there when she signed: he that was the great eater: she would own but three times that she had seen the Devil: but it was told her it could not but be more in 3 years time: she was unwilling to own if she had afflicted. [Martha Sprage] _sprague_martha  [Rose foster] _foster_rose  : but [Mary Bridges] _bridges_mary_jr  s'd she use to afflict by sticking Pins into Cloaths: which she then owned: She s'd #[she s'd] she was now willing to renownce the Devil & all his works: & she went: when bid & begged forgivnes of the #[of the] afflicted & and could come to them and not hurt them she owned she had been babtized at 5 mile pond above halfe a year agoe & the Devil Dipt her head in the water & s'd she must serv she s'd there were a great many at the witch meeting at Andover: but knew not exactly how many their might be 200: & they eat white bread & drank: & their was a minister & they [torn] a sacrement: & there was 200 there &  they eat bread that was white & drank some that was red: she s'd she heard there were 500 witches in the Country she s'd she & two of her sisters went to the villadge meeting & rod. upon a stik: the Devil Carried it & she rode before she s'd that [Folkner Wilford] _wilford_faulkner  of Haverell [Sarah Parker] _parker_sarah  was at the witch meeting & that she knew the two [Jaxons] _jackson_john_sr  good wife [torn] & [Mr Howard] _howard_john  of Rowley to be witches:I und'r written being apponted to take the examination Doe Testifie upon oath taken in Court that this is a true coppy or substance of it, to the best of my knowledge Janu'y 7'th 1692  [Simon Willard] _willard_simon  (Reverse)  the within [Hanah Post] _post_hannah  was examined before their Majesties Justises of peace in Salem atest [John Higginson.] _higginson_john  J: Peace owned before the Grand Jury  January 1692  [*Robert Payne] _payne_robert  foreman (Reverse) Examination of [Susanah Post] _post_susannah  ( Suffolk Court Files, Vol. 32, Docket no. 2705, Page 28. Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, Judicial Archives, Massachusetts State Archives. Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 103: Susannah Post
content: SWP No. 103.4(Court Record of the Trial of [Susannah Post] _post_susannah  )[May 10, 1693][Susanah Post] _post_susannah  of Andover in the County of Essex Singlewoeman being Indicted by the Jurors of our Soveraigne Lord & lady the King and Queen upon their oathes by Two Severall Indictments That is to Say 1'st For that she the said [Susannah Post] _post_susannah  of Andover Singlewoman about Three yeares Since in the Towne of Andover in the County of Essex aforesaid Wickedly malitiously & felloniously A Covenant with the Devill did make & Signed the Devills booke & was Baptized by the Devill & promised to Serve the Devill By which diabolicall Covenanting with the Devill in manner and forme aforesaid by the said [Susannah Post] _post_susannah  made she said [Susannah Post] _post_susannah  is become a Detestable witch against the peace of our Soveraigne Lord and Lady the King and Queen their Crowne [and] dignity & the Laws in that Case made & provided 2'dly For that She the said [Susanah Post] _post_susannah  of Andover in the County of Essex Single woeman, on the 25'th day of Aug'st in the yeare 1692 and divers other dayes and tymes as well before as after Certaine Detestable Artes Called Witchcrafts & Sorceries wickedly Mallitiously and felloniously hath used practised at & in the towne of Salem in the County aforesaid upon and ag'st one [Rose foster] _foster_rose  of Andover Single woeman By which wicked Arts the said [Rose Foster] _foster_rose  the day and yeare afores'd and divers other dayes and times as well as after was and is Tortured afflicted Tormented consumed pined & wasted ag'st the peace of our Soveraigne Lord and Lady the King and Queen their Crowne and dignity and the law in Case made and provided.Upon the aforesaid indictments and each of them the said [Susana Post] _post_susannah  was then and there before the Justices of our Lord and Lady the King and Queen aforesaid arraigned & upon her arraignm't She  did then and there the day and year abovesaid plead to them and each of them not Guilty and put her Selfe upon Tryall by God and her Contrey -- A Jury being called [Thomas Burnham] _burnam_thomas  foreman and accordingly Sworne noe exception being made by the prisoner The Said Indictm'ts and each of them being read together with Evidences, & Examinations and the prisoners defence being heard, The jury went out to agree on their verdict who returning did then and there in open Court deliver [their verdict] That the said [Susannah Post] _post_susannah  was not Guilty of the fellony by witchcraft for w'ch she stood indicted in and by the s'd Indictm'ts and each of them.The Court Order'd [Susannah Post] _post_susannah  aforesaid To be Discharged Paying her fees.

title: SWP No. 104: Margaret Prince
content: SWP No. 104.1(Warrant for the Apprehension of [Elizabeth Dicer] _dicer_elizabeth  and [Margaret Prince] _prince_margaret  & Officer's Return)[September 3, 1692] To the Constable  of Gloster. complaint haveing ben made to us their Majesties Justices of the Peace in Salem by [Ebenezer Babson] _babson_ebenezer  of Gloster against [Elizabeth Dicer] _dicer_elizabeth  wife of [Wm Dicer] _dicer_william  and [Margaret Prince] _prince_margaret  widow of Gloster for that they have griveously hurt & Tortured. [Elenor Babson] _babson_elenor  widow & [Mary Sargent] _seargeant_mary  wife of [Wm Sarjant] _seargeant_william  Just'e of Gloster by witchcraft & has given Bond to their Majesties to procecut Said Complaint to Effect These are therfore in their Majestes name to require you to Aprehend & seize the Bodys of [Elizab't Dicer] _dicer_elizabeth  wife of [william Dicer] _dicer_william  of Boston Seaman & [Margret Prince] _prince_margaret  widow of Gloster & them bring before their Majesties Justices of the Peace in Salem their to be Examined about the premises for w'ch this shall be your warrantSalem  3: September 1692.  [Bartho Gedney] _gidney_bartholomew  [John Hathorn] _hawthorne_john  [Jonathan. Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  (Reverse) in obedience to this within warrant I have Seized the bodys of [Elizabeth Dicer] _dicer_elizabeth  & [Margret Prince] _prince_margaret  widow & brought them to Salem before their Majestes Justices of the Peace 5 Sep'r 1692/ [Thom griggs jun'or] _griggs_thomas_jr  Constbl of Glostr Eliz. Dicer Margaret Prince ( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 50, Rare Books & Manuscripts, Boston Public Library, Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 104: Margaret Prince
content: SWP No. 104.3(Recognizance for [Margaret Prince] _prince_margaret  by [Thomas Prince] _prince_thomas  & [*Richard Tarr] _tarr_richard  )[December 15, 1692]Memorandum: That on this fifteenth Day of December anno D[mbar ]: one Thousand Six hundred Ninty and two in the fourth year of the Reigne of our Sovereigne Lord & Lady William & Mary by the Grace of God of England Scottland &c King & Queen Defend'rs of the faith &c Personally Came and Appeared before me [George Corwin] _corwine_george  High Shirriffe of the County of Essex of the Province of the Massathutetts Bay in New England Thomas Prince of Gloster in the County of Essex in New England Husbandman Richard Tarr of said Towne and County Husbandman  and Acknowledged them selves indebted to our said Sovereigne Lord & Lady the King & Queen, and the Surviver of them their Heires and Successers in the summe of two hundred pounds to be Leavied on their Goods & Chattles Lands & Tennements for the Use of our said Sovereigne Lord & Lady: King & Queen & the Surviver of them if Default be made in the Performance of the Condition Under writtenVidellisett The Condition of this Above Recognizance is such that Whereas [Margarett Prince] _prince_margaret  Widdow Of Gloster aboves'd: is suspected & Accused of Committing Acts of Witchcrafts. if therefore [Margerett Prince] _prince_margaret  Widdow afores'd shall & do make her Personall Appearance before the Justices of our s'd Sovereigne Lord & Lady the King and Queen at the Next Court of Assize Oyer & Terminer next: Generall Geoall Delivery to be held for or within the County of Essex afores'd to answer w't shall be Objected ag't her on their Maj'ties behalfe: & Referring to the Witchcrafts. & to do & Receive that by w'ch said Court shall be then & there Injoyned & not depart without Lycence Then the above Recognizance to be void or Else to abide & Remaine in full force and Virtue In Wittness whereof the above Named Persons have here unto sett their hand & seales this fifteenth Day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand six hundred Ninty & two and in the fourth year of our Maj'ties ReigneWittness [Benja Gerrish] _gerrish_benjamin [*Nathaniel Beadle Sr.] _beadle_nathaniel_sr [Jno Gyles] _giles_john [Thomas] _prince_thomas   Prince his marke L.S. title: SWP No. 106: Elizabeth Proctor
content: SWP No. 106.2(Warrant for the Apprehension of [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  & [Sarah Cloyce] _cloyce_sarah  and Officer's Return)[April 4, 1692 Salem Aprill. 4'th 1692 There Being Complaint this day made (Before us) by Capt [Jonat Walcott] _walcott_john  , and [Lt Nathaniell Ingersull] _ingersoll_nathaniel  both of Salem Village, in Behalfe of theire Majesties for themselfes and also for severall of their Neighbours Against [Sarah Cloyce] _cloyce_sarah  the wife of [peter Cloyce] _cloyce_peter  of Salem Village; and [Elizabeth Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  the wife of [John Procter] _proctor_john  of Salem farmes for high Suspition of Sundry acts of Witchcraft donne or Committed by them upon the bodys of [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  , and [John Indian] _indian_john  both of [Mr Sam parris] _parris_samuel  his family of Salem Village and [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  daugter  of one of the abovesaid Complainants, And [Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  and [Marcy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  of the famyly of [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  of Salem Village whereby great hurt and dammage hath beene donne to the Bodys of s'd persons above named therefore Craved Justice.You are therefore in theire Majest's names hereby required to apprehend and bring before us [Sarah Cloyce] _cloyce_sarah  the wife of [peter Cloyce] _cloyce_peter  of Salem Village and [Elizabeth procter] _proctor_elizabeth  the wife of [John Procter] _proctor_john  of Salem farmes; on Munday Morneing Next being the Eleventh day of this Instant Aprill aboute Eleven of the Clock, at the publike Meeting house in the Towne, in order to theire Examination Relateing to the premises aboves'd and here of you are. not to faile Dated Salem Aprill 8'th 1692To [George Herick] _herrick_george  Marshall of the County of essex ][John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  [Jonathan. title: SWP No. 106: Elizabeth Proctor
content: SWP No. 106.3(Examination of [Sarah Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  and [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  )[April 11, 1692 ]At a court held at Salem 11th April 1692,  by the honoured [Thomas Danforth,] _danforth_thomas  Deputy Governor. Q. John [Indian]; who hurt you? A.  [Goody Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  first, and then [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  . Q. What did she do to you? A. she brought the book to me. Q. John [Indian]! tell the truth, who hurts you? have you been hurt? A. The first, was a gentlewoman I saw. Q. Who next? A. [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  . Q. But who hurt you next? A. [Goody Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  . Q. What did she do to you? A. She choaked me, and brought the book. Q. How oft did she come to torment you? A. A good many times, she and [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  . Q. Do they come to you in the night as well as the day? A. They come most in the day. Q. Who? A. [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  and [Goody Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  . Q. Where did she take hold of you? A. Upon my throat, to stop my breath. Q. Do you know [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  and [Goody Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  ? A. Yes, here is [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  . (Cloyse) when did I hurt thee? A. A great many times. (Cloyse) Oh! you are a grievous liar. Q. What did this [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  do to you? A. She pinched and bit me till the blood came. Q. How long since this woman came and hurt you? A. Yesterday at meeting. Q. At any time before? A. Yes a great many times. Q. [Mary Walcot!] _walcott_mary  who hurts you? A. [Goody Cloyse.] _cloyce_sarah  Q. What did she do to you? A. She hurt me. Q. Did she bring the book? A. Yes. Q. What was you to do with it? A. To touch it, and be well. -- Then she fell into a fit. Q. Doth she come alone? A. Sometimes alone, and sometimes in company with [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  and [Goody Corey] _corey_martha  , and a great many I do not know. -- Then she fell into a fit again. -- Q. [Abigail Williams!] _williams_abigail  did you see a company at [Mr. Parris's] _parris_samuel  house eat and drink? A. Yes Sir, that was their sacrament. Q. How many were there? A. About forty, and [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  and [Goody Good] _good_sarah  were their deacons. Q. What was it? A. They said it was our blood, and they had it twice that day. Q. [Mary Walcot!] _walcott_mary  have you seen a white man? Yes, Sir, a great many times. Q. What sort of man was he? A. A fine grave man, and when he came, he made all the witches to tremble. -- [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  confirmed the same, and that they had such a sight at [Deacon Ingersoll's] _ingersoll_nathaniel  . Q. Who was at [Deacon Ingersoll's] _ingersoll_nathaniel  then? A. [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  , [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  , [Goody Corey] _corey_martha  , and [Goody Good] _good_sarah  . -- Then [Sarah Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  asked for water, and sat down as one seized with a dying fainting fit; and several of the afflicted fell into fits, and some of them cried out, Oh! her spirit is gone to prison to her sister [Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  . -- Q. [Elizabeth Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  ! you understand whereof you are charged, viz. to be guilty of sundry acts of witchcraft; what say you to it? Speak the truth, and so you that are afflicted, you must speak the truth, as you will answer it before God another day. [Mary Walcot!] _walcott_mary  doth this woman hurt you? A. I never saw her so as to be hurt by her. Q. [Mary Lewis!] _lewis_mercy  does she hurt you? -- Her mouth was  stopped. -- Q. [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  , does she hurt you? -- She could not speak. -- Q. [Abigail Williams!] _williams_abigail  does she hurt you? -- Her hand was thrust in her own mouth. -- Q. John! does she hurt you? A. This is the woman that came in her shift and choaked me. Q. did she ever bring the book? A. Yes, Sir. Q. What to do? A. to write. Q. What, this woman? A. Yes, Sir. Q. Are you sure of it? A. Yes, Sir. -- Again, [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  and [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  were spoke to by the court, but neither of them could make any answer, by reason of dumbness or other fits. Q. What do you say [Goody Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  to these things? A. I take God in heaven to be my witness, that I know nothing of it, no more than the child unborn. Q. [Ann Putman!] _putnam_ann_jr  doth this woman hurt you. A. Yes Sir, a great many times. -- Then the accused looked upon them and they fell into fits. Q. She does not bring the book to you, does she? A. Yes, Sir, often, and saith she hath made her maid set her hand to it. Q. [Abigail Williams!] _williams_abigail  does this woman hurt you? A. Yes, Sir, often. Q. Does she bring the book to you? A. Yes. Q. What would she have you do with it? A. To write in it and I shall be well. -- Did not you, said Abigal, tell me, that your maid had written? [(Procter)] _proctor_elizabeth  Dear Child, it is not so. There is another judgement, dear child. -- Then [Abigail] _williams_abigail  and [Ann] _putnam_ann_jr  had fits. -- By and by they cried out, look you there is [Goody Procter] _proctor_sarah  upon the beam. -- By and by, both of them cried out of [Goodman Procter] _proctor_john  himself, and said he was a wizard. -- Immediately, many, if not all of the bewitched, had grievous fits. -- Q. Ann Putman! who hurt you? A. [Goodman Procter] _proctor_john  and his wife too. -- Afterwards some of the afflicted cried, there is [Procter] _proctor_john  going to take up [Mrs. Pope's] _pope_bathshua  feet. -- And her feet were immediately taken up. -- Q. What do you say [Goodman Proctor] _proctor_john  to these things? A. I know not, I am innocent. -- [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  cried out, there is [Goodman Procter] _proctor_john  going to [Mrs. Pope] _pope_bathshua  , and immediately, said [Pope] _pope_bathshua  fell into a fit. -- You see the devil will deceive you; the children could see what you was going to do before the woman was hurt. I would advise you to repentance, for the devil is bringing you out. -- [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  cried out again, there is [Goodman Procter] _proctor_john  going to hurt [Goody Bibber] _bibber_sara ; and immediately[Goody Bibber] _bibber_sara  fell into a fit. There was the like of [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  , and divers others. -- [Benjamin Gould] _gould_benjamin  gave in his testimony, that he had seen [Goodman Corey] _corey_giles  and his wife, [Procter] _proctor_john  and his wife, [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  , [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  , and [Goody Griggs] _griggs_goody  in his chamber last thursday night. -- [Elizabeth Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  was in a trance during the whole examination. -- During the examination of [Elizabeth Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  , [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  and [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  ,  both made offer to strike at said [Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  ; but when [Abigail's] _williams_abigail  hand came near, it opened, whereas it was made up into a fist before, and came done exceeding lightly, as it drew near to said [Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  , and at length with open and extended fingers, touched [Procter's] _proctor_elizabeth  hood very lightly. Immediately [Abigail] _williams_abigail  cried out, her fingers, her fingers, burned, and [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  took on most greviously, of her head, and sunk down.Salem, April 11th, 1692. [Mr. Samuel Parris] _parris_samuel  was desired by the honourable [Thomas Danforth] _danforth_thomas  , deputy-governor, and the council, to take in writing the aforesaid examinations, and accordingly took and delivered them in; and upon hearing the same, and seeing what was then seen, together with the charge of the afflicted persons, were by the advice of the council all committed by us,[John Hawthorne,] _hawthorne_john [John Corwin,] _corwil_jonathan  Assistants.( Thomas Hutchinson , History of Massachusetts-Bay, II, 21-23 .)

title: SWP No. 106: Elizabeth Proctor
content: SWP No. 106.9(Declaration of [Arthur Abbott] _abbott_arthur  Testimony about Concerning [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  )[November 9, 1692 ]This may Certifie all whome this writting shall come before, that on the 15'th of October 1692, [Arthur Abbut] _abbott_arthur  sent for me [Daniell Epps] _epes_daniel  and [Capt Thomas wade Esqr] _wade_thomas  both of Ipwich, finding himselfe very weake and Ill by Reason of some sad distempers upon him, in Order to the makeing his will. leaveing something that might be to the view of the world -- Reffering to the Evidence that he had given in the Honored Court of Oyer and terminer held at Sallem a little before, which was as followeth, Viz:I [Arthur Abbut] _abbott_arthur  haveing a great impulse upon me to declare unto the Honored Court (as abovesayed sitting in Salem) some things that I had formarly discoursed with [Goodwife procter] _proctor_elizabeth  of Salem about and seen in her House, And gave Evidence thereof unto the s'd Honored Court, being a short time after sent for by the Wor'll [Samuel Appleton] _appleton_samuel  Esq'r And by him accused for takeing a false oath therein, I doe humblie acknowledg my weaknes and reale sorrow for mentioning stateing the time, or any way insisting upon that, Butt being Extraordinarily Charged with fallshood as to the things I had both seen and heard in her House, I did with more than ordinarie Exprestion atest the truth thereof And doe as in the presence of God, before whose Tribunall, both the accuser and the accused must appeare, Certinly affirme upon good Consideration and deep meditation, that to be true, which I had before declared to the Court, neither did I intend any of those great and solem expressions at [Majore Appletons] _appleton_samuel  , should any way be understood as to the time, but the things themselves,  and this desired to leave to the world, not knowing how it might please God to deale with me;This was taken from [Arthur Abbut] _abbott_arthur  at his Earnest request, at the time above mentioned by us[*Daniell Epps] _epes_daniel  . J: pDated this 9'th of November 1692I also affirme that I did hear the said [Arther Abbutt] _abbott_arthur  the day above mentioned (when [Cap't. Epps] _epes_daniel  was present) declare & affirme that what he had before said was the Truth according as is above Expressed. it being read to him or the like words after it was taken downe from his Mouth. speachWittness [*Thos Wade:] _wade_thomas  J. P.(Reverse) [Arthur Abbott] _abbott_arthur  his declaration when sick before Justices( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 108. )

title: SWP No. 106: Elizabeth Proctor
content: SWP No. 106.23(Deposition of [Joseph Bayley] _bayley_joseph  v. [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth )[+ August 5, 1692]The deposition of [Joseph Bayley] _bayley_joseph  aged forty four years testifyeth and saith, that I on the: 25'th day of may last my self & my wife being  bound tooston, on the road when I came in Sight of the house where [John proctor] _proctor_john  did live, there was a very hard blow strook on my brest which caused great pain in my Stomoc & amasement in my head but did see no person near me only my wife behind me on the same hors, and when I came against s'd [proctors] _proctor_john  house according to my understanding I did see [John proctor] _proctor_john  & his wife att s'd house [proctor] _proctor_john  himself loocked out of the windo & his wife did stand Just without the door, I tould my wife of it, & shee did loock that way & could see nothing but a littell maid att the dore I saw no maide there but [proctors] _proctor_john  wife according to my understanding did stand att the dore, afterwards about half a mile from the afores'd house I was taken spechles for sum short time my wife did ask me severall questions and desiered me that if I could not speak I should hould up my hand which I did. and immediatly I could speak as well as ever, and when we came to the way where Salem Road cometh into Ipswich road there I received another blow on my brest which caused much pain that I could not sitt on my hors and when I did alite off my hors, to my understanding I saw a woman coming towards us about sixteen or twenty pole from us but did not know who it was my wife could not see her when I did get up on my hors againe to my understanding there Stood a cow where I saw the woman, after that we went to Boston without any father molestation but after I came home againe to newbury I was pinched and nipt by sumthing invisible for sumtime but now through gods goodness to me I am well againJurat in Curia  by both persons.  (Reverse) [Joseph Bayley] _bayley_joseph  & wife ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 106. )

title: SWP No. 106: Elizabeth Proctor
content: SWP No. 106.24( Testimony of [Samuel Barton] _barton_samuel  & [John Houghton] _houghton_john  for [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  )[+ August 5, 1692]the testimony of [Samuel Barton] _barton_samuel  aged 28 years or therabouts who testifieth and saith that I being at [Thomas putnams] _putnam_thomas_jr  a helping to tend the aflickted folks i heard them talking who the Children Complained of an I heard them teel [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  that she Cryed out of [goody procter] _proctor_elizabeth  and [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  said that she did not Cry out of [goody procter] _proctor_elizabeth  nor nobody she said she did say thear she is but did not teel them who and [Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  & his wife & others told her that she Cryed out of [goody procter] _proctor_elizabeth  and[marcy lewes] _lewis_mercy  said if she did it was when she was out in her head for she said she saw nobody this being the 29 of march in the year 1691/2[John Houghton] _houghton_john  aged 23 testifieth and saith I this Deponent was present at the same tyme above written and I heard [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  , and his wife sayd that [mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  saw or named the wife of [John Procter] _proctor_john  in her fitt and we heard the sayd [mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  affirme that she never sayd that ever she saw her( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 107. )

title: SWP No. 106: Elizabeth Proctor
content: SWP No. 106.25( Deposition of [Samuel Parris] _parris_samuel  , [Nathaniel Ingersoll] _ingersoll_nathaniel  and [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  v. [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  )[+ April 11, 1692]The Deposition of [Sam: Parris] _parris_samuel  aged about.39.years, & [Nathanael Ingersol] _ingersoll_nathaniel  aged about fifty & eight year, & [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  aged about fourty years all of Salem --testifyeth & saith that [John Indian] _indian_john  , [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  & [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  & others of the bewitched persons were severall times & greivously tortured at the Examination of [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  wife to [John Proctor] _proctor_john  of Salem Farmes before the Honoured Magistrates the. II'th April. 1692 . & particularly that[Eliz: Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  was in a Trance during the whole examination unable to speak a word tho often called upon by s'd Magistrates, & also the said [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  & [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  then testifyed that they saw this [Eliz: Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  & her husband [John Proctor] _proctor_john  severall times afflicting of [Bathshua Pope] _pope_bathshua  the wife of [Joseph Pope] _pope_joseph  of Salem Yeoman, at which times the said [Bathshua Pope] _pope_bathshua  was seized with violent fits: & farther that the said [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  & [Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr , both of them made offer to strike at said [Eliz. Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  , but when said [Abigails] _williams_abigail  hand came near to said [Eliz: Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  it opend (whereas it was made up into a fist before) & came down exceeding lightly as it drew near to said [Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  , & at length with open & extended fingers touche said Proctors hood very lightly, & immediately said [Abigail] _williams_abigail  cryed out, Oh! my fingers, my fingers, my fingers burne, & [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  took on most greviously of her head, & sunk down, as far as she could being held up by such as tended her.[Nath: Ingatson] _ingersoll_nathaniel  and [thom. Putman] _putnam_thomas_jr  did on their oaths owne this their testimonies to be the truth be fore the Juriors of Inques this 30 of June 1692.( Essex Institute Collection, No. 18. Phillips Library, Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, MA. Also Rare Books & Manuscripts, MsCh.2.500, Boston Public Library, Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 106: Elizabeth Proctor
content: SWP No. 106.26(Petition of [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  to Recover the Estate of [John Proctor] _proctor_john  )To the Honourable Generall Court Asembled at Boston may twenty seventh 1696the Humble petetion of [Elizabeth procter] _proctor_elizabeth  widow and Relict of [John proctor] _proctor_john  of salem decesed Humbly sheweththat in the yere of our Lord 1692 when many persons in salem and in other towns ther about were accused by som evill disposed or strangly Influenced persons, as being witches or for being guilty of acting witchcraft my s'd Husband John procter and my selfe were accused of such and we both: my s'd Husband and my selfe were soe farr proceded against that we were Condemned but in that sad time of darkness before my said husband was executed it is evident som body had Contrived awill and brought it to him to sign wher in his wholl estat is disposed of not having Regard to a contract in wrighting mad with me before mariag with him; but soe it pleased god to order by his providence that although the sentanc was executed on my dere husband yet through gods great goodnes to your petitioner I am yet alive; sinc my husbands death the s'd will is proved and aproved by the Judg of probate and by that kind of desposall the wholl estat is disposed of; and although god hath Granted my life yet those that claime my s'd husbands estate by that which thay Call awill will not suffer me to have one peny of the Estat nither upon the acount of my husbands Contract with me before mariage nor yet upon the acount of the dowr which as I humbly conceive doth belong or ought to belong to me by the law for thay say that I am dead in the law and therfore my humble request and petetion to this Honoured Generall Court is that by an act of his honoured Court as god hath Contenewed my life and through gods goodnes  without feare of being put to death upon that sentanc you would be pleased to put me Into acapacity to make use of the law to Recover that which of Right by law I ought to have for my nessesary suply and support that as I your petetioner am one of his majestyes subjects I may have the benifett of his laws soe Humbly prayeng that god would direct your honnours in all things to doe that which may be well pleasing to him I subscrib your honours humble petetioner[Elizabeth procter] _proctor_elizabeth  widow Read 10th June. 1692 [sic] in Council (On reverse side of paper)  [Elizebeth Procter] _proctor_elizabeth  her petetion 1696 ( Mass. Archives Vol. 135, no. 109. Massachusetts State Archives, Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 107: John Proctor Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 107.1( [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  v. [John Proctor] _proctor_john  )[April 4, 1692]1692  Apr. 4. [Abig: Williams] _williams_abigail  complained of [Goodm Proctor] _proctor_john  & cryed out w't are you come to, #[are you come to,] you can pinch as well as your wife & more to that purposeAt night she complained of [Goodm: Proctor] _proctor_john  again & beat upon her breast & cryed he pinched her. The like I hear at [Tho. Putmans] _putnam_thomas_jr  house.12 Day, When the Marshall was sent up to enquire of [John Proctor] _proctor_john  & others & I was writing some what thereof as above I met with nothing but interruptions by reason of fits upon [John Indian] _indian_john  & [Abigail] _williams_abigail  , & [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  happening to come in just before, they one & another cryed out there is [Goodm: Proctor] _proctor_john  very often: And [Abigail] _williams_abigail  said there is [Goodm: Proctor] _proctor_john  in the Majstrats lap, at the same time [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  was sitting by a knitting we asked her if she saw [Goodm: Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  (for [Abigail] _williams_abigail  was immediately seized with a fit) but she was deaf & dumb, yet still a knitting, then [Mary] _walcott_mary  recovered her self & confirmed what [Abigail] _williams_abigail  had said that [goodm: proctor] _proctor_john  she saw in the Majstrats lap Then [John] _proctor_john  cryed out to the Dog under the Table to come away for [Goodm: Proctor] _proctor_john  was upon his back, then he cryed out of [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  , O you old Witch, & fell immediately into a violent fit that 3.men & the Marshall could not without exceeding difficulty hold him: In which fit [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  that was knitting & well composed said there was [Goodm: Proctor] _proctor_john  & his wife & [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  helping of him. But so great were the interruptions of [John] _proctor_john  & [Abigail] _williams_abigail  by fits while we were observing these things to notify them, that we were fain to send them both away that I might have liberty to write this  without disturbance [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  abiding composed & knitting whilest I was writing & the two other sent away, yet by & by whilst I was writing Mary Walcot said there [Goody Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  has pincht me nowNote.  [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  never saw [Proctor] _proctor_john  nor his wife till last night coming from the examination at Salem & then she saw [Goody Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  behind her brother Jonathan all the way from the [Widow Gidneys] _gidneys_widow  to Phillips where Jonathan made a little stay But this day & time I have been writing this she saw them many times.Note.  Just now as soon as I had made an end of reading this to the Marshall [Mary W] _warren_mary  [Walcott] immediately cryed O yonder is [Good: Proctor] _proctor_john  & his wife & [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  & [Goody Korey] _corey_martha  & [G [torn] Cloyse] _cloyce_sarah  & Goods Child & then said O [Goodm: Proctor] _proctor_john  is going to choke me & Immediately she was choaktMunday 11'th mo ditto [Lut. Nath: Ingersoll] _ingersoll_nathaniel  Declared that [John Procter] _proctor_john  tould [Joseph Pope] _pope_joseph  that if hee hade [John Indian] _indian_john  in his Costody hee would soone beat the Devell out of him: and so said to severall others(Reverse) Village papers concerning Sundry persons Under Suspition of Witchcraft [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  ag't John procter( Essex Institute Collection, no. 18, Phillips Library, Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, MA.  Also Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1, No. 57, Salem, MA.)

The Jurors for our Sovereigne Lord and Lady the King and Queen pr'sents That John Procter of Salem in the County of Essex, in New England husbandman the II'th Day of Aprill. in the forth Year of the Reigne of our Sovereigne Lord and Lady William & Mary by the Grace of God of England Scottland France & Ireland King and Queen Defenders of the faith &c and Divers other Dayes and times as well before as after certaine Detestable Arts called witchcrafts and Sorceries wickedly and felloniously hath used Practised and Exercised at and within the Towneship of Salem in the County of Essex aforesd. in upon and ag't one [Mercey Lewis] _lewis_mercy  of Salem Villiage in the County of Essex afores'd Singlewoman -- by which said wicked arts the said [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  the 11'th Day of Aprill in the forth Year abovesd and divers other Days and times as well before as after was and is Tortured afflicted Pined: Consumed, wasted and Tormented, and also for sundry other acts of witchcraft by said [John Procter] _proctor_john  Committed and done before and since that time ag't the Peace of our  Sovereigne Lord & Lady the King & Queen, and ag't the form of the Statute in that case made and Provided:Witnesses [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  ] Sworne[Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  ] Sworne(Reverse) Jno Procter No 2 On M: Lewis bil a vera ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 45.)

title: SWP No. 107: John Proctor Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 107.6(Petition for [John Proctor] _proctor_john  and [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  )[++ August 5, 1692 ]We must not Trouble y'r Honr's by Being Tedious, Therefore we being Smitten with the Notice of what hath happened, we Recoon it w'thin the Duties of o'r Charitie, That Teacheth us to do, as we would be done by; to offer thus much for the Clearing of o'r Neighb'rs Inocencie; viz: That we never had the Least Knowledge of such a Nefarious wickedness in o'r said Neighbours, since they have been w'thin our acquaintance; Neither doe we remember -- any such Thoughts in us Concerning them; or any Action by them or either of them Directly tending that way; no more than might be in the lives of any other p'rsons of the Clearest Reputation as to Any such Evills. What God may have Left them to, we Cannot Go into Gods pavillions Cloathed w'th Cloudes of Darknesse Round About.But as to what we have ever seen, or heard of them -- upon o'r Consciences we Judge them Innocent of the crime objected. His Breading hath been Amongst us; and was of Religious Parents in o'r place; & by Reason of Relations, & Proprties w'thin o'r Towne hath had Constant Intercourse w'th us We speak upon o'r p'rsonall acquaintance, & observations: & so Leave our Neighbours, & this our Testimonie on their Behalfe to the wise Thoughts of y'r Honours, & Subscribe &c. The Humble, & Sincere Declaration of us, Subscribers, Inhabitants, in Ipswich, on the behalf of o'r Neighb'rs [Jno Procter] _proctor_john  & his wife now in Trouble & und'r Suspition of Witchcraft.Too the Hon'rable Court of Assistants now Sitting In Boston. -- Hon'red & Right Worshipfull! The foresd [John Procter] _proctor_john  may have Great Reason to Justifie the Divine Sovereigntie of God under thos Severe Remarques of Providence upon his Peac & Hon'r und'r a due Reflection upon his Life Past: And so the Best of us have Reason to Adoar the Great Pittie & Indulgenc of Gods Providenc, that we are not Exposed to the utmost shame, that the Divell can Invent und'r the p'rmissions of Sovereigntie, tho not for that Sin fore Named; yet for o'r many Transgretions; for we Do at present Suppose that it may be A Method w'thin the Seveerer But Just Transaction of the Infinite Majestie of God: that he some times may p'rmitt Sathan to p'rsonate, Dissemble, & therby abuse Inocents, & such as Do in the fear of God Defie the Devill and all his works. The Great Rage he is p'rmitted to attempt holy Job w'th The Abuse he Does the famous Samuell, in Disquieting his Silent Dust, by Shaddowing his venerable P'rson in Answer  to theharmes of WitchCraft, & other Instances from Good hands; may be arg'd Besides the unsearcheable foot stepps of Gods Judgments that are brought to Light Every Morning that Astonish o'r weaker Reasons, To teach us Adoration, Trembling. & Dependanc, &ca but --We must not Trouble y'r Honr's by Being Tedious, Therefore we being Smitten with the Notice of what hath happened, we Recoon it w'thin the Duties of o'r Charitie, That Teacheth us to do, as we would be done by; to offer thus much for the Clearing of o'r Neighb'rs Inocencie; viz: That we never had the Least Knowledge of such a Nefarious wickedness in o'r said Neighbours, since they have been w'thin our acquaintance; Neither doe we remember -- any such Thoughts in us Concerning them; or any Action by them or either of them Directly tending that way; no more than might be in the lives of any other p'rsons of the Clearest Reputation as to Any such Evills. title: SWP No. 107: John Proctor Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 107.8(Statement of [Samuel Sibley] _sibley_samuel  v. [John Proctor] _proctor_john  )[August 5, 1692 ]The morning after the examination of [Goody Nurse.] _nurse_rebecca [Sam: Sibly] _sibley_samuel  met [John Proctor] _proctor_john  about Mr Phillips w'o called to said [Sibly] _sibley_samuel  as he was going to sd Phillips & askt how the folks did at the village He answered he heard they were very bad last night but he had heard nothing this morning [Proctor] _proctor_john  replyed he was going to fetch home his jade he left her there last night & had rather given 40d than let her come up sd [Sibly] _sibley_samuel  askt why he talt so [Proctor] _proctor_john  replyed if they were let alone so we should all be Devils & witches quickly they should rather be had to the Whipping post but he would fetch his jade Home & thresh the Devil out of her & more to the like purpose crying hang them, hang them. And also added that when she was first taken with fits he kept her close to the Wheel & threatened to thresh her, & then she had no  more fits till the next day he was gone forth, & then she must have her fits again firsooth &.Jurat in Curia  [Procter] _proctor_john  ownes he meant [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  attest. [*St. Sewall.] _sewall_stephen  Cler (Reverse) [Sam'l Sibleys] _sibley_samuel  Evidence ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 52.)

title: SWP No. 107: John Proctor Executed, August 19, 1692

title: SWP No. 107: John Proctor Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 107.19(Petition of [John Proctor] _proctor_john  from Prison)[July 23, 1692 ]Salem-Prison,July 23, 1692. [Mr. Mather,] _mather_increase  [Mr. Allen] _allen_john  , [Mr. Moody] _moody_daniel  , Mr. Willard, and [Mr. Bailey] _bailey_thomas .Reverend Gentlemen.The innocency of our Case with the Enmity of our Accusers and our Judges, and Jury, whom nothing but our Innocent Blood will serve their turn, having Condemned us already before our Tryals, being so much incensed and engaged against us by the Devil, makes us bold to Beg and Implore your Favourable Assistance of this our Humble Petition to his Excellency, That if it be possible our Innocent Blood may be spared, which undoubtedly otherwise will be shed, if the Lord doth not mercifully step in. The Magistrates, Ministers, Jewries, and all the People in general, being so much inraged and incensed against us by the Delusion of the Devil, which we can term no other, by reason we know in our own Consciences, we are all Innocent Persons. Here are five Persons who have lately confessed themselves to be Witches, and do accuse some of us, of being along with them at a Sacrament, since we were committed into close Prison, which we know to be Lies. Two of the 5 are (Carriers Sons) Youngmen, who would not confess any thing till they tyed them Neck and Heels till the Blood was ready to come out of their Noses, and 'tis credibly believed and reported this was the occasion of making them confess that they never did, by reason they said one had been a  Witch a Month, and another five Weeks, and that their Mother had made them so, who has been confined here this nine Weeks. My son [William Procter] _proctor_william  , when he was examin'd, because he would not confess that he was Guilty, when he was Innocent, they tyed him Neck and Heels till the Blood gushed out at his Nose, and would have kept him so 24 Hours, if one more Merciful than the rest, had not taken pity on him, and caused him to be unbound. These actions are very like the Popish Cruelties. They have already undone us in our Estates, and that will not serve their turns, without our Innocent Bloods. If it cannot be granted that we can have our Trials at Boston, we humbly beg that you would endeavour to have these Magistrates changed, and others in their rooms, begging also and beseeching you would be pleased to be here, if not all, some of you at our Trials, hoping thereby you may be the means of saving the sheeding our Innocent Bloods, desiring your Prayers to the Lord in our behalf, we rest your Poor Afflicted Servants,[JOHN PROCTER] _proctor_john  , etc. ( Robert Calef , More Wonders of The Invisible World [ London, 1700 ], excerpted in Burr, ed. , Narratives of the Witchcraft Cases, pp. 362-364 .)

[Mary Pickworth] _pickworth_mary  was in a fitt & the above afflicted persons said they saw [Proctor] _proctor_william  afflict her, and he by his touch recovered her [Elizabeth Booth] _booth_elizabeth  said she saw him twist and pinch [poppet] this very Day. she also was afflicted and he recovered her by his touch. [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  said the same.[Eliz Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  owned before the Grand jury upon the oath she had taken that s'd [Will'm Proctor] _proctor_william  had aflicted her both befour her examination at that time, & since many times, notwithstanding his promise to her.[*Robert Payne] _payne_robert  Foreman. as Attest(Reverse) I underwritten being appoynted by authority to take the within examination in [wbar ]ting Doe testify upon oath taken in Court that this is a true coppy of the substance of it, to the best of my knowledge 7't Jan'ry 1692/3[*Wm Murray] _murray_william ( Suffolk Court Files, Vol. 32, Docket no. 2706, Page 29 )

title: SWP No. 113: Ann Pudeator Executed, September 22, 1692
content: SWP No. 113.2([Sarah Churchill] _churchill_sarah  v. [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann  , [Bridget Bishop] _bishop_bridget  , and [George Jacobs, Sr.] _jacobs_george_sr  )[June 1, 1692][Sarah Churchwell] _churchill_sarah  confesseth that [Goody Pudeater] _pudeator_ann  brought the book to this Examin't and she signed it, but did not know her at  that tyme but when she saw her she knew her to be the same and that [Goody Bishop] _bishop_bridget  [abar ][lbar ][sbar ] Olliver appeared to this Examinan't & told her she had killed [John Trasks] _trask_john  Child, (whose Child dyed about that tyme) & said als [Bishop Olliver] _bishop_bridget  afflicted her as alsoe did old [George Jacobs,] _jacobs_george_sr  and before that time this Examin't being afflicted could not doe her service as formerly and her sd Master [Jacobs] _jacobs_george_sr  called her bitch witch & ill names & then afflicted her as #[before] above and that [Pudeater] _pudeator_ann  brought 3: Images like [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy , [Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  , [Eliza' Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  & they brought her thornes & she stuck them in the Images & told her the persons whose likeness they were, would be afflicted, & the other day saw [Goody Olliver] _bishop_bridget  [sitt] sate upon her knee,Jurat in Curia  by [Sarah Churchill] _churchill_sarah  this Confession was taken before [John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  and [Jonathan Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  Esq'rs 1'0 Junij 1692, as attests [*Tho: Newton] _newton_thomas  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 262. )

title: SWP No. 113: Ann Pudeator Executed, September 22, 1692
content: SWP No. 113.3(Examination of [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann  )[July 2, 1692 ][An Puddeater:] _pudeator_ann  examined before the Majestrates of Salem July 2: 92  [Sarah: Churchwell:] _churchill_sarah  was bid to: say what she: had to say of her: You have charged her with bringing: the book to you:A Yes. S'd: [Churchwell] _churchill_sarah have you seen her since. A no: [goodwife Puddeater:] _pudeator_ann  you have: formerly: bin complaynd of: we now further enquire: here is one person: saith you brought her: the book which is [Sarah Churchell] _churchill_sarah : look on the person: ses [Churchell] _churchill_sarah : you did bring me the book: I was at [goodman Jacobses] _jacobs_george_sr [Puddeater] _pudeator_ann  s'd I never saw the woman before now::it was told [Puddeater] _pudeator_ann  this mayd charged you with: bringing her: the book: at the last examinat'n [Puddeater] _pudeator_ann  s'd I never saw: the devils book nor knew: that he had one [L't Jer: Neal:] _neale_jeremiah  was asked what he could say of this woman [Neal] _neale_jeremiah  s'd she had bin an ill carriaged woman: & since my wife has bin sick of the small pox: this woman has come to my house pretending kindnes: and I was glad to see it: she asked: whether she might use our morter: which was used: for my wife: and I consented  to it: but I afterward repented of it: for the nurs told. me my wife was the wors: for senc she was very ill of a flux: which she had not beforeWhen the officer came: for: Puddeater: the nurs s'd you are come to late for. my wife grew wors. till she dyed: s'd Pudeater had often thretned my wife: [Eliz Hubard:] _hubbard_elizabeth  s'd she: had seen s'd [Pudeater] _pudeator_ann  #(but she) s'd Mary Walcut: but she had not hurt her she had seen her with [goodwife Nurs] _nurse_rebecca [goody Puddeater] _pudeator_ann  what did you doe with the ointments that you had in yo'r hous so many of them:: she s'd I never had ointment nor oyl but neats foot oyl in my hous since my husband dyed: but the Constable [Joseph Neal] _neale_joseph  affirmd she had: she had near 20 that had oynment or greas: in them: a little in a thing: she s'd she never had any oyntment but neats foot oyl: in the hous but what was in these things the Constabl. Speakes. of.A: It was greas: to make sope of::but: why: did you put them in so many things when one would have held all: but answerd not the porpose: but the constabl. s'd o. oyntments were of several sorts [Sarah Vibber] _bibber_sara  did you ever se this woman: before now answerd no [An putnum] _putnam_ann_jr  s'd she had never seen: her but since she come: to Salem Town last: s'd [Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  fell into a fitt: & s'd Puddeater: was commanded to take her by the wrist: & did & s'd [Putnum] _putnam_ann_jr  was well presently: [Many Warin] _warren_mary  fell into: two fitts quickly after. one another: & both times was helped: by s'd [Puddeaters:] _pudeator_ann  taking her by the wrist( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 264. )

title: SWP No. 113: Ann Pudeator Executed, September 22, 1692
content: SWP No. 113.4(Summons for Witnesses v. [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann  and [Alice Parker] _parker_alice  )[September 5, 1692]W'm & Mary by the Grace of God of England Scotland france & Ireland King & Queen defend' s  &c.To the Sheriff of Essex or deputy Greeting We Comand you to Warn [John Wesgate] _westgate_john  [John Bullock] _bullock_john  [Martha Dutch] _dutch_martha  [Susanna Dutch] _dutch_susanna  [L't Jeremiah Neale] _neale_jeremiah  [John Beckett] _beckett_john  [John Best Jun'r] _best_john_jr  [Jno Loader] _louder_john  [Sarah parott] _parott_sarah That they & Every of them appear at the Next Court of Oyer & Terminer holden at Salem on the Next Tuesday at Twelve of the Clock There to Testify the Truth to the best of thier knowledge On certain Indictments to be Exhibited against [Alce Parker] _parker_alice  & [Ann Pudeater] _pudeator_ann  hereof make return fail not dated in Salem Sep'r 5'th 1692 in the fourth yeare of Our Reign[*Stephen Sewall] _sewall_stephen  Cler(Reverse) Sep't 5'th 1692. I have Sumoned and have Warned all the within named persons [John Best Jun'r] _best_john_jr  Except sd [Best] _best_john_jr  being Removed to Ipswich that thay and Every of them appeare to Give in their Evid: &c: att time and place within writtenP'r me [*George Herrick] _herrick_george  Dep't sheriff( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 263. )

content: SWP No. 113.7([Mary Warren] _warren_mary  v. [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann )[Mary Warin] _warren_mary  upon her oath: that she hath taken affirms: to the Jury of inquest: that [Ann Puddeater:] _pudeator_ann  hath often: afflicted me: by biting me pinching me sticking pins in me: & choaking me: and particularly on the 2: day of July: att her examination: s'd [Puddeater] _pudeator_ann  did: afflict#(e) me greatly: also she or her Apperition: did offer: me the book to sign to: she told: me also that she was the caus of Jno Turners  falling  off: the cherry tree: to his great: hurt: & which: amazed him in his head & almost kild him: she told me also: she was the caus of: [Jeremiah Neals] _neale_jeremiah  wifes death: & I saw her hurt: [Eliz Hubbard:] _hubbard_elizabeth  [Mary Walcot:] _walcott_mary  & [An Putnam:] _putnam_ann_jr  the last night she: afflicted: me also: last night: by her wichcrafts & I doe veryly: beleev: s'd [Ann Puddeater] _pudeator_ann  is a: wich: she affirms [Puddeater:] _pudeator_ann  told her: she kild her husband [Puddeater:] _pudeator_ann  & his first wife and that she was an instrument of [Jno Bests:] _best_john_jr  wifes death: Sept'r 7: 1692  Sworne in Court( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 112 )

content: SWP No. 113.11([Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  v. [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann  )[Mary Walcot:] _warren_mary  upon oath: affirmd to the Jury of inquest: that: she hath seen [An Puddeater:] _pudeator_ann  afflict [Mary: Warin:] _warren_mary  [An Putnam:] _putnam_ann_jr  & [Eliz Hubbard:] _hubbard_elizabeth  at the time of her examination: at [M'r Tho Beadles:] _beadles_thomas  and also the last night: I saw: her: afflict [Mary Warin] _warren_mary  [#[Mercy Lewis]] _lewis_mercy  [An Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  & [Eliz Hubbard:] _hubbard_elizabeth  by wichcraft: & I verily beleev: s'd [Pudeater:] _pudeator_ann  is a witch September: 7: 92.  & that this day she hath afflicted this deponent.Jurat in Curia Sep'r 10. 92. title: SWP No. 113: Ann Pudeator Executed, September 22, 1692
content: SWP No. 113.15( [John Best, Jr.] _best_john_jr  v. [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann  )The testimony of [John best Junear] _best_john_jr  hou testifieth uppon his oath before the grand Inquest that his Mother did severall tims in har siknis complain of [ann pudeatar] _pudeator_ann  of salim the wife of [Jacob pudeatar] _pudeator_jacob  how she #(did captur) had beewiched har and that she did beleve she would kill har before she had dun: and soo she said severall times duering hear siknis: until har death: allso I this deponant: did severall tims goo in to the wouds to fech my fathars Cowes: and I did drive [goode pudeatars] _pudeator_ann  Cow back from. our Cowes: and I being all alone: [ann pudeatar:] _pudeator_ann  would Chide me when I Came houm: for turning the Cow bak: by Reson of which I this deponant did Conclude said [pudeater] _pudeator_ann  was a wichJurat in Curia  (Reverse) [John best: Junior] _best_john_jr  against pudeatar ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 113 )

title: SWP No. 113: Ann Pudeator Executed, September 22, 1692
content: SWP No. 113.16(Petition of [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann  )The humble Petition of [Ann Poodeater] _pudeator_ann  unto the honoured Judge and Bench now Setting in Judicature in Salem humbly sheweth:That Wheras your Poor and humble Petitioner being condemned to die and knowing in my own conscience as I shall shortly answer it before the great God of heaven who is the searcher & knower of all hearts: That the Evidence of [Jno Best Sen'r] _best_john_sr  and [Jno Best Jun'r] _best_john_jr  and [Sam'll Pickworth] _pickworth_samuel  w'ch was given in against me in Court were all of them altogether false & untrue and besides the abovesaid [Jno Best] _best_john_jr  hath been formerly whipt and likewise is rcorded for A Lyar I would humbly begg of yo'r honours to Take it into your Judicious and Pious  consideratio That my life may not be taken away by such false Evidence and wittnesses as these be likewise the Evidence given in against me by [Sarah church] _churchill_sarah  and [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  I am altogether ignorant off and know nothing in the least measure about it nor nothing else concernig the crime of witchcraft for w'ch I am condemned to die as will be known to men and angells att the great day of Judgment begging and imploring your prayers att the throne of grace in my behalfe and your poor and humble petition'r shall for ever pray as she is bound in duty for yo'r hon'rs health and happiness in this life and eternall felicity in the world to come(Reverse) [Ann Pudeaters] _pudeator_ann  Peticon An Pudeaters( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 113 )

title: SWP No. 114: Wilmott Reed Executed, September 22, 1692
content: SWP No. 114.1(Warrant for apprehension of [Wilmott Reed] _redd_wilmot  )To the Constables  of Marblehead You are in theire Majest's names hereby required to apprehend and bring before Us [willmut Reed] _redd_wilmot  the wife of [Samuell Reed] _reed_samuel  of Marblehead, on Tuesday next being the 31 day of this Instant moneth of May aboute ten of the Clock in the forenoon at the house of L't [Nathan'l Ingerslls] _ingersoll_nathaniel  in Salem Village; who Stands Charged with having Committed Sundry acts of Witchcraft on the bodys of [Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  and [Marcy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  and Others[?] of Salem Village to theire great hurt &c, in order to her Examination Relateing to the aboves'd premises and hereof you are not to faileDated Salem  May 28'th 1692  P us [John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  ] Assis'ts [Jonathan. Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  ] Assis'ts (Reverse) In answer to the withinmentioned warrant I have apprehended [Willmot Reed] _redd_wilmot  Wife to [Sam'll Reed] _reed_samuel  of Marblehead & brought her to the house of [L't Ingersals] _ingersoll_nathaniel  , May the 31'th 92hi>. [*James Smith] _smith_james  Con'st for Marblehead ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 Page 3 )

title: SWP No. 114: Wilmott Reed Executed, September 22, 1692
content: SWP No. 114.2(Indictment v. [Wilmott Reed] _redd_wilmot  , No. 1)Essex in the Province of the Massachusetts Bay in New England Ss//] Anno RR's & Reginae Gulielmi & Mariae Angliae &ca Annoq'e Domini 1692 The Juriors for our Sov'r Lord and Lady the King & Queen doe present That [Willmott Redd] _redd_wilmot  Wife of [Samuel Redd] _reed_samuel  of Marblehead In the County of Essex fisherman upon the Thirty first day of May In the Yeare afores'd and divers other days and times as well before as after Certaine detestable Arts called Witchcraft and Sorceries Wickedly Mallitiously and felloniously hath used practised and exercised At and in the Towne of Salem in the County of Essex-Aforesaid in upon and against one [Eliza' Booth] _booth_elizabeth  of Salem Aforesaid Single Woman -- by which said Wicked Acts the said [#(Elizabeth Booth WIlmott Redd) Eliz'a Booth] _booth_elizabeth  The day & yeare afore said and divers other days and times both before and after was and is Tortured Aflicted Consumed Pined Wasted and Tormented and also for Sundry other Acts of Witchcraft by the said [Willmott Redd] _redd_wilmot  Comitted and done before and Since that time against the peace of our Sov'r Lord & Lady the King & Queen theire Crown and Dignity and the forme Of the Stattute in that case made and Provided.(Reverse) Indictm't Vs [Willmott Redd] _redd_wilmot  for:bewitching [Eliza' Booth] _booth_elizabeth  Ignoramus( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 Page 3 )

content: SWP No. 114.3(Indictment v.
