title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.5(Examination of [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Examination of [John Willard.] _willard_john  .18 May. 1692 All the afflicted in most miserable fits when he came in, except [John Indian.] _indian_john When the Warrant was read, he lookt upon severall & they fell into fits. Here is a returne of the warrant that you were fled from Authority that is acknowledgment of guilt, but yet notwithstanding this we require you to confesse the truth in this matter. I shall, as I hope, I shall be assisted by the Lord of Heaven, & for my #[flying away I] going away I was affrighted & I thought by my withdrawing it might be better, I fear not but the Lord in his due time will make me as white as snow. What do you say? Why do you hurt them, it is you or your appearance? I know nothing of appearance. Was this the man? Severall said yes. They charge you, it is you or your appearance. I know nothing of appearance, & the God of Heaven will clear me -- Well they charge you not only with this but with dreadfull murthers, & I doubt not if you be guilty, God will not suffer evidences to be wanting. [Eliz: Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  testifyed against him & he lookt upon her, & she fell into a fit.[Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  testimony read.If you desire mercy from God, then confesse & give glory to God. S'r as for sins I am guilty of if the Minister askt me I am ready to confess. If you have thus revolted from God you are a dreadfull sinner [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  cryed out, oh! he bites me[Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  cryed out much of himOpen your mouth, don't bite your lips I will stand with my mouth open, or I will keep it shut, I will stand any how, if you will tell me how [An: Putmans] _putnam_ann_jr  testimony read.Do you hear this evidence read? Yes I do hear it [Sus: Sheldons] _sheldon_susannah  testimony read.What do you say to this murdering and bewitching your relations? One would think (said he) that no creature except they belong to [torn] their Cradle would be guilty of such things. You say you would bewitch your Grand-father because you, or your appearance saith he prays that the Kingdom of Satan may be thrown down. He offered large talk We do not send for you to preach [Benja. Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  gave in evidence of his unnaturall usage to his wife.You had much need to boast of your affections There are a great many lyes told, I would desire my wife might be called [Peter Prescot] _prescott_peter  testifyed that he with his own mouth told him of his beating of his wifeHe urged [Aaron Wey] _way_aaron  to speak[Aaron Wey] _way_aaron  thereupon said if I must speak, I will, I can say you have been very cruell to poor creatures.Let some person go to him [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  said she would go.He said let not that person but another come [John Indian] _indian_john  #[said] cryed out he cuts me[Susan: Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  said there is the black man whispering in his ear, & he should not confesseWhat do you say to this S'r I heard nothing nor see any thing. [Susan: Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  tryed to come to him, but fell down immediately.What is the reason she cannot come near you? They cannot come near any that are accus'd. Why do you say so, they could come near [Nehemiah Abbot] _abbott_nehemiah_jr  , the children could talk with him[Mary Warren] _warren_mary  in a great fit carryed to him, & he clasping his hand upon her arm, she was well presently.They all or most of the afflicted testifyed that the dead those that he had murdered were now about him. Do you think these are bewitcht.Yes, I really beleive it. Well, others they have accused it is found true that they are the guilty persons, why should it be false in you? [Susan: Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  & [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  testifyed that now his appearance comes from his body & afflicts them.How do you think of this, how comes it to pass? It is not from me, I know nothing of it. If you can find in your heart to confess it is possible you may obtain mercy & therefore bethink your [torn] S'r I cannot confess that which I do not know Well but if these things are true Heaven and Earth will rise up against you. I am as innocent as the child that is now to be borne. Can you pray the Lords prayer? Yes Let us hear you. He stumbled at the thresh hold & said Maker of heaven & earth He began again & mist It is a strange thing, I can say it at another time. I think I am bewitcht as well as they, & laughtAgain he mist Again he mist & cryed well this is a strange thing I cannot say it Again he tryed & mist Well it is these wicked ones that do so overcome me [Joshua Rea] _rea_joshua_jr  gave in testimony that last night he said he hoped he should confesse, but had a hard heart, but he hoped he should confesse.Well say what you will confesse I am as innocent as the child unborne. Do you not see God will not suffer you to pray to him? Are not you sensible of it? Why it is a strange thing? No it is no strange thing that God will not suffer a Wizard to pray to him. There is also the jury of Inquest that will bear hard against you -- therefore confesse. Have you never wisht harm to your neighbors? No never #[in my life] since I had a being. Well confesse & give glory to God, take counsell whilst it is offered I desire to take good counsell, but if it was the last time I was to speak, I am innocent (On Reverse) [John Willards] _willard_john  ExaminationExam[ination] ag't [Willard] _willard_john ( Boston Public Library -- Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts  [ 1939 acquisition ])

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.6(Examination of [John Willard] _willard_john  -- Second Version)The Examination of [John Willard] _willard_john  .18. May 1692 The afflicted in most miserable fits upon his this Examinants drawing near After several of them were recovered, he lookt upon them, & they again fell into fits, whilst the warrant & returne was reading. Here is a returne of the Warrant that you were fled from Authority that is an acknowledgment of guilt, but yet notwithstanding we require you to confess the truth in this matter. I shall, as I hope, I shall be assisted by the Lord of Heaven, & for my going away I was affrighted, & I thought by my withdrawing it might be better, I fear not but the Lord in his due time will make me as white as snow. What do you say? Why do you hurt these? It is you, or your appearance. I know nothing of appearance. Is this the man? Several of the afflicted said yes. They charge you, it is you or your appearance. I know nothing of appearance, & the God of Heaven will clear me. They charge you, not only with this, but with dreadfull murders, & I doubt not if you be guilty, God will not want evidence. [Eliz: Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  testifyed that he afflicted her, & then he lookt upon her & she fell into a fit.[Mercy Lewes] _lewis_mercy  testimony read.If you desire mercy from God, then you must confesse & give Glory to God. S'r as to sins I am guilty of, if the minister asks me I am ready to confesse If you have revolted from God you are a dreadful sinner. [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  cryed out, oh he bites me[Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  cryed out much of himOpen your mouth, don't bite your lips. I will stand with my mouth open, or I will keep it shut: I will stand any how, if you will tell me how. [Ann Putnams] _putnam_ann_jr  evidence readDo you hear this evidence read? Yes I do hear it. [Susan: Sheldons] _sheldon_susannah  testimony readWhat do you say to this murdering & Bewitching your relations? One would think (said he) that no creature except they belong to hell from their Cradle would be guilty of such things. You say, you will bewitch your Grandfather because he prays that the Kingdom of Sathan may be thrown down The examinant began a large oration We do not send for you to Preach. [Ben: Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  testifyed for all his natural affections he abused his wife much & broke sticks about her in beating of herYou had need to boast of your good affections There are a great many lyes told, I could desire my wife might be called [Peter Prescot] _prescott_peter  testifyed that he with his own mouth told him of beating his wife.It seems very much one of your confidence & ability to speak, should be no more #[in] courageous than to run away: by your running away you tell all that #[world] you are afraid The examinant called upon [Aaron Wey] _way_aaron  & urged him #[before] to speak if he knew anything against him[Aaron Wey] _way_aaron  if I must speak I will, I can say you have been very cruel to poor creatures.Let some persons goe to him [Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  said she would go.He said let not that person but another come. John Indian  cryed out Oh! he cuts me.[Susan: Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  said there is the black man whispering in his ear, & he should not confessWhat do you say to this? S'r, I heard nothing, nor see nothing. [Susan: Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  tryed to come near him but fell down immediately, & he took hold of her hand with a great deal of do, but she continued in her fit crying out, O [John Willard] _willard_john  , [John Willard] _willard_john  & #[the ex]What was the reason you could not come near him? The black man stood between us. They cannot come near any that are accused. Why do you say they could not come near any that were accused: You know [Nehemiah Abbet] _abbott_nehemiah_jr  they could talk with him.[Mary Warren] _warren_mary  in a great fit carried to him & he clasping his hand upon her arm was well presently.Why said he was it not before so with [Susannah Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah ?Because said she the standers by you did not Clasp your hand before. The like said the Constable and others. They all or most testifyed that the dead those that he had murdered were now about him. Do you think these are Bewitcht?Yes, I verily believe it. Well others they have accused it is found true on & why should it be false in you? [Sus. Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  & [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  testify that now h[torn] appearance come from his body & afflicts them.What do you think of this? How comes this to pass? It is not from me. I know nothing of it You have taxt your self wonderfully, it may be you do not think of it. How so? You cryed up your tender affections and here round about they testify your cruelty to man & beast, & by your flight you have given great advantage to the Law, things will bear hard upon you, if you can therefore find in your heart to repent it is possible you may obtain mercy & therefore bethink your self S'r I cannot confess that I do not know Well but if these things are true Heaven & Earth will rise up against you. I am as innocent as the child that is now to be born. Can you pray the Lords prayer? Yes. Well let us hear you. He stumbled at the threshold (that is the #(beging) beginning) & said Maker of Heaven & Earth. He began #[against] again & mist It is a strange thing, I can say it at another time. I think I am bewitcht as well as they & laughtAgain he began & said trespass against & mist us. He began again, & cryed being puzled Well this is a strange thing I cannot say it He begun again & could not say it Well it is these wicked ones that do so overcome me [Josh: Rea Sen'r] _rea_joshua_sr  gave in testimony that last night he said he hoped he should confess tho he had a hard heart, but, but he hoped he should confess.Well say w't you will confess. I am as innocent as the child unborn. Do not you see God will not suffer you to pray to him, are not you sensible of it? Why it is a strange thing. No it is no strange that God will not suffer a wizard to pray to him. There is also the jury of inquest for murder that will bear hard against you. Therefore confess. Have you never wisht harm to your Neighbours? Never since I had a being. Well confess & give glory to God. Take counsell. I desire to hearken to all good counsell. If it was the last time I was to speak I am innocent. This is a true account of the #(abovesaid) Examination of [John Willard] _willard_john  without wrong to any party according to my original from Characters at the moments thereofWitness my hand [*Sam: Parris] _parris_samuel On Reverse: [John Willard's] _willard_john  Examination( Boston Public Library -- Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts  [ 1939 acquisition ])

content: SWP No. 137.15([Susannah Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  v. [John Willard] _wilkins_john  )This this Is the first to bee Read the 9'th of may 1692  this #[this] Is the first to bee Read the testimony of [Susanah Shelton] _sheldon_susannah  Aged 18'ten yers or there About testifieth And saith the day of the date hereof I sawe At [natt Ingersons] _ingersoll_nathaniel  house the Apparitions of thes 4 persons [William shaws] _shaw_william  first wife the [widdow Cooke] _cook_elizabeth  gooman Jons And his Child And Among these Came the Apparition of [John Willard] _willard_john  to whome these 4 said you have murdered us these 4 haveing said thus to willard thay turned As Red As blood And turning About to look on mee they turned As pale As deth these 4 desiered mee to tell [Mr. hathorn] _hawthorne_john [J willard] _willard_john  hering them pulled out A knif saying If I did hee would Cut my throote the second to be ReadThe sam day ther Apeared to mee [eleasabath Coolson] _colson_elizabeth  and shee took a book and would have mee to set my hand to it and I would not and then shee Profered mee a blak Peas of monny and seaid I might touch that and I shall be well -- may the 10 on tusday ther a Peared to mee the sam appearations and another with them In the liknes of a man and they seaid I should Gooe and tell [mr hathorn] _hawthorne_john  of it then the seaid [willard] _willard_john  seaid he would break my head and stop my leegs that I should not gooe there did Appeared to Mee a shineing Man whoe tolde I should goe And tell w't I had heard And seen to [Mr hathorn] _hawthorne_john  this [willard] _willard_john  being there present tould Mee If I did hee would Cutt my throate At this same time and place this shining man told Mee that If I did goe to tell this to [Mr Hathorn] _hawthorne_john  that I should bee well goeing And Coming but I should bee Afflicted there then said I to the shining man hunt willard Away And I would beleve what he said that he might not chock mee with that the shining man held up his hand And willard vanished Away about two hours after the sam aPeared to mee againe and the seaid willard with them and I asked them wher ther wonds were and they seaid ther would Com a angell from heaven and would showe them and forth with the angell come I asked what the mans name was that A Peared to mee last and the angell tould his name was Southerek and the angell lifted up his winding sheet and out of his left sid hee Poolled out a Pitchfork tiang and Pot it in again and lik wise hee opened all ther winding Sheets and Showed all ther wound and the whit man tould mee to  tell [Mr Hathoren] _hawthorne_john  of It and I tould him to hunt willard away and I would and he held up his hand and he vanished away( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 97 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.16([Susannah Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  and [Elizabeth Colson] _colson_elizabeth  )The second to be Read the Evening of the same day Came to mee the Appariton of these three [John Willard] _willard_john  [Elizabeth Colson] _colson_elizabeth  And one old man which I knew not whom tempted her with their Boocks and money And Afflicted her sorely All the fore parte of the night I saw this willard suckle the Apparition of two black piggs on his breasts And this [Colson] _colson_elizabeth  suckled As it Appeared A yellow bird this old man Which I knew not Suckled A black snake then [willard] _willard_john  tempted mee Again with his Boocke I said to Willard how long have you binn A wizard hee told mee twenty years and forth with they kneelled to Prayer to the Black man with a loung Crouned hat which then was with them and then they vanished away --may the -11- being on wensday -- 1692 as I was Coming to the bound by the brige I saw the seaid [willard] _willard_john  and the olld man coming overe the waters they landed by Gorge hakers In a dish and at the Preasant writige thes three apeared with a booke tempting mee after the sam maner[Susanah Shelton.] _sheldon_susannah  did this 3. dy of June onid this har testimony before us the Jurrors of Inquest to be the truth( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 98 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.17([Susanna Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  , [Elizabeth Colson] _colson_elizabeth  , [George Jacobs, Jr.] _jacobs_george_jr  , [Rebecca Jacobs] _jacobs_rebecca  , [John Proctor] _proctor_john  , and [Elizabeth Proctor] _proctor_elizabeth  )May 17'th #(of) In the yeare 92  the Complainte of [Sewzanah Shellten] _sheldon_susannah  saith that [Elizabeth Colson] _colson_elizabeth  Remaynes in Afflicting of the said [Shellten] _sheldon_susannah  night & day. And Allso mrs white also [John willard] _willard_john  Remaines in  Afflicting of hur both day and night also mr Inglish. and his wife Remaines afflicting of hure both night and day[#(J) Googe Jacobs] _jacobs_george_jr  and his wife afflicting of hur the last lords day and tempting the said [Shellten] _sheldon_susannah  to sete her hand to the booke thay both appearing yesterday againe And would. have hur sete hur #(to sete) hand to the booke the said [Shelten] _sheldon_susannah  said she would not then she she said she would stabb hur then sudenly she Reseaved A sore wound on hur lifte side then: [Ellizebeth Colson] _colson_elizabeth  stabbing of hur one the back Right against the other woundes soe that she spente blood then goody prockter Appearing to her and Afflicting of hur and tempting hur to sete hur hand to the booke And last night goody prockter Appearing againe and would have hur sete hur hand to the booke and towld hur that she hade sete hur hand to the booke a grete while agooe. also s'd Shelden has severall times seen Jno procter and his wife afflict [Mary Warin:] _warren_mary  -- senc they. s'd procker: & his wife were in prison(On reverse side of paper) [Susannah Shelden] _sheldon_susannah  ag't [Jno Willard] _willard_john  [Eliz Coleson] _colson_elizabeth  [Geo. Jacob] _jacobs_george_sr  & wife and [Eliz. procter] _proctor_elizabeth  [] _sheldon_susannah  ag't G Buckly & daufter & G Hart( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 96 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.18( [Ann Putnam, Sr] _putnam_ann_sr  . v. [John Willard] _willard_john  , [William Hobbs] _hobbs_william  , and [Martha Corey] _corey_martha )[Hanah Putnam] _putnam_hannah  aged 30 years Saith that the shape of [Sam'll Fuller] _fuller_samuel  & [Lidia Wilkins] _wilkins_lydia  this day told me at my Owne house by the bed side. that #(fi) #(that) who appeared in winding sheets that if I did not Goe & tell [mr Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  that [John Willard] _willard_john  had Murdered them. they would tare Me #her) to peices I knew them when they were living & it was Exactly thier resemblance & Shape & at the Same Time the appa[rbar ][ibar ]con of [John Willard] _willard_john  told me that he had killd [Sam'll Fuller] _fuller_samuel  [Lidia Wilkins] _wilkins_lydia  [Goody Shaw] _shaw_goody  & Fullers Second wife & [Aron Ways] _way_aaron  Child & [Ben: fullers] _fuller_ben  Child & this deponents Child. Sarah 6 weeks old & [Phillips Knights] _knight_philip  Child w'th the help of [Wm #Knig) Hobbs] _hobbs_william . & [Jonathan Knights] _knight_jonathan  Child & 2 of [Ezek: Cheevers] _cheever_ezekiel  Children with the help of [Wm Hobbs] _hobbs_william . [Anna Elliott] _elliot_anna  & [Isack Nicholls] _nicholls_isaac  w'th help of [Wm Hobbs] _hobbs_william  : shaps & that if [mr Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  would not beleive them (ie) [Sam. Fuller] _fuller_samuel  & [Lida Wilkins] _wilkins_lydia  [pbar ]haps they would appear to the Majistrates[The Same day Joseph Fullers] _fuller_joseph  apparicon also came to me & told me that [Goody Corey] _corey_giles  had Killd him #(?) the Spector afors'd told me that vengeance vengeance was Cried by s'd [fuller] _fuller_joseph This Rel[abar ][cbar ]on is true marke Ann  [Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  Sworne in Court June 2'd 1692 (On reverse side of paper) [Ann Putnams] _putnam_ann_jr  Relacon Sworne ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 96 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.19(Samuel Parris, [Nathaniel Ingersoll] _ingersoll_nathaniel  , and [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The deposition of [Samuel Parris] _parris_samuel  aged about .39. years, & [Nathanell Ingersoll] _ingersoll_nathaniel  aged about fifty & eight yeares & also [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  aged about fourty yeares all of Salem testifyeth & saith that [Eliz: Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth , [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  & [Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  & [John Indian] _indian_john  were exceedingly tortured at the Examination of [John Willard] _willard_john  of Salem Husbandman, before the honoured Magistrates the .18. May .1692 . & also that upon his looking upon [Eliz: Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  She was knockt down, & also that some of the afflicted & particularly [Susannah Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  then & there testifyed that they saw a black man whispering him in the ear, & that said [Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  could not come near to said [Willard] _willard_john  but was knockt down, & also that [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  in a fit being carried to him the said [Willard] _willard_john  she said [Warren] _warren_mary  was presently well upon his grasping her arm, & farther that severall of the afflicted also then testifyed, that divers of those he had murthered then rose up against him, & farther that he could by no means rightly repeat the Lords Prayer tho he made manifold assayes.[Mr Samuel parris] _parris_samuel  and [Nathaniel Ingerson] _ingersoll_nathaniel  and: [thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  did uppon the oath which they had taken did before us the Juris of inquest owne this their testimony: this .3. dy of June: 92.Sworn in Court by [Mr. Parris] _parris_samuel  & [Tho: Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr (On reverse side of paper) The depo[tbar ][ibar ]on of [Sam: Parris] _parris_samuel  &c ags't[John Willard] _willard_john  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 97 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.20([Sarah Bibber] _bibber_sara  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )june the .3. 1692: [Sarah vibber] _bibber_sara  aged 36 years or thear abouts testifie and saith the day befor [Jno Welard] _willard_john  was exammnend at the villeg I being in lef't [Ingorsols] _ingersoll_nathaniel  Chambor I saw the aporishtion of [john willard] _willard_john  com to [mary walcot] _walcott_mary  & marcy luis & hurt them grivosly & almost choked Them Then I tould of it & emediatly the said [wiliard] _willard_john  fel upon me & tormented me grevesly & pinched me & threw me down[sarah vibber] _bibber_sara : ownid this har testimony before us the Jurriars for Inquest: this. .3. of June: 1692 Jurat in Curia.  (Reverse)[Sarah Vibber] _bibber_sara  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 99 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.21([Elizabeth Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The deposistion of [Elizabeth Hubburd] _hubbard_elizabeth  agged about 17 years who testifieth and saith that on the 11 may 1692 I saw the Apperishtion of [John willard] _willard_john  of Salem villege who did Immediatly torment me and urged me to writ in his book: but on the 18th of may being the day of his Examination [John willard] _willard_john  did most greviously tortor me dureing the time of his Examination for if he did but look upon me he would Immediatly strick me down or almost choak me: and also dureing the time of his Examination I saw the Apperishtion of [John willard] _willard_john  goe from him and afflect the bodys of [mary walcott] _walcott_mary  [mircy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Abigaill williams] _williams_abigail  and [Ann putnam Jun'r] _putnam_ann_jr [elizabeth hubburt:] _hubbard_elizabeth  did one this testimony aftar the Reding of it before us the Jurris for Inquest this. .3. dy of June: 92(Reverse) [Elizabeth Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  ag't [John Willard] _willard_john ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 99 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.22([Elizabeth Booth] _booth_elizabeth  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Deposistion of [Eliz: Booth] _booth_elizabeth  agged about. 18 years who testifieth and saith that severall times sence the later end of June 1692 I have ben most greviously afflected and tormented by [John willard] _willard_john  or his Apperanc by pinching pricking and almost choaking me to death: also I have often seen [John willard] _willard_john  or his apperanc most greviously tormenting and afflecting my Brother [George Booth] _booth_george  almost Redy to kill him:[Susannah Shelden] _sheldon_susannah  also Testfieth that within this fortnight she hath seen [John willard] _willard_john  or his Apparancs most greviously torment and afflect [George Booth] _booth_george  almost Redy to prese him to death.Susannah Shelden also Testfieth that within this fortnight she hath seen John willard or his Apparancs most greviously torment and afflect George Booth allmost Redy to prese him to death. ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 100 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.23( [Lydia Nichols] _nichols_lydia  and [Margaret Knight] _knight_margaret  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The deposition of [Lydia Nicols] _nichols_lydia  aged. 46 yeares and of [Margaret knight] _knight_margaret . Aged. 20. years #(and of Margaret) who testefy and say. That the wife of [John Willard] _willard_john  being at her fathers house. when the sayd [Willard] _willard_john  lived at Groaton. she made a lamentable complaynt. how cruelly her husband had beaten her: she thought her selfe that she should never recover of the blows he had given her: the next morninge he was got into a litle hole under the stayers and then she thought some thinge extraordinary had befallne him. then: he ran out at the doore: and ran up. A steep hill. almost impossible for any man to run up: as she sayd: then she tooke her mare and rid away. fearing some evil had ben intended agaynst her. and when she came to the house of Henery or [Benjamin Willard.] _willard_benjamin  she told how it was with her and the sayd Henery    Willard. or both went to looke after him and met him comeinge in a strange destracted frame(Reverse) [Lidia Nichols] _nichols_lydia ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 100 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.24( [Samuel Wilkins] _wilkins_samuel  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Deposistion of [Samuell wilknes] _wilkins_samuel  aged about 19 years who testifieth and saith that sence [Jno: willard] _willard_john  has ben in prizson I have been afflected in a strange kind of maner for about the later end of June or begining of July as I was a weaveing the yarn broak exceeding fast: and as. I was a tying a thread I had a stroak on my hand like a knife the blood being almost Redy to com out and I was also pinched several times by an unseen hand: also Riding to marblehead Just as I came to forrist River Bridge I was immediatly seazed with a violent wait on my back and I saw a black hate: and was Immediatly pulled ofe my horse or mare and almost pulled into the Rivere: but: holding fast at last I gott up againe: awhile affter as I was once in the woods and a goeing hom & a little boy with me: I thought I must run: and I said: to the boy let us Run: and as soon as I Ran there was a black hate Run a long by me: a while affter one morning about an hour by sun I was afflected and I saw [John willard] _willard_john  or his Apperance with a darke collored coot and a black hate very like that hate which I formmorly saw: a litle while after this one night as soon as I was abed [John willard] _willard_john  whom I very well knew or his Appearanc came in to the Room where I was a bed: and another man and woman along with him which I did not know and they tould me they would cary me away before morning.Jurat in Curia  (Reverse) [Sam Wilkins] _wilkins_samuel  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 101 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.25( [Thomas Bailey] _bailey_thomas  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The deposition of [Thomas Baly] _bailey_thomas  aged 36 yeares who testefieth and saythThat I being at Groaton. some short tyme after [John Willard.] _willard_john  as the report went had beaten his wife I went to cal him home. and comeinge home with him in the night I heard such a hideous noyse of strang creatures I was much affrighed for I never had heard the like noyse I fearinge they might be some evil spirits I enquired of the sayd [Willard] _willard_john  what might it be that made such a hideous noyse the sayd [Willard] _willard_john  sayd they were Locust: the next days as I suppose the sayd [Williards] _willard_john  #(bringing his wife) wife with a younge childe and her mather being upon my mare. ridinge. betweene Groaton Mil and Chensford. they. being willing to goe on foote a litle desired me to ride: then I taking my mare being willing to let her feed a litle: there as I remember I aprehend I heard the same noyse agayne where at my mare started and got from me.Jurat in Curia.  (Reverse) [Tho. Bayley] _bailey_thomas  ag't [Willard] _willard_john  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 101 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.26( [Elizabeth Bailey] _bailey_elizabeth  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Testimonie of [Elizabth Bayly] _bailey_elizabeth  aged twenty seaven years or there aboutes testifyeth and saith that [John Willard] _willard_john  lookeing his oxen mett w'th this deponant and told her that all the way from [Francis Eliotts] _elliot_frances  hous to his owne home hee #(ver) veryly thought that the Divell #(Devell) Came before him or behind him all the way which dreadfully frighted him the s'd Deponant asked him why he thought so he answered hee could not tell and Emediately fell a singingThe marke of  [Elizabeth Bayly] _bailey_elizabeth X #(Againest Ellieth) Jurat in Curia  (Reverse) [El Bayley] _bailey_elizabeth  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 102 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.27( [Rebecca Wilkins] _wilkins_rebecca  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The testomony of [Rebeckah wilkins] _wilkins_rebecca  aged ninteen years Doe testifie that 29'th July at night shee se [John wilard] _willard_john  seting in the Corner and hee said that hee wold afflick me that night and forthwith hee ded afflick me: and the nax day I ded se him afflick me soer by Choaking & Polling me ear into Peases the nex day being the Lords day I being Going to meting I se [John wilard] _willard_john  and hee afflickted me very soerJurat in Curia  [Rebeckah Wilkins] _wilkins_rebecca  (Reverse) [Rebecka Wilkins] _wilkins_rebecca  vs. [Willard] _willard_john  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 102 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.28( [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  and [Edward Putnam] _putnam_edward  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The deposistion of [Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  agged 40. years and [Edward putnam] _putnam_edward  agged 38 years who testifie and say that we haveing been conversant with severall of the afflected parsons as namly [mary walcott] _walcott_mary  [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Elizabeth Hubbrut] _hubbard_elizabeth  [Abigail williams] _williams_abigail  and [ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  jun'r: and we have seen them most greviously tormented by pinching and pricking and being all most choaked to death most greviously complaining of [John willard] _willard_john  for hurting them: but on the 18'th day of may 1692: being #(be) the day of his examination the afforesaid afflected parsons ware most greviously tormented dureing the time of his examination for if he did but cast his eies upon them they ware strocken down or all most choak: also severall times sence we have seen the afforesaid afflected parsons most greviously tormented as if their bones would have been disjoyned greviously complaining of [John willard] _willard_john  for hurting them: and we veryly beleve that [John willard] _willard_john  the prizsoner at the barr has severall times tormented and afflected the afforesaid parsons with acts of wicthcraft[Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  [Edward putnam.] _putnam_edward  Jurat in Curia.  (Reverse) [Thomas] _putnam_thomas_jr  & [Edward Putnam] _putnam_edward  their Evidence ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 103 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.29( [Henry Wilkins, Sr.] _wilkins_henry_sr  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Deposition of [Henery Wilkins Sen] _wilkins_henry_sr  aged 41 yeares who testifieth and sayth. that upon the third of may last [John Willard] _willard_john  came to my house: and very earnestly entreated me to go with him to Boston w'ch I at lenght consented to go with him, my Son [Daniel] _wilkins_david  comeinge and understanding I was goinge with him to Boston. and seemed to be much troubled that I would go with the sayd [Willard:] _willard_john  and. he sayd he thought it were wel If the sayd [Willard] _willard_john  were hanged: w'ch made me admire for I never heard. such an expression. come from him. to any. one Livinge. beeinge since he came to yeares of discretion but. After. I was gone. in a few days. he was taken. sicke: and. grew every day worse & worse where upon we made aplication to a phisitian who. affirmed. his sicknes. was by some preternatural cause. & would make no application of any phisicke some tymes after this our neighbours comeing to visit my son. [mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  came w'th them and affirmed that she saw the apperition of [John Willard] _willard_john  afflicting him. quickly after came [An Putnam.] _putnam_ann_jr  and she saw the same apperition and then my eldest daughter was taken in a sad manner. & the sayd An: saw the sayd [Willard] _willard_john  aflecting her. at Another tyme [mercy lewes.] _lewis_mercy  and [mary Walcut] _walcott_mary  came to visit him and they. saw. the same apparition of Willard  aflicting him. and this was but a litle tyme before his death.Sworne in Court. (Reverse) [Henry Wilkins] _wilkins_henry_sr  ag't [Willard] _willard_john ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 104 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.30( [Benjamin Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  and [Thomas Flint] _flint_thomas  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Testimony of [benjamin wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  #(and Thom) [lost] aged about .3[lost] and [Thomas Flint] _flint_thomas  aged about: 46: years Testifieth [lost] one the .16. day of may last: 1692: we being at The house [henry wilkins] _wilkins_henry_sr  where we saw his son [danell wilkins] _wilkins_david  [torn] [as] we judged at the point of death & [marcy luis] _lewis_mercy  & [mary [wolcot]] _walcott_mary  being with us Tould us That [john willord] _willard_john  & [goody bucly] _buckley_sarah  [were] upon his Throat & upone his brest and presed him & [choked] him & to aur bes judgment he was  presed and choked [from the] time we saw him almost to death & the said [benjamin wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  continued with him til [torn] was about .3 howrs aftor & he altered not in the mannor [torn] Condisthtion only grew wors & wors till he diedJurat in Curia  by [Ben: Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  (Reverse) [Ben Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  [Tho. Flintt] _flint_thomas  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 105 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.31( [Bray Wilkins] _wilkins_bray  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Deposition of [Bray Wilkins] _wilkins_bray  of Salem Village aged about eighty & one years with reference to [John Willard] _willard_john  of s'd Salem, lately charged with Witchcraft, when he was at first complained of by the afflicted persons for afflicting of them he came to my house greatly troubled, desiring me with some other Neighbours to pray for him: I told him I was then going from home, & could not stay, but if I could come home before night I should not be unwilling, but it was near night before I came home & so I did not answere his desire, but I heard no more of him upon that account. Whither my not answering his desire did not offend him, I cannot tell, but I was jealous afterwards that it did. A little after my wife & I went to Boston at the last Election, when I was as well in health as in many yeares before, & the Election day coming to my brother Lf't [Richard Way's] _way_richard  house, at noon there were many friends to dine there, they were sat down at the Table, [Mr Lawson] _lawson_deodat  & his wife & severall more, [John Willard] _willard_john  came into the house with my sone [Henry Wilkins] _wilkins_henry_sr  before I sat down, & s'd [Willard] _willard_john  to my apprehension lookt after such a sort upon me as I never before discerned in any, I did but step into the next room, & I was presently taken in a strange condition, so that I could not dine, nor eat any thing, I cannot express the misery I was in for my water was sodainly stopt, & I had no benefit of nature, but was like a man on a #(wrack) Rack, & I told my wife immediately that I was afraid that [Willard] _willard_john  had done me wrong, my pain continuing & finding no relief my jealousie continued: [Mr Lawson,] _lawson_deodat  & others there, were all amazed, & knew not what to do for me: There was a Woman accounted  skilfull came hoping to help me, & after she had used means, she askt me whither none of those evil persons had done me damage. I said, I could not say they had, but I was sore afraid they had, she answered she did fear so too, as near as I remember. I lay in this case .3. or. .4. dayes at Boston, & afterwards with the jeopardy of my life (as I thought) I came home, & then some of my friends coming to #(se) see me (& at this time [John Willard] _willard_john  was run away) One of the afflicted persons [Mercy Lewes] _lewis_mercy  came in with them, & they askt whither she saw any thing: She said yes, they are looking for [John Willard] _willard_john  but there he is upon his Grandfathers Belly (& at that time I was in greivius #(parts) pain in the small of my Belly) #(I sent my) I continued so in greivous pain & my water much stopt till s'd [Willard] _willard_john  was in chains, & then as near as I can guess I had considerable ease, but on the other hand in the room of a stoppage, I was vexed with a flowing of water, so that it was hard to keep my self dry. On the .5. July last talking with some friends about [John Willard] _willard_john  some pleading his innocency & my self & some others arguing the contrary, within about 1/4 of an hour after that I had said it was not I, nor my son [Benj'n Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  , but the testimony of the afflicted persons, & the jury concerning the Murder of my Grandson [Dan: Wilkins] _wilkins_david  that would take away his life if any thing did, & within about 1/4 hour after this was taken in the sorest distress & misery my water being turned into real blood, or of a bloody colour & the old pain returned excessively as before which continued for about 24. houres together(Reverse) [Bray Wilkins] _wilkins_bray  Testimony ags't [John Willard] _willard_john ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 106 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.32( [Philip Knight] _knight_philip  and [Thomas Nichols] _nichols_thomas  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The deposition of [Philip knight] _knight_philip  aged 46 yeares and of [Thomas Nicols] _nichols_thomas  22 yeares who do testefy and say That sometymes in April last there was discourse at the house of the sayd [Philip Knight.] _knight_philip  about several of the village that were taken up upon suspition of witchcraft. [John #(Willard) willard] _willard_john  being present then replyed: hang them. they ar all witches(Reverse) [Philip Knight] _knight_philip ( Essex County Archives Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 105 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.33( [Benjamin Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  and [Sarah Buckley] _buckley_sarah  )The Testimony of [benjamin wilkns] _wilkins_benjamin  aged about. 36: years saith That about the 12: of may last marcy lues being at my fathers hous tould us that she saw [john wilard] _willard_john  and goody bucly upon my father [wilkins] _wilkins_henry_sr  presing his belly and my father complained of extreme paine in his bely at the same time: then John putnam  struck at the aperistions then [marcy luis] _lewis_mercy  fel down & my father had ease emediatly:[John putnam] _putnam_john_jr  testifieth to the same above written(Reverse) [Benj. Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  Contra [Willard] _willard_john ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 105 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.34([Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Deposistion of [Mircy Lewes] _lewis_mercy  who testifieth and saith that I have often seen the Apperishtion of [John Willard] _willard_john  amongst the wicthes with in this three weeks: but he did not doe me much hurt tell the 11'th of may 1692 and then he fell upon me most dreadfully and [did] most greviously afflect me allmost redy to kill me urgeing me most vehemently to writ in his book: and so he hath continewed ever sence att times tortoring me most dreadfully beating and pinching me and allmost Ready to choak me threating to kill if I would not writ in his book: also I being caried to wi[lls] hill on the 14'th of may att evening to see the afflected parsons there I saw there the Apperishtion of [John willard] _willard_john  greviously afflecting his grandffather wilknes: and I also saw the apperishtion of [John willard] _willard_john  there greviously afflecting the body of [Daniell wilknes] _wilkins_david  who laid speachles and in a sad condition and [John willard] _willard_john  tould me he would kill [Daniell wilknes] _wilkins_david  with in Two days if he could: also I was at [Henry wilknes] _wilkins_henry_sr  the 16 may a little before night and their I saw the apperishtion of [John willard] _willard_john  a choaking [Daniell wilknes] _wilkins_david  also on the 18'th may being #[ing] the day of his examination I was most greviously tortored  by him dureing the time of his examination for if he did but look upon me he struck me down or almost choaked me to death and severall times sence the Apperishtion of [John willard] _willard_john  has most greviously afflected me by beating pinching and allmost choaking me to death: also dureing the time of his examination I saw the Apperishtion of John willard goe from him and afflect the bodyes of [Mary Wolcott] _walcott_mary  [Abigail williams] _williams_abigail  [Elizabeth Hubburd] _hubbard_elizabeth  and [Ann putnam Jun'r] _putnam_ann_jr (Reverse) [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  ag't [John Willard] _willard_john ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 Page 107 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.35(Evidence of [Benjamin Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  , [John Wilkins] _wilkins_john  , and [Nathaniel Richardson] _richardson_nathaniel  )The deposition of [benjamin Wilkins] _wilkins_benjamin  aged 36 years and [John Wilkins] _wilkins_john  aged 26 years these deponents testifieth and say that [Lidia Wilkins] _wilkins_lydia  wiffe of [John Wilkins] _wilkins_john  was well delivered with child. and was well the next day after but the 2 day after shee was deleivered shee was taken with a violent feaver and flux as we supposed had in a litle time the flux abated but the feaver continued till she died which was about four dayes(Reverse) [Nath. Richison] _richardson_nathaniel  tells of a Nashway man that speakes of a profound sleep that [Willard] _willard_john  was in( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 Page 58 )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.36([Ann Putnam, Jr.] _putnam_ann_jr  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Deposition of [Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  who testifieth and saith that on the 23 of April 1692 att evening I saw the Aperishtion of [John Williard] _willard_john  and I was very sorry to se him so: that one that had helpt to tend me was com to afflect me: and I bid him lett me alone and I would not complaine of him: but on the 24 of Appril being Saboth day he did soe greviously afflect me that he forced me to crie out against him before all them that were with me: and he being tould of it as he  tould me on the 25'th of Apr. he came personally to my fathers house to talk with me and I tould him to his face it was so that he did hurt mee: But he denyed it most dreadfully: but I also tould him that if he would leave ofe and hurt me no more that I would not complain of him: and for 3 or 4 days he did hurt me but very little but then againe he did sett upon me most dreadfully and beat me and pinched and almost choaked me to death; threatening to kill me if I would not writ in his book: for he tould me he had whiped my little sister sarah to death and he would whip me to death if I would not writ in his book but I tould him I would not writ in his book tho he did kill me: affter this I saw the apperishtion of my little sister Sarah who died when she was about six weeks old crieing out for vengance against [John Willard] _willard_john  I also saw the Apperishtion of a woman in in a winding sheat which tould me she was [John Wilknes] _wilkins_john  first wife and that [John Willard] _willard_john  had a hand in her death: also I being caried to Wills hill on the 15th of May att evening. to see the afflected parsons there I saw there the Apperishtion of [John Willard] _willard_john  afflecting of his grandfather Wilknes and [Daniel Wilknes] _wilkins_david  and [Rebecka Willknes:] _wilkins_rebecca  & he also tould me that he would kill [daniel wilknes] _wilkins_david  if he could but he had not power enufe yet to kill him: but he would goe to [Mr Burroughs] _burroughs_george  and git power to kill [daniel wilknes:] _wilkins_david  and also on the 18'th may being the day of his examination I was most greviously Afflected by him dureing the time of his examination for if he did but look upon me he would Immediately strick me down or almost choak me to Death and also att the time of his examination I saw the Apperishtion of [John Willard] _willard_john  goe from him and afflect the bodyes of Mary Walcott [Mircy lewes] _lewis_mercy  Abigail williams and [Elizabeth Hubburd] _hubbard_elizabeth [Ann putnam Jun:] _putnam_ann_jr  one har oath which she had taken did after the Reding of this to har did owne it to be the truth: before use the Jurris of Inqwest this 3 day of June: 1692.Jurat in Curia  ( Boston Public Library -- Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts [1939 acquisition] )

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.37([Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  v. [John Willard] _willard_john  )The Deposishion of [mary walcott] _walcott_mary  agged above 17 years who testifieth & saith that on the 15'th of may 1692 I saw the apperishtion of  [John willard] _willard_john  who did Immediately affect me most greviously and urged me greviously to write in his book and so he hath contineued eversence greviously torturing by times and threating to kill me if I would not write in his book and he also tould me that he had bewitched his grandfather wilknes: and I being caried up to wills hill on the: 16'th of may a litle before night I saw their the Apperishtion of [John #[Wilknes] Willard] _willard_john_wilknes  a choaking [Daniell wilknes] _wilkins_david  also on the 18'th may being the day of his examination I was most greviously tortored by him dureing the time of his examination for if he did but look personally upon me he would Immediately strick me down or allmost choak me to death: also severall times during the time of his examination I saw the Apperishtion of [John #[Wilk] Willard] _willard_john_wilknes  go from him and afflect the bodyes of [mircy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Abigail williams] _williams_abigail  [Elizabeth Hubburd.] _hubbard_elizabeth  and [ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  Junr[Marry Wallcot:] _walcott_mary  upone the Reading of this har testimony to har. did on the oath shi hath takin: owne it to be the truth before us the Juriars for Inquest: this 3'd of June. 92 Jurat in Curia  (On Reverse) [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  ag't John Willard ( Boston Public Library -- Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts  [ 1939 acquisition ])

title: SWP No. 137: John Willard Executed August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 137.38( [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  v. [John Willard] _willard_john_wilknes  )The Testimony of [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  witnesseth & saith that sundry times she hath seen & been almost killed by the Appartion of [John Willard] _willard_john  of Salem Village Husbandman on & before the 18. May. 1692 .[Abegall Williams] _williams_abigail  did deliver this testimony to us the Jurriars for Inqwist this 3'd of June: 1692. and did afarme to the truth of it(On reverse) [Abig. Williams] _williams_abigail  ags't [John Willard] _willard_john ( Boston Public Library -- Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts  [ 1939 acquisition ])

title: SWP No. 138: Abigail Williams
content: SWP No. 138.1( [Joseph Hutchinson] _hutchinson_joseph  v. [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  )The deposition of [Joseph Hutchinson] _hutchinson_joseph  aged 59: year doe testifie as fourth[Abigaill Williams] _williams_abigail  I have heard you spake often of a booke that have bin offred to you. She Said that thare was two Books one wos a short thike book & the other wos a Long booke: I asked her w'h Coler the booke war of: she said the bookes ware as rede as blode I asked her if she had sene the booke opned: shee said that shee had sen it opned many times: I asked her if shee did see any Ritinge in the in the booke: shee said thar wos many lins Riten & at the end of Evary line thar wos a seall: I asked her whoe brought the booke to her: shee towld me that it was the blacke man I asked her whoe the blacke man was: shee towld mee it wos the devell: I asked her if shee wos not afraid to see the devell: Shee said at the first shee was and did goe from him but now shee wos not afraid but Could talke with him as well as shee Could with #(him) mee( Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 139: Sarah Wilson, Sr.
content: SWP No. 139.1( [Rev. Increase Mather's] _mather_increase  Report of the recantations of Mary Osgood, Deliverance Frye, et. al. [Sarah Wilson, Sr.] _wilson_sarah_srGoodwife [Wilson] _wilson_sarah_sr  said, that she was in the dark as to some things in her confession; yet she asserted that, knowingly she never had familiarity with the devill; that knowingly she never consented to the afflicting of any person, &c. However she said that truly she was in the dark as to the matter of her being a witch; and being ask'd how she was in the dark, she replyed that the afflicted persons crying out of her as afflicting them made her fearfull of herself, and that was all that made her say that she was in the dark.(Charles W. Upham, Salem Witchcraft  [Boston, 1867] II, 406.)

title: SWP No. 139: Sarah Wilson, Sr.
content: SWP No. 139.2(Recognizance for [Sarah Wilson, Sr.] _wilson_sarah_sr  and [Sarah Wilson, Jr.] _wilson_sarah_jr  )Memorandum That on the Thirteenth day of January 1692 In the fourth year of the Reigne of our Sovereigne Lord & Lady William & Mary by the Grace of God of England &c: King & Queen defenders of the faith &c: Personally appeared before W'm Stoughton Esq'r cheife Justice of their Maj'ies Province of the Massachusets bay in New England [John Osgood] _osgood_john  of the Town of Andiver in the County of Essex husbandman & Joseph Wilson of the same Towne and acknowledged themselves to be Joyntly and Severally Indebted unto our s'd Sovereigne Lord & Lady and the Surviver of them their Heires & Successors in the sum of One Hundred Pounds to be levied on their or  either of their Lands and Tennements, goods and chattles for the use of our said Sovereigne Lord & Lady the King & Queen or Survivor of them On Condition that [Sarah Wilson] _wilson_sarah_sr  the wife of [Joseph Wilson] _wilson_joseph  and [Sarah] _wilson_sarah_jr  her daughter haveing stood committed for suspitian of Witchcraft shall make their Personall appearance before the Justices of our s'd Lord & Lady the King & Queen at the next Court of Assizes & Generall Goale Delivery to be holden for the County of Essex then and there to answer to all such matters & things as shall in their Maj'ies behalfe be alledged against them and to doe & receive that which by the s'd Court shall be then & there injoyned them & thence not to depart w'th out licenceAttest [*Jona Elatson] _elatson_jonathan  Cler --(Reverse) Recognizance of [Jno Osgood] _osgood_john  & [Joseph Willson] _wilson_joseph  ][Sarah Willson] _wilson_sarah_sr  the wife of [Joseph Willson] _wilson_joseph  and [Sarah] _wilson_sarah_jr  her daughtermay the 10th Appeard( Mass. Archives Vol. 135 No. 145 )

title: SWP No. 014: Sarah Bishop
content: SWP No. 14.1(The [Rev. John Hale] _hale_john  et al. v. [Sarah Bishop] _bishop_sarah  )[May 20, 1692 ][John Hale] _hale_john  of Beverly aged about 56 yeares [torn] & saith that  about 5 or 6 years ago e Christian the wife of [John Trask] _trask_john  (living in  Salem bounds bordering on the abovesaid Beverly) beeing in full  comunion in o'r Church came to me to [de] sier that [Goodwife Bish- op] _bishop_bridget  her Neighb'r wife of [Edw: Bishop Jun'r] _bishop_edward_jr  might not be permitted  to receive the Lords Supper in our church till she had given her the  said Trask satisfaction for some offences that were against her.viz be-  cause the said [Bishop] _bishop_bridget  did entertaine people in her house at unseason-  able houres in the night to keep drinking and playing at shovel-board  whereby discord did arise in other families & young people were in  danger to bee corrupted & that the s'd [Trask] _trask_sarah  knew these things  & had once gon into the house & fynding some at shovel-board had  taken the peices thay played with & thrown them into the fyre  & had reprooved the said [Bishop] _bishop_bridget  for promoting such disorders, But re-  ceived no satisfaction from her about it.I gave s'd [Christian Trask] _trask_sarah  direction how to proceed farther in  this matter if it were clearly prooved And indeed by the information  I have had otherwise I doe fear that if a stop had not been putt to  those disorders s'd [Edw. Bishop's] _bishop_bridget  house would have been a house of  great prophainness & iniquity.But as to [Christian Trask] _trask_sarah  the next news I heard of her was that  she was distracted & asking her [husband Trask] _trask_john  when she was so taken  [he told] mee shee was taken distracted that night after shee [came  from] my house when shee complained against [Goody Bishop] _bishop_bridget  .She continueing some time Distracted wee sought the Lord by  fasting & prayer & the Lord was pleased to restore the s'd [[Trask]] _trask_sarah   to the use of her reason agen. I was s'th her often in [her] distraction  (& took it then to bee only distraction, yet fearing sometimes  somw't worse) but since I have seen the fitts of those bewitched at  Salem Village I call to mind some of hers to be much like some of  theirs.The said [Trask] _trask_sarah  when recovered as I understood it did manifest  strong suspicion that shee had been bewitched by the s'd [Bishop's] _bishop_edward_jr   wife & showed so much aversness from having any conversation that  I was then troubled at it hopeing better of s'd [Goody Bishop] _bishop_bridget  at that  time for wee have since [torn] At length s'd [Christian Trask] _trask_sarah  [was]  agen in a distracted fit on a Sabboth day in the forenoon at the pub-  l[i]ck meeting to o'r public desturbance & so continued sometimes  better sometimes worse unto her death, manifesting that shee under  temptation to kill her selfe or somebody else.I enquired of [Marg'rt Ring] _ring_margaret  who kept at or nigh the house, what  shee had observed of s'd [Trask] _trask_sarah  before this last distraction shee told  [mee.] [Goody Trask] _trask_sarah  was much given to reading & search the pro-  phecys of scrip[ture].The day before shee made that disturbance in the meeting [house  she[e] came home & said shee had been w'th [Goody Bishop] _bishop_bridget  & that  they two were now friend or to that effect.I was oft praying w'th & councelling of [Goody Trask] _trask_sarah  before her  death and not many days before her end being there shee seemed  more rationall & earnestly desired [Edw: Bishop] _bishop_edward_jr  might be sent for  that shee might make friends with him, I asked her if shee had  wronged [Edw. Bishop] _bishop_edward_jr  shee said not that shee knew of unless it were  in taking his shovel-board pieces when people were at play w'th them  & throwing them into the fyre & if she did evill in it she was very  sorry for it & desiered he would be friends with her or forgive her.  this was the very day before she dyed, or a few days before.Her distraction (or bewitching) continued about a month and in  those intervalls wherein shee was better shee earnestly desired prayers  & the Sabboth befere she dyed I received a note for prayers on her  behalf w'ch her husband said was written by her selfe & I judge was  her owne hand writing beeing well acquainted with her hand.As to the wounds she dyed of I observed 3 deadly ones; apeice  of her wind pipe cutt out. & another wound above that threww the   windpipe & Gullet & the veine they call jugular. So that I then judge  & still doe apprehend it impossible for her w'th so short a pair of  cissars to mangle her selfe so without some extraordinary work of  the devill or witchcraftsigned. 20. may 1692  by [*John Hale.] _hale_john  To severall parts of this testimony can wittness [Maj'r Gidney] _gidney_bartholomew  .  [Mr Paris] _parris_samuel  [Joseph Hirrek] _herrick_joseph_jr  Ju'r & his wife [Thomas Raiment] _rayment_thomas  & his wife  [John Traske] _trask_john  [Marget King] _king_margaret  , [Hanah] _baker_hannah  wife of [Cornell Baker] _baker_cornell  , []  Miles & others. As also about the s'd [Goody Bishop] _bishop_edward_jr  Capt [W'm Raiment] _rayment_william_sr  , his son  [W'm Raiment] _rayment_william_jr  about creatures strangely dying. [James Kettle] _kettle_james  , & the  abovs'd [Jos: Hirreck] _herrick_joseph_jr  & [Tho: Raiment] _rayment_thomas  about sundry actions that  [have] the apearance of witchcraft. (Reverse) Deposition 16 [John Hale] _hale_john  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft vol. 1, no. 142.)

title: SWP No. 014: Sarah Bishop
content: SWP No. 14.2([James Kettle] _kettle_james  v. [Sarah Bishop] _bishop_sarah  )[+ May 20, 1692 ]The deposition of [James Kettle] _kettle_james  aged twenty seven years or there  about testyfieth & saith that I was att [Docter Grigs] _grigs_doctor  his hous on the  tenth of this instant may & there saw [Elizebeth Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  in severall  Fitts: and after her fits ware over she told me that she saw my two  Childdren Laying before her & that thay cry'd for vengance & that  [Sarah Bishop] _bishop_sarah  bid her Look on them & said that she kiled them  & and thay were by her description much as they were when they  ware put in to there Coffins [to?] be buried & she told me that [Sarah bishop] _bishop_sarah  told her [th]at I was going to burn akiln of potts & that she  would break them if she Could: & i took notice that while she was in  her Fitts that she Cried & held her apron before her face saying that  she would not se them [Docter Grigs] _grigs_doctor  & his wife and [John hues] _hughes_john  ware  thare present(Reverse) [[Sar]ah Bishop] _bishop_sarah ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft vol. 2, no. 116.)

title: SWP No. 014: Sarah Bishop
content: SWP No. 14.3( [Elizabeth Balch] _balch_elizabeth  & [Abigail Waldon] _waldon_abigail  v. [Sarah Bishop] _bishop_sarah  )[+ May 20, 1692 ]The Depotion of [Elizabeth Balch] _balch_elizabeth  of Beverly Aged aboute Eight  & thirty years & wife unto [Benjamin Balch] _balch_benjamin  ju'r This Deponant Testi-  fieth hereby & saith that she being at Salem on the very Day that  Cap't [Georg Curwin] _corwine_george  was buried & in the evening of s'd Day Cominge  from s'd Salem unto s'd Beverly on horse back with her sister then  known by the name of [Abigaile Woodburie] _woodbury_abigail  now [Abigaile Waldon] _waldon_abigail  Liv-  ing in Wenham wife unto [Nathaniell Waldon] _waldon_nathaniel  Rideing behinde her  & as they were Rideing as befour & were Come soe far as Crane River   Common soe Called [Edward Bishop] _bishop_edward_jr  & his wife over tooke us (on  horse back) who are both now in prison under suspition of witch-  craft & had some words of Difference it seemed unto us. s'd [Bishop] _bishop_edward_jr   rideing in to the brooke pretty hastily she finding fault with his soe  doing & said that he would throw her in to the water or words to  that purpose s'd [Bishop] _bishop_edward_jr  Answered her that it was noe matter if he  Did or words to that Effect: & soe wee Rode along all together to-  ward Beverly & she blamed her husband for Rideing soe fast & that  he would Doe her a mischeife or words to that purpose & he An-  swered her that it was noe matter what was Done unto her or words  to that purpose: And then s'd [Bishop] _bishop_edward_jr  Directed his speech unto us  as we Rode along & s'd that she had ben a bad wife unto him ever  since they were marryed & reckoned up many of her miscarriages to-  wards him but now of Late she was worse then Ever she had ben  unto him before (and that the Devill Did Come bodyly unto her  & that she was familiar with the Devill & that she sate up all the night  Long with the Devill) or words to that purpose & with such kinde of  Discourse he filled up the time untill we Came to s'd [Bishops] but  what was truth & s'd [Bishops] _bishop_edward_jr  wife made very Little reply to all her  husbands Discourse Dureing all the time we wer with them & farther  said notthe mark of  [elezebeth title: SWP No. 015: Mary Black
content: SWP No. 15.1(Examination of [Mary Black] _black_mary  and Clearance by Proclamation)[April 22, 1692 ]The examination of [Mary Black] _black_mary  (a Negroe) at a Court held at Salem  Village 22. 1692  By the Magistrates of SalemMary, you are accused of sundry acts of witchcraft: Tell me be  you a Witch?-- Silent. How long have you been a witch? I cannot tell. But have you been a witch? I cannot tell you. Why do you hurt these folks I hurt no body Who doth? I do not know. [Benj'a Putnam] Her Master saith a man sat down upon the farm with her about a  twelve month agoe.What did the man say to you? He said nothing. Doth this Negroe hurt you? Severall of them said yes. Why do you hurt them? I did not hurt them. Do you prick sticks? No I pin my Neck cloth Well take out a pin, & pin it again. She did so, & severall of the afflicted cryed out they were prick't.  [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  was prick't in the arm till the blood came, [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  was prick't in the stomach & [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  was prick't in  the foot.[mr Samuell parris] _parris_samuel  being desired to take in wrighting the Examination  of [Mary Black] _black_mary  a Negro Woman delivered itt as aforesaid And upon  heareing the same and seeing what wee did then see togather with the  Charge of the afflicted persons then present Wee Committed s'd  [Mary black] _black_mary  .[Pbar ] us [John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john   [Jonathan. title: SWP No. 016: Mary Bradbury
content: SWP No. 16.3(Answer of [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  )[+September 9, 1692]The Answer of [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  in the charge of Witchcraft or  familliarity with the Divell I doe plead not guilty.I am wholly inocent of any such wickedness through the goodness  of god that have kept mee hitherto) I am the servant of Jesus Christ  & Have given my self up to him as my only lord & saviour: and to   the dilligent attendance upon him in all his holy ordinances, in  utter contempt & defiance of the divell, and all his works as horid  & detestible; and accordingly have endevo'red to frame my life;  & conversation according to the rules of his holy word, & in that faith  & practise resolve by the help and assistance of god to contineu to  my lifes end:for the truth of what I say as to matter of practiss I humbly  refer my self, #[my selfe,] to my brethren & neighbors that know  mee and unto the searcher of all hearts for the truth & upright-  ness of my heart therein: (human frailties, & unavoydable infirmi-  ties excepted) of which i bitterly complayne every day:/[Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft vol. 2, no. 72, Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, Judicial Archives, on deposit James Duncan Phillips Library, Salem, MA. )

title: SWP No. 016: Mary Bradbury
content: SWP No. 16.5( Testimony of [Thomas Bradbury] _bradbury_thomas  for [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  )[July 28, 1692]July the 28: 1692 Concerning my beloved wife [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  this is that I have to  say: wee have been maried fifty five yeare: and shee hath bin a   loveing & faithfull wife to mee, unto this day shee hath been wonder-  full laborious dilligent & Industryous in her place and imployment,  about the bringing up o'r family (w'ch have bin eleven children of  o'r owne, & fower grand-children: shee was both prudent, & provi-  dent: of a cheerful Spiritt liberall Charitable: Shee being now very  aged & weake, & greived under her affliction may not bee able to  speake much for herselfe, not being so free of Speach as some others  may bee: I hope her life and conversation hath been such amongst  her neighbours, as gives a better & more reall Testimoney of her,  then can bee exprest by words.own'd by mee   [*Tho: Bradbury] _bradbury_thomas  . (Reverse) [Capt Bradberys] _bradbury_thomas  testamony of his [wif] _bradbury_mary  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft, Vol. 2 p. 36 )

content: SWP No. 16.8( Testimony of [James Allen] _allen_james  , [Robert Pike] _pike_robert  , and [John Pike] _pike_john  for [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  )[September 7, 1692]Being desired to give my testimony concerning the life & conver-  sation of [mrs Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  of Salisbury amonst us: w'ch is as followeth.  viz. I having lived nine years at Salisbury in the work of the min-  istry -- & now four years in the office a Pastour; to my best notice  & observation of [mrs Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  she hath lived according to the rules  of the gospell, amongst us. was a constant attender upon the ministry  of the word; & all the ordinances of the gospell; full of works of char-  ity & mercy to the sick & poor. neither have I seen or heard any  thing of her unbecoming the profession of the gospell: --[James Allin.] _allen_james  [mr James Allin] _allen_james  made oathe to the truth of w't is above written  Septem'r the 7'th: 1692: before me [Rob't Pike] _pike_robert  Asst I do also aferm to the truth of w't is above testifyed upon up-  ward of fifty years experience and shall so testify if opertunity do  present w'ch I shall indever [Robt: Pike] _pike_robert  Having lived many years in Salbury & been much Conversant  there, according to my best notice & observation of [Mrs Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  .  must needs affirm to what is above written & add my oath to it if  Called thereto [John Pike] _pike_john  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 p. 75 )

title: SWP No. 016: Mary Bradbury
content: SWP No. 16.10( Deposition of [Samuel Endicott] _endicott_samuel  v. [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  )[September 9, 1692 ][Sam'll Endecott] _endicott_samuel  aged thirty one years or thereabout Testifies  Thatt about eleven years since being bound upon a vioage to sea  w'th [Capt Sam'll Smith] _smith_samuel  Late of Boston Diceas'd, just before we  sayl'd [mrs Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  of Salisbury the prisoner now att the barr came  to Boston w'th some firkins of butter of w'ch [Capt Smith] _smith_samuel  bought  two, one of them proved halfe way butter and after wee had been att  sea three weekes our men. were nott able to eat itt, itt stanck soe  and runn w'th magotts, w'ch made the men very much disturb'd  about itt and would often say thatt they heard [mrs Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  was a  witch and thatt they verily beleived she was soe or else she would  nott have served the Capt soe as to sell him such butter. And further  this deponent Testifieth that in four dayes after they sett sayle they  mett w'th such a violent storm that we lost our main mast and rig-  gin & Lost fifeteen horses and thatt about a fortnight after we sett  our jury mast and thatt very night there came up a Shipp by our side  and Carried away two of the mizon shrouds and one of the Leaches  of the mainsaile: and this deponent further sayth thatt after they  arived att Barbados and went to Saltitudos & had Laden their vessell  the next morning she sprang a leake in the hold w'ch wasted sevrall  tunns of salt in soe much thatt we were forct to unlade our ves-  sell again wholy to stopp our leake there was then four foot of  water in the hold after we had taken in our lading again we had a  good passage home butt when we came near the Land the Capt  sent this deponent forward to looke out for land in a bright moone  shining night and as he was [Reverse] sitting upon the windless he heard a  Rumbling noise under him w'th thatt he the s'd deponent Testi-  fieth Thatt he looked one the side of the windless and saw the leggs  of some [pbar ]son being no wayes frighted & Thatt presently he was   shook and looked over his shoulder, & saw the appearance of a wom-  an from her middle upwards, haveing a white Capp and white neck-cloth on her, w'ch then affrighted him very much, and as he was  turning of the windless he saw the aforsaid two leggs.Jurat in Curia  Sep'r 9'th 1692  (Reverse) [Sam. Endecott] _endicott_samuel  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft Salem - Witchcraft, vol. 2, no. 76.)

[Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  )[+ September 9, 1692]The deposistion of [Richard: Carr] _carr_richard  who testifieth and saith.  that about 13 years ago presently after sume Diferance that hap-    pened  to be between my Hon'rd father [mr George Carr:] _carr_george  and [Mis Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  the prisoner at the barr upon a Sabboth at noon as we  ware riding hom by the house of [Capt Tho: Bradbery] _bradbury_thomas  I saw [mis Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  goe into hir gate turne the corner of and Immediately there  derted out of hir gate a blue boar and darted at my fathers horses  ledgs which made him stumble but I saw it no more and my father  said boys what doe you se: we both answed a blue bore:[Zorobabell Endicott] _endicott_zerubable  testifieth and saith that I lived att [mr George Carr:] _carr_george  now deceased att the time above mentioned and was  present with [mr George Carr] _carr_george  and [mr Richard Carr] _carr_richard  and I also saw a  blue bore dart out of mr Brdbery gate to [Mr Gorge Carrs] _carr_george  horses  ledges which mad him stumble affter a strange manr and I also saw  the blue bore dart from [mr carrs] _carr_george  horses ledgs in att [mis Bradberys] _bradbury_mary   window: and [mr carr] _carr_george  immediately said boys what did you see and we  both said a blue bore then said he from whence came it and we said  out of [mr Bradberys] _bradbury_thomas  gate. then said he I am glad you see itt as well  [a]s wel[l] as I. Jurat in Curia Sep'r 9'th 92& they both further say on their Oathes that [mr Carr] _carr_george  discoursed w'th  them as they went home about what had happened and they all con-  cluded that it was [mrs Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  that so app'rd as a blue boar.(Reverse) [Richard Carr] _carr_richard  [Zorobable Endecott] _endicott_zerubable (Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft Salem, vol. 2, no. 80.)

title: SWP No. 016: Mary Bradbury
content: SWP No. 16.13( Deposition of [James Carr] _carr_james  v. [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary )[September 9, 1692]The Deposistion of [James carr.] _carr_james  who testifieth and saith that about  20 years agoe one day as I was accidently att the house of [mr whele- right] _wheelwright_mr  and his daughter the [widdow maverick] _maverick_widdow  then lived there: and she  then did most curtuously invite me to com oftener to the house and  wondered I was grown such a stranger and with in a few days affter  one evening I went thether againe: and when I came thether againe:  [william Bradbery] _bradbury_william  was there who was then a suter to the said widdow but I did not know it tell affterwards; after I came in the  widdow did so corsely treat the s'd [william Bradbery] _bradbury_william  that he went  away semeing to be angury: presently after this I was taken affter  a strange maner as if #[every] liveing creature did run about every  part of my body redy to tare me to peaces and so I continued for   about 3 quarters of a year by times & I applyed myself to doctor  crosbe who gave me a grate deal of visek but could make non work  tho he steept tobacco in [bofit] drink he could make non to work  where upon he tould me that he beleved I was behaged: and I tould  him I had thought so a good while: and he asked me by hom I tould  him I did not care for spaking for one was counted an honest wom-  an. but he uging I tould him and he said he did beleve that [mis Brad- bery] _bradbury_mary  was a grat deall worse then goody mertin: then presently affter  this one night I being a bed and brod awake there came sumthing to  me which I thought was a catt and went to strick it ofe the bed and  was [seud] fast that I could not stir hedd nor foot but by and by  coming to my strength I hard sumting a coming to me againe and I  prepared myself to strick it: and it coming upon the bed I did strick  at it and I beleve I hit it: and affter that visek would work on me and  I beleve in my hart that [mis Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  the prison'r att the bar has  often afflected me by acts of wicthcraftJurat in Curia  Septm 9: 92.  (Reverse) [James Carr] _carr_james  Dep[obar ]ition ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft, vol. 2, no. 79.)

content: SWP No. 16.15(Testimony of [William Carr] _carr_william  for [Mary Bradbury] _bradbury_mary )[September 9, 1692 ]The testamony of [william Carr] _carr_william  Aged 41 or ther abouts is That  my brother [John Carr] _carr_john  when he was yong was a man of as good capa-  sity as most men of his age but faling in Love with [Jane Tru] _true_jane  (now wif  of [Capt John march] _march_john  ) and my father being pswaded by [some] of the  family (w'ch I shall not name) not to Let him mary so yong: my  father woold not give him a porsion w'r'upon the mach broke of  w'ch my brother layd so much to hart that he grew melencoly & by  degrees much crazed not being the man that he was before to his  dying dayI do farther testify that my s'd brother was sick about a fort-  night or three weeks & then dyed & I was present with him w'n he  dyed & I do aferm that he dyed peacibly and quietly never manifest-  ing the Lest troubl in the world about any body nor did not say any  thing [mrs Bradbury] _bradbury_mary  n(o)r any body else doing him hurt & yet I was  with him till the breath & Lif was out of his bodyJurat in Curia  (Reverse) [william Cars] _carr_william  testamony ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft, vol. 2, no. 82.)
