title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.15( Deposition of [Simon Willard] _willard_simon  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[August 3, 1692]The Deposition of [Simon Willard] _willard_simon  [aged about 42] years saith I  being at Saco in the year [1689] some: in Capt [Ed Sarjants] _seargents_ed  garison  was speaking of [mr George Borroughs] _burroughs_george  his great strength saying he  Could take:a barrill of mallasses out of a Cannoe or boat alone: and  that he Could. take it in his hands or arms out of the Cannoo or boat  and carry it and set it on the shore: and [mr Borroughs] _burroughs_george  being: there  sayd that he had carryed one barrill of molasses.or sider: out of a  cannoo that had like to have done him a displeasure: s'd [mr Bor- roughs] _burroughs_george  intimated: as if he did not want strength to do it but the dis-  advantage of the shore was such: that his foot slipping in the sand:  he had like to have strained his legg[*Simon Willard] _willard_simon  [Simon Willard] _willard_simon  ownd: to the Jury  of Inquest, that the above written  evidence is the truth Jurat in Curia  (Reverse) [Simon Willard] _willard_simon  ag'st [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft, vol. 2, no. 28.)

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.16( Testimony [Mary Webber] _webber_mary  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[August 2, 1692][Mary Webber] _webber_mary  wid aged aboute 53 years Testifieth and sayth that  she liveing at Casco Bay aboute six or seaven years agoe, when  [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  was Minester at s'd place, and liveing anner --  Neighbour to s'd [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  , was well acquainted with his wife  w'ch was dauter to [mr John Ruck] _ruck_john  of Salem she hath heard her tell  much of her husband unkindness to her and that she dare not wright  to her father to acquaint [him] how it was with her, and soe desired  mee to wright to her father that he would be pleased to send for  her and told mee she had beene much affrighted, and that something  in the night made anoise in the chamber where she lay as if one Went  aboute the Chamber, and she calling up the negro. to come to her  the negro not Comeing sayd that she could not Come some thing  stopt her, then her husband being called he came up. some thing   Jumped down from between the Chimney & the side of the house  and Run down the stairs and s'd [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  followed it down, and  the negro then s'd it was something like a white calfe: another tyme  lyeing with her husband some thing came into the house and stood  by her bed side and breathed on her, and she being much affrighted  at it, would have awakened her husband but could not for a con-  siderable tyme, but as soone as he did awake it went away., but this  I heard her say. and know nothing of it myselfe otherwise Except by  common report of others also concerning such thingsSalem  August 2'd 1692   [*mary webber] _webber_mary  (Reverse) Mary Webber ve. Burro ( Witchcraft Papers, no. 9, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA..)

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.17( [Hannah Harris] _harris_hannah  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[+ August 5, 1692]The depotion of [Hannah Harres] _harris_hannah  Aiged twenty seven yeares or  thareabouts Testifieth and saith that she Lived at the hous of [Georg Burros] _burroughs_george  at falmouth & the above said [hannah harres] _harris_hannah  many times  hath taken notic that when she hath had anny Discorse with the  above said [burross] _burroughs_george  wife-when the above said [burros] _burroughs_george  was from hom  that apone has Returne he hath often scolded wife and told her  that he knew what they said when he was abroad and further saith  that upone a time when his wife had Laine In Not above one weak  that he fell out with his wife and kept her by Discorce at the Dore  till she fell sicke In the place and grew wors at night so that the  above said [hannah harres] _harris_hannah  was afraid she would dye and thay called  In thare Naibours and the above said [burroses] _burroughs_george  Daughter told One  of the women that was thare the cause of her mothers Ellness and  the a bove said [burros] _burroughs_george  chid his Daughter for telling and the a bove  said [burros] _burroughs_george  Came to the a bove said [hannah harres] _harris_hannah  and told her If  that his wif Did otherwise than well she should not tell of It  & the abovsaid [hannah harres] _harris_hannah  told him that she would not be con-  fined to anny such thingJurat in Curia   [Hannah Harris] _harris_hannah  ag't [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  (On reverse side of paper)  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2, no. 32 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.18([Ann Putnam, Jr.] _putnam_ann_jr  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[August 3, 1692]The Deposition of [Ann putnam:] _putnam_ann_jr  who testifieth and saith that on  20'th of April 1692 :at evening she saw the Apperishtion of a Minister  at which she was greviously affrighted and cried out oh dreadfull:  dreadfull here is a minister com:what are Ministers wicthes to: whence  com you and What is your name for I will complaine of:you tho you  be A minister: if you be a wizzard; and Immediatly I was tortored  by him being Racked and all most choaked by him: and he tempted  me to write in his book which I Refused with loud out cries and said  I would not writ in his book tho he tore me al to peaces but tould  him that it was a dreadfull thing: that he which was a Minister that  should teach children to feare God should com to perswad poor  creatures to give their souls to the divill: oh. dreadfull tell me your  name that I may know who you are: then againe he tortored me  & urged me to writ in his book: which I Refused: and then presently  he tould me that his name was [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  and that he had  had three wives: and that he had bewitched the Two first of them to  death: and that he kiled [Mist. Lawson] _lawson_mistress  because she was so unwilling  to goe from the village and also killed [Mr Lawsons] _lawson_deodat  child because he  went to the eastward with Sir Edmon and preached soe; to the  souldiers and that he had bewicthed a grate many souldiers to death  at the eastword, when Sir Edmon was their. and that he had made  [Abigail Hobbs] _hobbs_abigail  a wicth and: severall wicthes more: and he has con-  tinewed ever sence; by times tempting me to write in his book and  greviously tortoring me by beating pinching and almost choaking me  severall times a day and he also tould me that he was above wicth  for he was a cunjurerJurat in Curia  wee whose names are under writen being present with [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  att the time above mentioned hard hir declare what is above   writen what she said she saw and hard from the Apperishtion of  [Mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  : and allso beheld hir tortors:and perceived  her hellish temtations by hir loud out cries I will not I will not writ  tho you torment al days of my life:and being conversant with hir  ever sence have seen hir tortored and complaining that [Mr. Burroughs] _burroughs_george   hirt hir.and tempts hir to writ in his Book  [Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr   [peter prescott] _prescott_peter   [Robert Morrell] _morrill_robert  Ann Puttnam declared har above written evidence to be the  truth:before the Jury of Inquest: Aug'st 3: 92: upon her oath [Ezekiel Chever] _cheever_ezekiel  made Oath to the latter part.of this paper Jurat in Curia  (Reverse) Ann putnam ag'st Burroughs ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2, no. 24 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.20(Letter of [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  to [John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  &  [Jonathan Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  )[April 21, 1692 ] Salem Village , this 21'st of April, 1692   Much honored: After most humble and hearty thanks presented to your Honors  for the great care and pains you have already taken for us, for which  we are never able to make you recompense (and we believe you do  not expect it of us; therefore a full reward will be given you of the  Lord God of Israel, whose cause and interest you have espoused,  and we trust this shall add to your crown of glory in the day of the  Lord Jesus); and we, beholding continually the tremendous works of  divine providence -- not only every day but every hour -- thought  it our duty to inform your Honors of what we conceive you have  not heard, which are high and dreadful: of a wheel within a wheel,  at which our ears do tingle.Humbly craving continually your prayers and help in this dis-  tressed case, so praying almighty God continually to prepare you,   that you may be a terror to evil-doers and a praise to them that do  well, we remain yours to serve in what we are able.[Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  ( Charles W. Upham, Salem Witchcraft  [ Boston, 1867 ] II, 139-140 .)

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.21(Deposition of [Ann Putnam, Jr.] _putnam_ann_jr  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[August 3, 1692]The deposistion of [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  who testifieth and saith that on  the 5'th of may 1692 at evening I saw the apperishtion of [Mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  who greviously tortored me and urged me to writ in his  book which I refused then he tould me that his Two first wives  would appeare to me presently and tell me a grat many lyes but I  should not beleve them:then immediatly appeared to me the forme  of Two women in winding sheats and napkins about their heads: att  which I was gratly affrighted: and they turned their faces towards  [Mr. Burroughs] _burroughs_george  and looked very red and angury and tould him that he  had been a cruell man to them.and that their blood did crie for ven-  gance against him: and also tould him that they should be cloathed  with white Robes in heaven, when he should be cast into hell: and  immediatly he vanished away: and as soon as he was gon the Two  women turned their faces towards me and looked as pail as a white  wall: and tould me that they ware [mr Burroughs] _burroughs_george  Two first wives  and that he had murthered them: and one tould me that she was his  first wife and he stabed hir under the left Arme and put a peace of  sealing wax on the wound and she pulled aside the winding sheat  and shewed me the place and also tould me that she was in the house  Mr parish now lives w'n it was don, and the other tould me that [Mr Burrough] _burroughs_george  and that wife which he hath now kiled hir in the vessell  as she was coming to se hir friends because they would have one  another: and they both charged me that I should tell these things  to the Magestraits before [Mr Burroughs] _burroughs_george  face and if he did not own  them they did not know but that they should appere their: thes  morning also [Mis Lawson] _lawson_mistress  and hir daughter [Ann] _lawson_ann  appeared to me  whom I knew: and tould me that [Mr Burroughs] _burroughs_george  murthered them:  this morning also appeared to me another woman in a winding sheat   and tould me that she was goodman fullers first wife and [Mr Bur- roughs] _burroughs_george  kiled hir because there was sum differance between hir hus-  band and him: also on the 9'th may dureing the time of his ex-  amination he did most greviously torment and afflect [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary   [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Eliz Hubburd] _hubbard_elizabeth  and [Abigail williams] _williams_abigail  by pinching prick'g  and choaking them Jurat in Curia(Reverse) [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  Cont [Geo Burroughs] _burroughs_george  Death of his wife  & Lawson's Childewe whose names are under written being present with ann put-  nam at the times above mentioned: saw hir tortured and hard hir  refuse to writ in the book also hard hir declare what is above writen:  what she said she saw and hard from the Apperishtion of [Mr. George Burroghs] _burroughs_george  and from thos which acc[used him] for murthering of  them[Edward putnam] _putnam_edward   #[[Robert Morrell] _morrill_robert ] [Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  ownid this har testimomy to be the truth uppon har  oath.before the Juriars of Inquest this: 3. dy of agust 92 ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 Page 12 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.23([Sarah Bibber] _bibber_sara  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[August 3, 1692]The deposistion of [Sarah viber] _bibber_sara  who testifieth and saith that on  the 9'th day of may 1692 . as I was agoeing to Salem village I saw  the apperishtion of a little man like a minister with a black coat  on and he pinched me by the arme and bid me goe along with  him but I tould him I would not but when I cam to the village I   saw theire [Mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  which I never saw before and then  I knew that it was his apperishtion which I had seen in the morning  and he tortured me several times while he was in examination also  dureing the time of his examination I saw [Mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  or  his Apparanec most greviously torment and afflect [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary   [mercy Luis] _lewis_mercy  [Elizabeth Hubbert] _hubbard_elizabeth  [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  and [abigaill williams] _williams_abigail  by  pinching twisting & almost choaking them to death also severall  times sence [mr george Burroughs] _burroughs_george  or his Apperance has most grevious-  ly tormented me with variety of tortors and I beleve in my heart  that [mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  is a dreadfull wizzard and that he has most  greviously tormented me and the above mentioned parson by his  acts of wicthcraft[Sarah Viber] _bibber_sara  declared to the Jury of inquest:that the above  written evidence is the truth:Aug'st 3: 1692 the which she owned  on her oathJurat in Curia   [Sarah Viber] _bibber_sara  ag't [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  (Reverse)  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 no. 27 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.24(Deposition of [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  & Statement of [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  and [Edward Putnam] _putnam_edward  ) v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george[August 3, 1692]the deposistion of [Mircy Lewes] _lewis_mercy  who testifieth and saith that one  the 7'th of may 1692 att evening I saw the apperishtion of [Mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  whom i very well knew which did greviously  tortor me and urged me to writ in his Book and then he brought to  me a new fashon book which he did not use to bring and tould me  I might writ in that book: for that was a book that was in his studdy  when I lived with them: but I tould him I did not beleve him for  I had been often in his studdy but I never saw that book their: but  he tould me that he had severall books in his studdy which I never  saw in his studdy and he could raise the divell: and now had be-  wicthed [Mr. Sheppards] _shepherd_mr  daughter and I asked him how he could goe  to be wicth hir now he was keept at Salem: and he tould me that  the divell was his sarvant and he sent him in his shapp to doe it then  he againe tortored me most dreadfully and threatened to kill me for   he said I should not witnes against him also he tould me that he had  made [Abigaill Hoobs:] _hobbs_abigail  a wicth and severall more then againe he did  most dreadfully tortor me as if he would have racked me all to  peaces and urged me to writ in his book or elce he would kill me but  I tould him I hoped my life was not in the power of his hand and  that I would not writ tho he did kill me: the next night he tould me  I should not see his Two wifes if he could help it because I should  not witnes agast him this 9'th may [mr Burroughs] _burroughs_george  caried me up to  an exceeding high mountain and shewed me all the kingdoms of the  earth and tould me that he would give them all to me if I would  writ in his book and if I would not he would thro me down and  brake my neck: but I tould him they ware non of his to give and I  would not writ if he throde me down on 100 pichforks: also on  the 9'th may being the time of his examination [mr. George Bur- roughs] _burroughs_george  did most dreadfully torment me: and also several times sence[marce luis] _lewis_mercy  uppon har oath did owne this har testimony to be the  truth be fore the Juriors for In quest:agust:3: 92.we whose names are under writen being present hard [mircy lewes] _lewis_mercy   declare what is above writen what she said she saw and hard from the  Apperishtion of [Mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  and also beheld hir tortors  which we cannot express for sume times we ware redy to fear that  every joynt of hir body was redy to be displaced: also we perceived  hir hellish temtations by hir loud out cries [mr.Burroughs] _burroughs_george  . I will  not writ in your book tho you doe kil me[Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr   [[Edward] Putnam] _putnam_edward   Jurat in Curia  (Reverse) [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  ag'st [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2, no. 25 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.25(Testimony of [Elizabeth Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[May 9, 1692 ]May the 9. 1692 .[Elizabeth hubord] _hubbard_elizabeth  aged about 17 yers saith that the last second day at  night: There apeared a little black beard man to me in blackish  aparill I asked him his name. & he told me his name was borrous,  Then he tooke a booke out of his pocket: & opened it.& bid me set  my hand to it I tould him I would not: the lines in this book was  read as blod; then he pinched me twise & went away: The next morn-  ing.he apeared to me againe.and tould me he was above a wizard; for  he was a conjurar and so went away but sins that he hath apeared  to me every day & night very often and urged me very much to set  my hand to his book: and to run a way telling me if I would do so  I should be well & that I should need feare no body: & withall tor-  mented me severall ways every time he Came exept that time he told  me he was a conjuror: This night he asked me very much to set my  hand to his book or else he sayed he would kill me; withall tortor-  ing me very much by biting and pinching squesing my body and  runing pins into me also on the: 9'th may 1692 being the time of  his examination [mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  or his Apperance did most  greviously afflect and torment the bodyes of [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  and [Abigail williams] _williams_abigail  for if he did but look upon  them he would strick them down or almost choak them to death also  severall times sence he has most dreadfully afflected and tormented  me with variety of torments and I beleve in my heart that [mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  is a dreadfull wizzard and that he has often tormented  me and also the above named parsons by his acts of wicthcraftJurat in Curia  [Eliz Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth .declared:the above written evedence:to be the  truth: upon her oath:that she had taken.this she owned before the  Jury of inquest: Aug'st 3 1692  (Reverse) [Eliz: Hubbert] _hubbard_elizabeth  ag't [burroughs] _burroughs_george  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2, no. 30 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.26([Susannah Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[+ May 9, 1692 ]The Complaint of [Susannah Shelden] _sheldon_susannah  against [mr burroos] _burroughs_george  which  brought a book to-mee and told mee if i would not set my hand too  if hee would tear mee to peesses i told him i would not then hee  told mee hee would starve me to death then the next morning he  told mee hee could not starve mee. to death, but hee would choake  me that my vittals should doe me but litl good then he told mee  his name was borros which had preached at the vliage the last night  hee Came to mee and asked mee whether i would goe to the village  to morrow to witnes against him i asked him if hee was exsamened  then hee told hee was then i told him i would goe then hee told mee  hee would kil mee beefoar morning then hee apeared to mee at  the hous of [nathanniel ingolson] _ingersoll_nathaniel  and told mee hee had been the  death of three children at the eastward and had kiled two of his  wifes the first hee smouthered and the second he choaked and killed  tow of his own children(Reverse) [Susannah Shelden] _sheldon_susannah  against [G. Burroughs] _burroughs_george ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2, no. 34 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.27( Testimony of [Benjamin Hutchinson] _hutchinson_benjamin  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[++ April 22, 1692 ][Benjemin huchension] _hutchinson_benjamin  s'd that one the 21'st aprell 92 abegeral  wiluams s'd that there.was a lettell black menester that Lived at  Casko bay he told me so and s'd that he had kild 3 wifes two for  himself and one for [mr Losen] _lawson_deodat  and that he had made nine Weches in  this plase and s'd that he Could hold out the hevest gun that Is  in Casko bay w'th one hand w'c no man Can Case hold out w't  both. hands this Is about a ll a clock and I ask her Where about this  lettel man stood s'd she Just where the Cart wheell went along I  had a 3 graned irne fork in my hnad and I thru it wher she said  he stud and she presently feell in a letel feet and when it twas over  Said She you have toren his coot for I hard it tare wher abouts  said I one won side said shethen we come into the house of left [Ingersoll] _ingersoll_nathaniel  and I went into the  great Roome and abigle come in and said ther he stands I said wher   wher and presently draed my rapyer but he emmedetly was gon as  she said then said she ther is a gray catt then i said wher abouts  doth she stand ther s'd she ther than I struck # [with] with my  rapyer then she fell in afitt and when it was over she said you kild  hur and immedetly [Sary good] _good_sarah  come and carrid hur away this was  about 12 a clock The same day after lecttor in the said: [Ingersolls] _ingersoll_nathaniel   chamber [abigaill williams] _williams_abigail  [mary walcot] _walcott_mary  said that [goody hobs] _hobbs_abigail  of  topfell bitt [mary walcot] _walcott_mary  by the foot then both falling into a fit  as soone as it was over the said [william hobs] _hobbs_william  and his wife goe both of  them a long the table; the said [hucheson] _hutchinson_benjamin  tooke his rapier stabed  [goody hobs] _hobbs_abigail  one the side as [abigaill williams] _williams_abigail  & [mary walcot] _walcott_mary  saide:  the said [abigaill] _williams_abigail  & [mar] _walcott_mary  said the roome was full of them then the  said [hucheson] _hutchinson_benjamin  & [Ely putnam] _putnam_ely  stabed with their raperres at a ventor  then said [mary] _walcott_mary  & [abigell] _williams_abigail  you have killed a greet black woman of Ston-  intown. and an Indian that comes with her for the flore is all covered  with blod.then the said [mary] _walcott_mary  and [abigaill] _waldon_abigail  looked out of dores & said  they saw a greet company of them one a hill & there was three of  them lay dead the black woman & the indian & one more that they  knew notThis being about.4.a clock in the after noon (On reverse side of paper) [Ben Huchison] _hutchinson_benjamin ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft Vol. 2, Page 16 )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.28( Deposition of [Abigail Hobbs] _hobbs_abigail , Deliverance Hobbs & [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  Sarah Good, Sarah Osburn, Bridget Bishop, Giles Cory, Rebecca Nurse, Elizabeth Procter, Alice Parker, Ann Pudeator, Abigail Soames, John Procter,& Lydia Dustin)[June 1, 1692 ]1st June 1692 [Abigaile Hobbs] _hobbs_abigail  then confessed before [John Hathorn] _hawthorne_john  & [Jonathan cor- win] _corwil_jonathan  Esq'rs That at the generall meeting of the Witches in the feild  near [Mr Parrisse's] _parris_samuel  house she saw [Mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  , [Sarah Good] _good_sarah   [Sarah Osborne] _osbourne_sarah  [Bridgett Bishop] _bishop_bridget  a[lbar ]s. [Olliver] _bishop_bridget  & [Giles Cory] _corey_giles  , two or  three nights agone, [Mr Burrough] _burroughs_george  came & sat at the window & told  her he would terribly afflict her for saying so much ag't him & then  pinched her, [deliverance Hobbs] _hobbs_deliverance  then saw s'd [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  & he would  have tempted her to sett her hand to the book & almost shooke  her to pieces because she would not doe it,[Mary Warren] _warren_mary  Testifyeth that when she was in prison in Salem about a  fortnight agone [Mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  , [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  [Goody procter] _proctor_elizabeth  ,   Goody parker, [Goody pudeator] _pudeator_ann  , [Abigail Soames] _somes_abigail  , [Goodman procter] _proctor_elizabeth  ,  [Goody Darling] _downing_mehitabel  [Dowing?] & others unknowne came to this depon't  & [Mr Burroughs] _burroughs_george  had a trumpett & sounded it, & they would have  had this depon't to have gone up with them to a feast at [Mr parris- ses] _parris_samuel  & [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  & [Goody procter] _proctor_elizabeth  told her this depon't they were  Deacons & would have had her eat some of their sweet bread & wine  & she asking them what wine that was one of them said it was blood  & better then our wine but this depon't refused to eat or drink with  them & they then dreadfully afflicted her at that tyme.Sworne the first of June 1692   [John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john   [Jonathan Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  {  Assis'ts M'd. that at the time of the taking of this deposicon [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca   appeared in the roome & afflicted the Depon't Mary & [Deliverance Hobbs] _hobbs_deliverance  as they attested & alsoe almost Choaked [abigaile Hobbs] _hobbs_abigail  as  alsoe testified, & [Mr English] _english_phillip  then run a pin into Maryes hand as she  attested ( Witchcraft Papers, no. 6, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA., Boston. )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.29([Mary Warren] _warren_mary  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  , [John Alden] _alden_john  ,  [Elizabeth Cary] _cary_elizabeth  , and [Ann Pudeator] _pudeator_ann  )[August 3, 1692]The Testimone of [Mary Warren] _warren_mary  aged twenty yeares or thereaboutes  Testifeyeth and saith that Sometime in July last [mr Burrougs] _burroughs_george  pinched  mee very much and choaked me almost to death: and I saw and  hard him sound a Trumpett and Immediatly I saw severall com to  him as namely Capt Allding [Mis Cary] _corey_martha  and [goody pudeater] _pudeator_ann  and sev-  erall others and they urged me to goe along with them to their  sacremental meeting and [mr Burroughs] _burroughs_george  brought to me bread to eat  and wine to drink which I Refuseing he did most greviously torment  me urging me vehemently to writ in his book: also I have seen mr  [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  or his Apperance most greviously tormenting [mary walcott] _walcott_mary  and [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  and I verily beleve in my heart that Mr.  [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  is a dreadfull wizzard and that he has severall  times tormented me and the affore said persons by his acts of  wicthcraft[Mary Warrin] _warren_mary  declared: upon: her oath; to the Jury of Inquest that  the above written evidence: is the truth. Aug'st 3: 1692( Witchcraft Papers, no. 8, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.30([Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[August 3, 1692]The Deposition of [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  agged about 17 years who testi-  fieth and saith that on the later end of April 1692: [mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  or his Apperance came to me whom I formerly well  knew: and he did Immediatly most greviously torment me by biting  pinching and almost choacking me urging me to writ in his book:  which I refusing he did -- againe most greviously torment me and  tould me if I would but touch his book I should be well but I tould  him I would not for all the world and then he threated to kil me and  said I should never witnes against him: but he continewed tortering  and tempting me tell the 8 may: and then he tould me he would  have kiled his first wife and child: when his wife was in travil but he had not the power: but he  keept hir in the kithin tell he gave hir hir deaths wound.but he  charged me in the name of his God I should not tell of it:but Im-  mediatly there appeared to me [mr.Burroughs] _burroughs_george  two first wives in their  winding sheets whom I formerly well knew and tould me that [mr. Burroughs] _burroughs_george  had murthered them and that their blood did crie for  vengance againt him: also on the 9'th may being the day of his ex-  amination he did most greviously torment me dureing the time of  his examination for if he did but look on me he would strick me  down or allmost Choake me: also dureing his examination I saw  [mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  or his Apperane most greviously torment  [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Eliz Hubb [e] rt] _hubbard_elizabeth  [Abigail william] _williams_abigail  and [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  and I  beleve in my heart that [mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  is a dreadful wizzard lb> and That he had often afflected and tormented me and the afore  mentioned parsons by his acts of wicthcraft[Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  declared this writing to be a true evidence: to the Jury  of Inquest Aug'st 3 1692 upon the oath she has takenJurat in Curia  ( Witchcraft Papers, no. 7a, Mass. Hist. Society )

[George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[+ May 9, 1692]The deposistion of [Tho. putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  aged 40: years and [Edward putnam] _putnam_edward   agged 38 years who testifieth and saith. that we haveing ben conver-  sant with severall of the afflected persons as [maryWolcott] _walcott_mary  [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Eliz: Hubburt] _hubbard_elizabeth  and we have seen them most dreadfully tomen-  ted and we have seen dreadfull marks in their fleesh which they  said [Mr. Burroughs] _burroughs_george  did make by hurting them: but on 9'th may 1692 : the day of the Examination of [Mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  the af-  foresaid parsons were most dreadfully tormented dureing the time  of his Examination as if they would have been torne al to peaces  or all their bones putt out of joynt and with such tortors as no  tounge can express also severall times sence we have seen the affore-  said afflected parsons most dreadfully tormented and greviously  complaining of [Mr. Burroughs] _burroughs_george  for hurting them and we beleve that   [Mr. George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  the prisoner att the bar has severall times af-  flected and tormented the afforesaid persons by acts of wicthcraft[*Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr   Jurat in Curia  ( Withcraft Papers, 11a, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA., Boston. )

title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.33( Deposition of [John Putnam, Sr.] _putnam_john_sr  and [Rebecca Putnam] _putnam_rebecca  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[+ May 9, 1692]the Deposition of [John putnam] _putnam_john_sr  & [Rebecah] _putnam_rebecca  his wife testifieth  and saith that in the yeare:80: [Mr Burros] _burroughs_george  lived in our house nine  month, there being a great differanc betwixt Sd [Barros] _burroughs_george  & his wife,  the differanc was so great that they did Desier us the deponants  to com into their room to hear their difference, the contrivercy  that was betwixt them was that the afor s'd [Burros] _burroughs_george  did rquier his  wife to give him a written covenant under her hand and Seall that  shee would never reveall his secrits, our anser was that they had  once made a covenant before god and men which covenant we did  conseive did bind each other to keep their lawfull secrits, and further  saith that all the time that s'd [Burros] _burroughs_george  did live att our house he was  a very sharp man to his wife, notwithstanding to our observation  shee was a very good and dutifully wife to himJurat in Curia  (Reverse) [Jno Put[nbar ]] _putnam_john_sr  & [Reb.] _putnam_rebecca  his wife. title: SWP No. 022: George Burroughs Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 22.34( Statement of [Elizar Keyser] _keyser_elizer  v. [George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  )[August 3, 1692][Elizer Keysar] _keyser_elizer  aged aboute fourty five yeares Sayth that on Thursday  last past being the fift day of this Instant moneth of May I was at  the house of [Thomas [Beadles]] _beadles_thomas  in salem, and Capt Daniell King being  there also, at the same tyme, and in the Same Roome. s'd Capt  [Daniell King] _king_daniel  Asked mee Whether I would not goe up, and see [mr Burrows] _burroughs_george  and discourse with him. he being then in one of the Cham-  bers in s'd House. I told him itt did not belong to mee, and I was   not willing to medle or make with itt, then s'd [King] _king_daniel  sayd are you not  a Christian if you are a Christian goe [&] see him and discourse with  him, but I told him I did beleive it did not belong to such as I was to  discourse him he being a Learned man. then s'd [King] _king_daniel  sayd I beleive  he is a Child of god, a Choice Child of god, and that God would  Clear up his Inocency; soe I told him my Opinion or feare was,  that he was, the Cheife of all the persons accused for witchcraft or  the Ring Leader of them -- all, and told him also that I beleived  if he was such an one his Master meening the divell had told him  before now, what I said of him, And s'd [King] _king_daniel  seemeing to mee to be  in a passion. I did afterwards forbeare #[The same Evening after  these words being alone in one Roome of my house and noe candle  or light being in the s'd Roome] the same afternoone I haveing Occa-  tion to be at the s'd [Beadles] _beadles_thomas  house and [being] in the Chamber  where [mr George Burroughs] _burroughs_george  Keept I observed that s'd [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  did  steadfastly fix [his] eys upon mee, the same Evening being in my  own house, in a Roome without any Light I did see very strange  things appeare in the Chimney. I suppose a dozen of them. w'ch  seemed to mee to be something like Jelly that used to be in the water  and quaver with a strainge Motion, and then quickly diappeared  soone after which I did see a light up in the chimney aboute the  bigness of my hand some thing above the bar w'ch quivered  & shaked. and seemed to have a Motion upward upon Which I called  the Mayd, and she looking up into the Chimney saw the same, and  my wife looking up could not see any thing, soe I did and doe  #[very Certainly] [Concider] it was some diabolicall apperition(On left side of paper) [Mr. Elizer. Keyzer:] _keyser_elizer  declared: to the Jury of Inquest that the evi-  dence: in this paper is the truth upon oath: Aug'st 3 1692 [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy . also: s'd that: [Mr Borroughs] _burroughs_george : told her that: he made lights: in [Mr Keyzers:] _keyser_elizer  ChimnyJurat in Curia   by  [Mr Keysor] _keyser_elizer   Sworne also by  [Eliz: Wardwell] _wardwell_elizabeth   as to the last night ( Manuscripts and Archives Division, Salem Selections New York Public Library. )

title: SWP No. 023: Candy
content: SWP No. 23.01(Examination of [Candy] _candy , as told by John Hale)[July 4, 1692 ]Among the Confessors, Anno 1692. was a Negro Woman, who charged two women to make her a Witch, describing how she see her mark in the Devils Book. And said, if she might be permitted, she would fetch the things whereby she tormented the afflicted complainers. And accordingly brought an Handkerchief, wherein several knots were tyed, raggs of Cloth, a piece of Cheese and a piece of grass And as I was credibly informed, some compelled her to swallow the grass, & that night was burned in her flesh; and one took a piece of her ragg and burnt it in the fire, and one of the Afflicted that had complained of her, was presently burned on the hand. Another piece of her rags was put under water, and then others complaintants were choaked, and strived for breath as if under water; And another ran to the River as if she would drown her self. John Hale. A Modest Enquiry into the Nature of Witchcraft (Boston: Green & Allen, 1702), pp. 80–81.

title: SWP No. 023: Candy
content: SWP No. 23.1(Examination of [Candy] _candy  )[July 4, 1692 ]SALEM, Monday, July 4, 1692 . The examination of [Candy] _candy , a  negro woman, before [Bartholomew Gedney] _gidney_bartholomew  and [John Hawthorne] _hawthorne_john   Esqrs. [Mr. Nicholas Noyes] _noyes_nicholas  also present.Q. [Candy] _candy  ! are you a witch? A. [Candy] _candy  no witch in her country.  [Candy] _candy 's mother no witch. [Candy] _candy  no witch, Barbados. This country,  mistress give [Candy] _candy  witch. Q. Did your mistress make you a witch in  this country? A. Yes, in this country mistress give [Candy] _candy  witch.  Q. What did your mistress do to make you a witch? A. Mistress bring  book and pen and ink, make [Candy] _candy  write in it. Q. What did you write  in it? -- She took a pen and ink and upon a book or paper made a  mark. Q. How did you afflict or hurt these folks, where are the pup-  pets you did it with? -- She asked to go out of the room and she  would shew or tell; upon which she had liberty, one going with her,  and she presently brought in two clouts, one with two knots tied in  it, the other one; which being seen by [Mary Warren] _warren_mary , [Deliverance Hobbs] _hobbs_deliverance  and [Abigail Hobbs] _hobbs_abigail , they were greatly affrighted and fell into  violent fits, and all of them said that the black man and [Mrs. Hawkes] _hawkes_margaret   and the negro stood by the puppets or rags and pinched them, and  then they were afflicted, and when the knots were untied yet they  continued as aforesaid. A bit of one of the rags being set on fire, the  afflicted all said they were burned, and cried out dreadfully. The  rags being put into water, two of the aforenamed persons were in  dreadful fits almost choaked, and the other was violently running  down to the river, but was stopped.Attest. [John Hawthorne] _hawthorne_john  , Just. Peace. ( Thomas Hutchinson,  History of Massachusetts-Bay. Cambridge, MA: 1936.II, 26 .)

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.3(Examination of [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[May 31, 1692 ]The Examination of [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  . 31. May. 1692 [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  w'o hurts you?[Goody Carrier] _carrier_martha  of Andover.[Eliz: Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  who hurts you?[Goody Carrier] _carrier_martha [Susan:Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  , who hurts you?[Goody Carrier] _carrier_martha  , she bites me, pinches me, & tells me she would cut  my throat, if I did not signe her book[Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  said she afflicted her & brought the book to her.What do you say to this you are charged with? I have not done it. [Sus:Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  cried she looks upon the black man.[Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  complained of a pin stuck in her.What black man is that? I know none [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  testifyed there was.[Mary Warrin] _warren_mary  cryed out she was prickt.What black man did you see? I saw no black man but your own presence. Can you look upon these & not knock them down? They will dissemble if I look upon them. You see you look upon them & they fall down It is false the Devil is a liar. I lookt upon none since I came into the room but you [Susan:Sheldon] _sheldon_susannah  cryed out in a Trance I wonder what could you  murder. 13. persons?[Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  testifyed the same that there lay.13. Ghosts.All the afflicted fell into most intollerable out-cries & agonies. [Eliz: Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  & [Ann Putman] _putnam_ann_jr  testifyed the same that she had killed  13. at Andover.It is a shamefull thing that you should mind these folks that are out  of their wits.Do not you see them? If I do speak you will not believe me? You do see them, said the accusers. You lye, I am wronged. There is the black man wispering in her ear said many of the afflicted. [Mercy Lewes] _lewis_mercy  in a violent fit, was well upon the examinants grasping  her arm.The Tortures of the afflicted was so great that there was no enduring  of it, so that she was ordered away & to be bound hand & foot with  all expedition the afflicted in the mean while almost killed to the  great trouble of all spectators Magistrates & others.Note. As soon as she was well bound they all had strange & sodain  ease.[Mary Walcot] _walcott_mary  told the Magistrates that this woman told her she  had been a witch this. 40. yeares.(Reverse) [Martha Carriers] _carrier_martha  Carrier Examina[cbar ]ion( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1, no. 311. )
