title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.6(Summons for Witnesses and Officer's Return)[July 30, 1692 ]Wm & Mary by the Grace of God of England Scotland France  & IrelandKing & Queen defend'rs of the faith &ca To the Constable or Constables of Andover Greeting   Wee Comand you to Warn & give Notice unto [Allen Toothaker] _toothaker_allen   [Ralph farnum Jun'r] _farnham_ralph_jr  [John farnum] _farnum_john  son of [Ralph farnum sen'r] _farnham_ralph_sr   [Benjamin Abbot] _abbott_benjamin  & his wife [Andrew foster] _foster_andrew  [Phebe Chandler] _chandler_phoebe  daughter  of [Wm Chandler] _chandler_william_sr  : [Sam'l Holt Sen'r] _holt_samuel  [Samuel Preston Jun'r] _preston_samuel_jr  that they  & Every of them be and personaly appear at the Court of Oyer & Ter-  miner to be held by adjournment on Tuesday Next at Ten of the  Clock in the Morning there to testifye the truth to the best of their  knowledge on certain Indictments to be Exhibited against [Marth Car- rier] _carrier_martha  of Andover hereof fail not at your utmost perill & make return  of your doings hereinDated in Salem  July 30'th 1692   [Stephen Sewall] _sewall_stephen  Cle[rbar ]. (Reverse) In obedenc to this writ I have timely warned the persons  hose names are herein writen and every one of them this I day of  august 1692 By mee [John Ballard] _ballard_john  constable of Andover ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem - Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 313)

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.7(Summons for Witnesses)[July 30, 1692 ]William & Mary by the Grace of God of England Scotland France  & Ireland King & Queen defend'rs of the faith &caTo the Constable of Billrica Greeting. -- Wee Comand you to Warn & give Notice unto [Capt Danforth] _danforth_capt  -- [John Rogers] _rogers_john  & that they & Every of them be and personaly appear at the  Court of Oyer & Terminer to be held by Adjurnment Att Salem on  Tuesday Next at Ten of the Clock in the Morning there to testify the   truth to the best of their knowledge on Certaine Indict-  ments to be Exhibited against [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  of Andover and hereof  they Nor you are to fail at your utmost perill making return hereof  under your hand. --Dated in Salem  July 30'th 1692  & in the fourth year of Our Reign  [*Stephen Sewall] _sewall_stephen  Cle[rbar ]. (Reverse)According to this warrant I have shew ^d it^ to [Capt Danforth] _danforth_capt , & his Answr is, that hee can say nothing in ^yt^ case, that is worth mentioning, I have warned John Rogers, & he saith he will attend if his garison may guarded in his absence Billerica Ahgr August 1st. 92 James paterson, Cconst: ( Witchcraft Papers No. 18. Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.8( Testimony of [Benjamin Abbott] _abbott_benjamin  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[August 3, 1692 ]The teastymony of [Benjamin Abbutt] _abbott_benjamin  aged about 31 years Saith:  last march was twelfe months: then haveing Some land granted to  me by the Touwne of Andover Near to good man Carriers his land,  & when this land Came to be laied out [goodwiffe Carrier] _carrier_martha  was verÿ  Angerÿ , & said that she would stick as Closs to [Benjamin Abbut] _abbott_benjamin  as  the bark stooke to the Tree & that I should Repent of it afore Seven  years Came to an Eand & that doctor prescott Could Never Cure  me: These words were heard bÿ [Allin Toothaker] _toothaker_allen  She also Said to  [Ralph farnam Jun'r] _farnham_ralph_jr  that she would hold my noss so Closs to the  grindstone as Ever it was held since mÿ Name was [Benjamin Abbut:] _abbott_benjamin   presently after I was taken with a swelling in mÿ foott & then was  taken with a paÿne in mÿ side Ecksidienglÿ Tormented, wich bred  to a sore: which was lancit bÿ docter prescott & severall gallons of  Corruption did Run out as was Judged & so Continued about six  weeks Verÿ bad, & then one other sore did breed in mÿ grine wich  was lancit bÿ doct.prescott also: & Continued verÿ bad a while  & then on other sore breedin mÿ grine which was also Cutt: & putt me  to verÿ great misserÿ , so that it brough me almost to Deaths doore,  & Continued, untill [goodwiffe Carrier] _carrier_martha  was Taken & Carried a waÿe  by the Constable & that verÿ daÿ I begun to grow better, mÿ soers  grew well & I grew better Everÿ daÿ: & so have been well Ever since:  & have great cause to think that the s'd [Carrier] _carrier_martha  had a great hand in  my sickness & misery[benjamen Abbut] _abbott_benjamin   Jurat in Curia  Aug't 3'd. 1692.   Attest [Step. Sewall] _sewall_stephen  Cle[rbar ]. ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 314 )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.9(Deposition of [Sarah Abbott] _abbott_sarah  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[August 3, 1692 ]The deposition of [Sarah Abbott] _abbott_sarah  aged about 32 years testifieth  that since my husband had a parcell of land granted by the Towne,  lying near the land of [Thomas Carrier] _carrier_thomas_sr  , (Which as I have heard) his  wife [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  was greatly troubled att & gave out Threatening  words) that my husband [Benjamin Abbott] _abbott_benjamin  has not been only afflic-  ted in his body, as he testifies, but alsoe that strange & unusuall  things has happened to his Cattle, for some have died suddenly  & strangely, which we could not tell any naturall reason for, & one  Cowe Cleaned a fourthnight before she Calved, but the Cowe died  afterwards strangely though she calved well soe far as we Could  [pbar ]rceive , & some of the Cattle would Come out of the woods w'th  their tounges hanging out of their mouths in a strange & affright-  ing manner, & many such things, which we can give noe account of  the reason of, unless it should be the effects, of [martha Carriers] _carrier_martha   threatningsJuriat: in Curia   Aug't 3'd 1692  attest  her mark.  [Sarah Abbott] _abbott_sarah   [*Steph:Sewall] _sewall_stephen  Cle[rbar ]. (Reverse) [Ben Abbott] _abbott_benjamin  & wife ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 314 )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.10(Deposition of [John Rogers] _rogers_john  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[August 2, 1692 ]The deposition of [John Rogger] _rogers_john  of Billreca aged 50 yeares or  Thereabouts SaithThat about Seven yeares since [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  being a Nigh Neig-  bour unto this depon't and there hapening some difference betwixt  us she gave forth severall threatning words as she often used to doe  and in a short time after this deponent had two large lusty Sowes  w'ch frequented home daily that were lost & this deponent: found  one of them dead Nigh the s'd Carriers house w'th both Eares cut  of & the other sow I Never heard of to this day; & the same summer  to the best of my rembrance I had a Cow w'ch used to give a good  Mess of milke twice a day & of a sudden she would give little or  None Every Morning though a Nights she gave as formerly and   this Continued above the space of a month in w'ch time I had three  Meals milke on three severall Mornings not successively: and no  more though One Night three of us Watched the Cow all night  #[one night] yet I could have no milke in the morning of her  & about the monthes End she gave milke as formerly she used, by all  w'ch. I did in my Conscience beleive then in the day of it & have so  done Ever since & doe yet beleive that [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  was the occa-  sion of those Ill accidents. by Meanes of Witchcraft she being a very  Malicous Woman & further Saith Notmarke of   [John Rogger] _rogers_john  Inq'd [Sam Holt] _holt_samuel  Andover about [M.C. Capt Danforth] _danforth_capt  Billerica (Reverse) [Jno Rogger] _rogers_john  of Billrica Ver: [Marth: Carrier] _carrier_martha  Court O.  & Ter. by Adjt Aug't 2.92 [Carrier] _carrier_martha  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 315 )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.11(Deposition of [Phoebe Chandler] _chandler_phoebe  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[+ August 3, 1692 ]The deposition of [Phoebe Chandl'r] _chandler_phoebe  aged about 12 years:Testifieth That about a fourthnight before [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  , was  sent for to Salem to be examined, upon the Sabbath day when the  psalm was singing, s'd [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  took me s'd deponent by the  shoulder & shaked me, in the meeting house & asked me where I  lived: but I made her no answere, (not doubting but that she knew  me, having lived some time the next door to my fathers house, on  one side of the way) & that day that s'd [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  was ceased,  my mother sent me to Carry some bear to the folks that were att  work in the lott, & when I came within the fence there was a voice  in the bushes(which I thought was [Martha Carriers] _carrier_martha  voice, which I  knowe well) but saw noe body, & the voice asked me, what I did  there & whether I was going: which greatly frighted me, soe that  I run as fast as I could to those att work, & told them what I had  heard, about an hour & half, or two hours after, my mother sent me  again upon the same occasion, to the workmen aboves'd Coming  home, near the place aboves'd where I heard that voice before, I   heard the same voice, as I judged, over my head, saying I should be  poysoned within two or three days, which accordingly happened, as  I Conceive, for I went to my sister Allens farm the same day, and on  friday following, about one half of my right hand was greatly swolen  & exceeding painfull, & allsoe part of my face, which I can give noe ac-  count how it Came & Continued very bad some days, & severall  times since I have been troubled with a great weight upon my breast,  & upon my leggs, when I have been going about, soe that I could  hardly goe, which I have told my mother of: And the last sabbath  day was seaven night, I went to meeting very well in the morning,  & went to my place where I used to sitt (the ministers not being Come)  & [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  son of aboves'd [Martha] _carrier_martha  looked very earnestly  upon me, & imediately my hand which had formerly been poy-  soned as aboves'd, began to pain me greatly, & I had a strange burn-  ing att my stomake, & then was struck deaf that I could not hear  any of the prayer, nor singing, tell the two or three last words of  the singing:Jurat in Curia   her mark  [Phoebe Chandler] _chandler_phoebe   [Bridget Chandler] _chandler_bridget  aged 40 years Mother to the s'd [Phoebe] _chandler_phoebe  Testi-  fieth that in the day of it her daughter Complained as above is Ex-  pressed. Jurat in Curia  (Reverse) [Phebe Chandler] _chandler_phoebe  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 316 )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.13(Deposition of [Allen Toothaker] _toothaker_allen  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[+ August 3, 1692 ]The deposition of [Allin Toothaker] _toothaker_allen  aged about 22 years Saith  I heard [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  Saÿ that [Benjamin Abbutt] _abbott_benjamin  would wish he   had not medled with that land so Near our houwse for she would  stick as Cols to him as the barck to the tree, afore seaven years Com  a bout, & that doctor prescott should Never Cure him, & a bout last  march [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  & mÿ selfe had som difference, & said Rich-  ard pulled me downe by the haer of mÿ head to the ground for to  beat me: I desired him to lett me Risse, when I was up I went to  strick at him, but I fell downe flate upon my back to the ground  & had not power to ster hand Nor foote, then I toold sayd Richard  I would yeald to him & owne him the best man & then I saw [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  goe of from mÿ brest, butt when I was Rissen up I saw non of  her, I was Wounded in the Warre, [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  tould me I Would  Never be Cured, afore she was Aprehended I Could thrust in mÿ  Wound a knitting Nedle four Inches deep but, since she have been  Taken I am thorowlÿ healed: and have had more Ease then I have  had in halfe a year before Sometimes when [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  & I had  some difference she would Clap her hand at me & saÿ I should gett.  Nothing by it: & #[still] with i[numl ] a daÿ, or two: I lost a three year  old heffer: Next a yealin: & then a Couw; & then had som litle dif-  ference a gaine & lost a yearlin, #[ -- -- these aboves'd Creatures  which died, I could not Learn of any reason for their -- -- ] And I  knowe not of any naturall Causes of the death of the abovs'd Crea-  tures, but have always feared it hath been the effect of my Aunt  [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  her malice:Jurat in Curia   his mark  [Allen Toothaker] _toothaker_allen  (Reverse) [Allen Toothaker] _toothaker_allen  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 No. 317 )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.14(Testimony of [Samuel Preston] _preston_samuel  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[+ August 3, 1692 ][Samuel Preston] _preston_samuel  aged about 41: years Saith that about 2 yeares  since I had some difference w'th [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  w'ch also had  hapened sever'll times before and soon after I lost a Cow in a strange  manner being Cast upon her back w'th her heels up in firm ground  when she was very Lusty it being in June & within abo't month after   this the s'd [Martha] _carrier_martha  & I had some difference again at which Time she  told me I had lost a Cow lately & it Would not or should not be  long before I should loose Another w'ch accordingly came to pass.  for I had a Cow that was well kept w'th English Hay & I could not  [pbar ]ceive that she aild any thing & yet she pined & quickley lay downe  as if she was asleep & dyedJurat in Curia  (Reverse) [Sam. Preston] _preston_samuel  ag't [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 no. 318 )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.15(Deposition of [Elizabeth Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[July 1, 1692]The deposistion of [Eliz: Hubburd] _hubbard_elizabeth  agged about 17 years who testi-  fieth and saith that I have been along time afflected by a woman that  tould me hir name was [Carrier] _carrier_martha  and that she came from Andevore but  on the 31:may 1692 [martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  did most greviously tortor. me  dureing the time of hir Examination for if she did but look upon me  she would strick me down or almost choak me and also I saw [martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  most greviously torment [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary , [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy , [Abigail williams] _williams_abigail  and [ann putnam jun'r] _putnam_ann_jr  with such dreadfull tortor as no tongue  can express: that had not the Honr'd Majestrats Commanded hir to  be fast bound I beleve she would have quickly kiled sume of us: and  I verily beleve in my hart that [martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  is a most dreadful  wicth for severall times sence [martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  #[or hir Apperance]  has been in prison she hath or hir Apperance com to me and most  greviously tortored me by pinching pricking and [and] almost choak-  ing me to death: which I beleve she could not doe if she ware not a  witch/[Elizabeth Hubburd:] _hubbard_elizabeth  owned: the above written evidence: to be the  truth: to the Jury of Inquest: upon: the oath: she hath taken:  July: 1: 1692Jurat in Curia  ( Witchcraft Papers no. 17b, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.16(Deposition of [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[July 1, 1692]The deposistion of [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  agged about 18 years who testifi-  eth and saith that I have ben a long time afflected by a woman  which tould me hir name was [Carrier] _carrier_martha  and that she came from Ande-  vor but on the 31'th may 1692 : [martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  of Andever did most  greviously torment me dureing the time of hir Examination by  biting pricking pinching and all most Choaking me to death for if  she did but look upon me she would strik me down or allmost  Choak me to death also on the day of hir Examination I saw [martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  most greviously torment and afflect [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Elizabeth Hubburd] _hubbard_elizabeth  abigail williams and ann putnam jun'r by most dreadfully  pricking and claping hir hand on their throats and allmost choaking  them to death and with such cruell tortors as no toung can Express:  that had not the Hon'rd Majestrats Command hir to be bound fast  #[heart I beleve] she would have quickly kild sum of us: and I  beleve in my heart that [Martha carrier] _carrier_martha  is a most dreadfull wicth and  that she hath tormented me and the parsons affore named by hir  acts of wicthcraf[Mary Walcot:] _walcott_mary  owned: to: the Jury of inquest that the above written  evidence: is the truth. upon the oath she hath taken: July 1: 1692Jurat in Curia  ( Witchcraft Papers, no. 17a, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.17( Deposition of [Thomas Putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  and [John Putnam, Jr.] _putnam_john_jr  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  )[+ August 3, 1692]The Deposistion of [Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  agged 40 years and [Jno putnam] _putnam_john_jr   aged 36 years -- who testifie and saith that we haveing ben conversant  with divers of the afflected parsons as namely [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  [mercy lewes] _lewis_mercy  [Abigail williams] _williams_abigail  [Eliz. Hubburt] _hubbard_elizabeth  and [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  and we have  seen tham often most greviously tormented by biting pinching and  being almost Choak to death often Complaining of one [goody Carrier] _carrier_martha  for hirting them: but on the 31: may 1692 being the day of  the Examination of [martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  the afforementioned parsons  ware most dreadfully tormented dureing the time of hir exami-    nation  that had not the Hon'd Majestrats commanded hir to be  bound we ware redy to think she would quickly have kiled sum of  them: also severall times sence we have seen the affore mentioned  most dreadfully affleted and tormented as if all their bones would  have been disjoyned or [their] bodyes twisted all to peces com-  plaining most dreadfully of [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  for hurting them and we  beleve in our hearts that [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  the prizsoner att the barr  has most dreadfully tormented and most greviously afflected the  affore mentioned parsons by acts of wicthcraft[Thomas putnam] _putnam_thomas_jr   [Jno putnam] _putnam_john_jr   Jurat in Curia  ( Witchcraft Papers, no. 21a, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 024: Martha Carrier Executed, August 19, 1692
content: SWP No. 24.18( Testimony of [Andrew Foster] _foster_andrew  v. [Martha Carrier] _carrier_martha  ,  [Mary Toothaker] _toothaker_mary  , and -- Toothaker)[+ August 3, 1692]The tistimony of [Andrew foster] _foster_andrew  aged about 55 who saith that some  time Last may I being at the hous of [Thomas Carrier] _carrier_thomas_jr  I was saieing  that I hard that when [Timothy oosgood] _osgood_timothy  and his Brother [Samuell] _osgood_samuel   want to Salam the other day thay goeing to Let Engerson one of the  afflicted maides lucked out and asked what thay brought them three  woman behind them fore thay asked what woman the maid sayd  [Goodwife Carrier] _carrier_martha  goodwife Touthacor and hir dughter and thay goe-  ing into Engerson hous thay askeed the maide where [goodwife car- rier] _carrier_martha  was shee Answared thar shee sits by you upon the table upon  which the maide had a fitt: which #[almost] twisted her nick  almost round of. then [goodwife carrier] _carrier_martha  Answared no it is no matter  if hir nicke had ben quite of if shee sayd I was thiereJurat in Curia  ( Witchcraft Papers, no. 21b, Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston, MA., Boston, MA. )

title: SWP No. 025: Richard Carrier
content: SWP No. 25.1(Warrant for apprehension of [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  and [Andrew Carrier] _carrier_andrew  and Officer's Return)[July 21, 1692]To the Sherriffe of the County of Essex or Deputy or Constable  of Andover You are in their Majesties names hereby required to  Apprehend and forthwith bring before us [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  and  [Andrew Carrier] _carrier_andrew  Son of [Thomas Carier] _carrier_thomas_sr  of Andivor Husband-  man who Stands charged on behalfe of their Majesties with have-  ing Comitted Sundry acts of wichcraft on the body of Mary  Warren of Salem &c & that in order to his Examination relating  to the abovesaid premisses and hereof Faile not & you are like-  wise to inquire after & make Serch for any paper or popetts.  that may relate to witchcraft.[Bartho' Gedney] _gidney_bartholomew   [John Hathorn] _hawthorne_john   [Jonathan. Corwin] _corwil_jonathan   [John Higginson] _higginson_john   Jus's Peace Dated in Salem 21 July 1692  in obedience to this warrant I have  sessed the body of [richard carier] _carrier_richard  and  [andrew carier] _carrier_andrew  and have brought them  to the house of [Mr Thomas [Beadle]:] _beadles_thomas  By me [*John Ballard] _ballard_john   Constable in Andover ( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 208, Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts, Boston Public Library )

title: SWP No. 025: Richard Carrier
content: SWP No. 25.2(Examination of [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  and [Andrew Carrier] _carrier_andrew[July 22, 1692]22th July 1692 [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  aged 18 years & His Brother [Andrew] _carrier_andrew  a'bt 16 years [Rich'd Carrier] _carrier_richard  & his brother brought into Court who unto many Questions propounded returend Negative Answers to all & the afflicted persons s'd they Saw the black man & there Mother w'th others stand before them on the Table to Hinder there Conffession --Q.M.L. did not [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  Joynee w'th. you In severall things A Yes & he burned [Timo Swan] _swan_timothy  w'th his Tobacco pipe Q Where was [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  when he did it A In [Swans] _swan_timothy  Chamber In Spirit Q Who Else Joyned In it A [Goody Carrier] _carrier_martha  My Ganmother & Mother & Rich'd Q. Was Rich'd there bodyly A his body Came to the house & his Spirit went In & did it -- Q were ye all bodyly in the Chamber A Somtimes we ware in Shapes & Somtimes in body but they did not See us She s'd further that they rod upon hand poles & the Divel also was there in the Shape of a black Man & high Crowned hatt & bid us Kill [Swan] _swan_timothy  by Stabing him to Death & we also Stick pinns Into his Liknes Q. and what Else had you any hott Irons or knitting Knedles A Yes we had an Iron Spindle & [Rich'd Carrier] _carrier_richard  ran it through or Into [Swans] _swan_timothy  Knee Q wher had you that Spindle A the Divel Brought it to us Q had you any quarrell w'th. him A we all Came in Upon [Mrs. Bradberys] _bradbury_mary  Acco' or quarrel She had w'th. him Q [Goody Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  did not you hurt [Swan] _swan_timothy  . A No The daughter S'd. Yes Mother doe not deny it Q Goody Lacy who was in the Company A Goody Carrier & her Son [Mrs. Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  & wee Q were not the Mother there viz [foster] _foster_ann  A I know not but She Might be there Q. did You hurt him A the Divel made his Imps doe it Q w'ch way did you hurt him A there was hott Irons & the Divel  held them Q. the Daughter s'd it was an Iron Spindle A yes yes it was a Spindle Q. did you practise w'th. a Tobaco. pipe A I think once Q who was it that you hurt A [Timo. Swan] _swan_timothy  Q who held the pipe A the Divel & his Imps Q. had You any thing for his Sicknes A ther was athing before as it were -- Goody Lacey were You in the Chamb'r w'th him A Yes [Q] w'ch way did you gett in A the Divel helped us in at the window And Mary Lacey s'd She sent in at the door Mary Lacey how maney was there A granmoth'r Goody Carrier [Rich'd Carriers] _carrier_richard  Mother & G. & [Mrs. Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  & we went upon the Divel & [Mrs. Bradb'y] _bradbury_mary  . acc't. who Came to us & brought us from our own home.And we consented to Kill him if we were not brought out before, & here [Marey Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  Related Somthing of the Quarrell between [Bradb'y] _bradbury_mary  . & Swan a'bt Thatching of a house -- Now [Rich'd Carrier] _carrier_richard  w't say you to these two Evidences that saw You w'th [Timo. Swan] _swan_timothy  , but Still he Denyed all -- Questions -- [Mary Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  when you went to afflict [Ballard] _ballard_elizabeth  was not this man w'th You Viz Rich'd. Carrier A Yes & it was a'bt afortnight Since we went upon poles in the night we got into the house & this Rich'd. afflicted [Ballard] _ballard_elizabeth  by pinching & choaking her & I was ther also when the Sider was Drawn Goody Lacey doe you Remember anything of afflicting this [Ballard] _ballard_elizabeth  A Yes. and this Rich'd was there and afflicted by pinching choaking & Laying his hand on her Stomak [Mary Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  Urged [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  very much to Confes & S'd further that he bid her help to kill [Swan] _swan_timothy  & that they used to discourse togeth'r on ther Jorneys & used to tell her he would goe and afflict persons, telling him he had ahart as hard as a Rock to Deny it, she s'd further that this [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  told her he would Kill [Goody ballard] _ballard_elizabeth  also Mary was it [Richard] _carrier_richard  pipe that burnt [Swan] _swan_timothy  A. Yes and it he did him Self & Run the Spindle into [Swans] _swan_timothy  knee he told me also that he would make his Broth'r one & afflict person [Mary Warrin] _warren_mary  in abad fitt & blood Runing out of her Mouth. [Mary Lacy] _lacey_mary_jr  S'd. that this Andrew did it. The afflicted persons were Grevously tormented that [Richa'd] _carrier_richard  and [Andrew] _carrier_andrew  were Carried out to another Cambbre and there feet & hands bound a Little while after [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  was brought In again Q Rich'd though you have been Verry Obstinate Yett tel us how long agoe it is Since you ware taken in this SnareA ayear Last May and Noe More Unto Many Questions Propounded he answered affermativly as followeth viz he Saw the Shape of a man In the night, he had been in twone & was Goeing home the man was Black & had a high Crowned hat he told me I was afrayd to goe home  & asked me what I Should be afraid of & proffered to goe a little way w'th me, he bid me Serve him & he would Gett me New Cloaths & give me a horse, he told me also that he was Christ, & I must beleve him, & I think I did Soe, I Sett my hand to his book it was a little Red book I wrought w'th a Stick & mad a red Colour w'h it & I promised to Serve him & at parting. hee bid bid me goodnight -- the 2nd time he Apeared to me was in the Shape of a Yellow Bird And told me. he had not performed his promise but would & that Shortly -- I was to doe Service a'bt the Children & afflicted persons he told me also of [Timo. Swan] _swan_timothy  & I must Give him leave to afflict him he asked my Consent also to afflict [Ballards wife] _balch_elizabeth  -- I also hurt the Images of persons or the liknes of them by Sqezing anything I had amind to, betwene my hands -- The 2nd Aperance was last January, It is not above amoth Since that I began to afflict [Swan] _swan_timothy  , I can not tell how long it is Since that I rod to Salem Village, I was ther twice & Rod w'th [Mary Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  the Divel Carried us Somtimes in the Shape of a horse somtimes In the Shape of a Man the 1rst time he was ahorse the 2nd. time a Man, when he was a horse our pol lay a Crose the horse, when he was a man our pol was on his Sholder -- when We went to [ballard] _ballard_joseph  he was a man we ware at [ballards] _ballard_joseph  house and went in Somtimes at the Window & Somtimes at the Door, I goot the Sider out of the Sell'r. & Drew it in a pot belonging to the house & Drank it in the Orchard I fetcht the Sider my Self & went in my Spirit for it here [Mary Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  S'd he went in his Spirit & his body lay dead the while & out of doors he s'd it was true --I hurt Swan in my Spirit & Struck him in the knee w'th a Spindle the Divel brought it & was then in the Shape of a black man & high Crowned hatt I afflicted [frys] _fry_eunice  Child by Squezing of it & I did it upon anything I had amind should represent the Child, my Mother was w'th me Somtimes but not often, -- Mother was bodyly w'th me -- I have Seen her once in her Spirit Since her Imprissonment & in the Shape of a Catt I was present when brother Signed the book & I think Mother was there also & the Divel -- I rod the 1st time on a horse & the 2nd time on a man to Salem Village & think there might be a Seventy there at Each Mettings, we mett in a Green w'ch was the Ministers paster -- And we were in two Companys at the Last I think there was a few Men w'th them I heard [Sarah Good] _good_sarah  talk of a minister or two -- one of them was he that had ben at the Estward  & preached once at the Village, his name Is [Burroughs] _burroughs_george  and he Is a little man -- I remember not the other Ministers Name I saw the Divel Open a Grate Booke & we all Sett or hands & Seales to it, the Ingagement was to afflict persons & over Come the Kingdome of Christ, & set up the Divels Kingdome & we ware to have hapy Days -- Marey Lacey S'd she heard them talk of throwing Dwone the Kingdome of Christ & Setting up the Divel on his throwne -- they ware to doe Soe throughout all the whole Country & were Enjoyned by the Divel to make as many Witches as we Could -- I know [Marthra Toothaker] _toothaker_mary  & her Mother to be witches & they ware in Company both times -- In Goeing to the Village Metting -- [Goody Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  s'd all this was true [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  S'd that Toothak'r. that Dyed in prison was one too, [Mary lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  then in a bad fitt afflicted, this [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  Could then See Toothak'r Upon her --( Essex Institute Collection, no. 24, 3r-4r, James Duncan Phillips Library, Peabody Essex Museum, Salem. )Q. [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  can you name any that ware at the mettings A. [Jno. Willard] _willard_john  [Jno. Procter] _proctor_john  & his Wife [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  . Goodman Gory & his wife. [Goody. how] _how_elizabeth  [Mrs Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  & [Goody Oliver] _bishop_bridget  &c. -- [Jno. Willard] _willard_john  Is a black hared Man of a Midle Statture & he told me his Name -- we heard a drum & [Mary Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  heard the Same -- [Mary Lacey] _lacey_mary_jr  In a bad fitt [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  Sayd an kurse upon her & S'd. further that that man was at Salem Village Metting -- I was w'th [ballards wife] _balch_elizabeth  I Think I have afflicted 3 at the Village -- 2 in the Ministers house one of them a grown person the other a Child the growne person was the Mrs of the house, the Younger person was one [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  also [Mary Walkutt] _walcott_mary  on Wednesday last, I doe it by Roling up a handcherchif & Soe Imagining to be a representation of a person -- the Divel Doth it Some times the Divell Sturred Me Up to hurt the Ministers Wife -- I was Baptized at the falls at Newberry in the River he dipt my head into the Watt'r. but doe not Remember w't he S'd there were not above 7 Baptiz'd Viz [Mrs Brad'y] _bradbury_mary  [Goody Nurse] _nurse_rebecca  [Goody How] _how_elizabeth  -- When they Signed the book the Divel told them they Should over Come & Prevail the witches are all afaird they Shall al Come out & the Divel threatens if I come not Unto this Quarrell he will tear me in peaces --  After this [Rich'd] _carrier_richard  would take the afflicted persons by the hand w'th out hurting of them & asked forgiveness --

title: SWP No. 025: Richard Carrier
content: SWP No. 25.3(Examination of [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  )[July 22, 1692][Richard Carriers:] _carrier_richard  Confession July 22: 1692 Q. have you bin in the devils snare A: yes. Q. is yo'r bro: [Andrew] _carrier_andrew   ensnared by the devils snare: A Yes how long has yo'r brother bin   a witch: A: not long: Q. have you joined in aflicting the aflicted  persons: A: Yes: Q. you help't to hurt: [Timo: Swan:] _swan_timothy  did you A yes.  Q. how long: have you bin a wich: A abo't five weeks: who was in  Company when you Covnanted with the devill: A [Mrs Bradbery] _bradbury_mary   did she help you afflict: yes: what was the ocasion: [mrs Bradbery:] _bradbury_mary   would have to afflict [Timo. Swan:] _swan_timothy  A becaus: [her husband] _bradbury_thomas  & [Timo Swan] _swan_timothy  fell out about a scyth: I think: Q. did they not fall out about  thaching of a barn: to A no not as I know of Q. who was att the  Villadge meeting when you was there. A [goodwife How] _how_elizabeth  : [goodwife Nurs] _nurse_rebecca  [g wildes] _wilds_sarah  , Procter: & his wife [mrs Bradbery] _bradbury_mary  : & Gorys wife: Q:  was any of Boston there A no: Q how many was there in all: A: a  duzzen I think: was [Jno Willard] _willard_john  there A I think he was: Q. what kind  of man is [Jno willard:] _willard_john  a young man or an old man A he is not an old  man: he had black hair Q what meeting was this meeting: was this:  that: that was near: [Ingersals:] _ingersoll_nathaniel  A Yes I think Q. what did they do  then. A. the: eat & they drank wine: was there: a minister. there A.  no: not as I know of: whence had you your wine: A. from Salem I  think was from Q. [goodwife Olliver] _bishop_bridget  there: yes I knew her( Essex County Archives Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 No. 111 )

title: SWP No. 025: Richard Carrier
content: SWP No. 25.4(Indictment v. [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard  for Afflicting [Timothy Swann] _swan_timothy  )[+ January 13, 1693]Province of the Massatutchetts  Bay in New England EssexAnno RR's & Reginae Gulielmi & Mariae Angliae &c Quarto Annoq'e  \ D[mbar ] : 1692The Jurors for our Sov'r Lord & Lady the King & Queen Presents  That [Richard Carier] _carrier_richard  of Andvor in the County of Essex Son of  Andrew Carier of Andivor aforesaid Husbandman Sometime in the  month of June in the Yeare 1692 aforesaid -- And Divers other  Dayes and times as well before as after Certaine Detestable Arts  called Witchcrafts & Sorceries Wickedly Mallishiously & felloniously  hath Used Practised and Excercised at & in the Towne of Andivor in  the County of Essex afores'd upon & against one [Timothy Swann] _swan_timothy  --  the Day and year afores'd and Divers other Dayes and times as well  before as after, was and is Tortured Afflicted Tormented Consumed  Pined and wasted against the Peace of our Sovereigne Lord and Lady   the King & Queen their Crowne & Dignity and the Lawes in that Case  made and Provided(Reverse) [Richard Carryer] _carrier_richard  for Afflicting [Timothy Swan] _swan_timothy Billa vera [*Richard Payne] _payne_robert  foreman( Massachusetts Archives. Vol. 135 No. 130, Massachusetts State Archives, Boston. )

title: SWP No. 025: Richard Carrier
content: SWP No. 25.5(Fragment of an Examination of [Richard Carrier] _carrier_richard )[July 22, 1692]We met in a green, which was the minister's pasture-we were in two companies at last. I think there was a few men with them.-I heard [Sarah Good] _good_sarah  talk of a minister or two. One of them was she that had been at the eastward; his name is [Burroughs] _burroughs_george , and is a little man.-I remember not the other's name.The New England Historical & Genealogical Register and Antiquarian Journal, 1870 edition, p. 401: "The Witchcraft Delusion of 1692" by Gov. Thomas Hutchinson, from manuscript draft of his The History of the Province of Massachusetts Bay (1760s).

title: SWP No. 026: Sarah Carrier
content: SWP No. 26.1(Examination of [Sarah Carrier] _carrier_sarah  )[+August 11, 1692. ]The Examination of [Sarah Carrier] _carrier_sarah  Taken before [Dudly Broad- steat] _bradstreet_dudley  [Sarah Carrier] _carrier_sarah  being accused of witchcraft Confeseth as fol-  loweth that she hath been a witch Ever Since She was Six years Old  that her Moth'r brought a red book to her and She touched it that  her Moth'r Baptiz'd her in [Andrew fostters] _foster_andrew  pauster the day before  She went to prison & that her Moth'r promised her she should  not be hanged that her Mother taught her how to afflicte persons  by pinching them or Setting on them that She began to afflict [Sarah Phelps] _phelps_sarah  last Satterdy & that [Betty Johnson] _johnson_elizabeth_jr  was w'th her that her  Moth'r gave her a Spear last Night & that She pricked [Sarah Phelps] _phelps_sarah   & [Ann Puttnam] _putnam_ann_jr  w'th it.(On side of paper) [Sarah Carrier] _carrier_sarah ( Essex Institute Collection, Peabody Essex Museum, No. 24- 5 )

title: SWP No. 026: Sarah Carrier
content: SWP No. 26.2(Examination of [Sarah Carrier] _carrier_sarah  .)[August 11, 1692. ]Aug. the 11th, 1692. It was asked [Sarah Carrier] _carrier_sarah  by the Magistrates or Justices [John Hawthorne] _hawthorne_john  Esq; and others: How long hast thou been a witch? A.  Ever since I was six years old. Q. How old are you now? A. Near  eight years old, brother [Richard] _phelps_richard  says, I shall be eight years old in  November next. Q. Who made you a witch? A. My mother, she  made me set my hand to a book. Q. How did you set your hand to  it? A. I touched it with my fingers and the book was red, the paper   of it was white. She said she never had seen the black man; the place  where she did it was in [Andrew Foster's] _foster_andrew  pasture and [Elizabeth Johnson junr.] _johnson_elizabeth_jr  was there. Being asked who was there beside, she answered  her Aunt Toothaker and her cousin. Being asked when it was, she  said, when she was baptized. Q. What did they promise to give you?  A. A black dog. Q. Did the dog ever come to you? A. No. Q. But  you said you saw a cat once. What did that say to you? A. It said  it would tear me in pieces if I would not set my hand to the book.  She said her mother baptized her, and the devil or black man was  not there, as she saw, and her mother said when she baptized her,  thou are mine for ever and ever and amen. Q. How did you afflict  folks? A. I pinched them, and she said she had no puppets, but  she went to them that she afflicted. Being asked whether she went in  her body or her spirit, she said in her spirit. She said her mother  carried her thither to afflict. Q. How did your mother carry you  when she was in prison? A. She came like a black cat. Q. How did  you know that it was your mother? A. The cat told me so that she  was my mother. She said she afflicted Phelp's child last saturday,  and [Elizabeth Johnson] _johnson_elizabeth_jr  joined with her to do it. She had a wooden  spear, about as long as her finger, of Elizabeth Johnson, and she had  it of the devil. She would not own that she had ever been at the  witch meeting at the village. This is the substance.Attest. [Simon Willard.] _willard_simon  ( Thomas Hutchinson, The History of the Province of Massachusetts-Bay, vol. 2, ed. Lawrence Shaw Mayo. (Harvard University Press, 1936). p. 34..)

title: SWP No. 027: Thomas Carrier Jr.
content: SWP No. 27.1(Examination of [Thomas Carrier, Jr.] _carrier_thomas_jr  )[+ August 10, 1692. ]The Examination of [Tho.. . Carrier] _carrier_thomas_jr  Taken before [Dudly Broad- stret] _bradstreet_dudley  Esq'r on of their Majesties Justices of the Peace --[Tho. Carr'r] _carrier_thomas_jr  being acused of witchcraft Conffeseth that he was  guilty of witchcraft & that he had been a witch a week & that his  Mother taught him witchcraft --That a Yellow bird apeared to him & Spoke to him w'ch She  being affrighted his Mother apeared to him & brought him a book  & bid him Sett his hand to it telling him it would doe him good if he  did Soe & that She would tear him in peices if he would not --That his Mother baptized him in ShawShin River pulled of his  Cloths & put him into the River & that his Mother then told him he  was hers for Ever. That his Moth'r bid him afflict [Mary Walkutt] _walcott_mary  [Ann Puttman] _putnam_ann_jr  & [Sarah Phelps] _phelps_sarah  -- And that he went the 9'th Instant at  night to [Jno Chandlers] _chandler_john  , that their were 10 in Company w'th him who  rid upon 2 Poles that there were 3 men in the Company & 2 of the  woeman belonged to Ispwich whose names ware [Mary] _walcott_mary  & [Sarah] _phelps_sarah   & that he Saw [Betty Johnson] _johnson_elizabeth_jr  in the Company & Conffesed that he did  the 9'th Instant at night afflict [Sarah Phelps] _phelps_sarah  & [Ann Puttnam] _putnam_ann_jr  by  pinching them. --(In left margin) [Thos Carrier] _carrier_thomas_jr ( Essex Institute Collection, no. 24-5v, Phillips Library, Peabody Essex Museum, Salem.)

title: SWP No. 028: Bethia Carter, Sr.
content: SWP No. 28.1(Recognizance for [Bethia Carter, Sr.] _carter_bethia_sr  by John Pierson & George Lilly)[December 8, 1692]Memorandum. That on the 8'th. Day of Decemb'r 1692 in the fowert Year of  the Reign of our Soveraign Lord & Lady William & Mary by the  Grace of God of England &c King & Queen Defenders of the faith  personally Appeared before us [James Russell] _russell_james  & [Sam'll Heman] _hayman_samuel  Esq'r  of their Majests Councill & province of the Massachusets Bay in New  England & Justices of Peace within the Same [John Pierson] _pierson_john  & [George Lylly] _lilly_george  of Lin in the County of Essex husbandman, And acknowledged  themselves & Each of them to be indebted unto our Said Lord  & Lady the King & Queen & the Survivor of them their Heires & Suc-  cessors in the Some of (two hundred pounds to be leavied on their  or Either of their goods or Chattels Lands or Tennements for the  use of our Said Lord & Lady the King & Queen or Survivor of them  if Default be made in the [pbar ]formance of the Condition under-  written --The Condition of the Above Recognizance is Such that where as  [Bethya Carter] _carter_bethia_sr  of Wooburn Widdow in the County of Middlesex  Stands Charged with Suspition of the horrible Sin of witchcraft  & was Committed to Goale for the same; If therefore the Aforesaid  [Bethya Carter] _carter_bethia_sr  who is Suspected as Abovs'd, Shall make her personall  Appearance before the Justices of our Said Lord & Lady the King  & Queen at the Next Court of Assize Oyer & Terminer & Generall  Goall delivery to be holden for & within the County of Middle-  sex. Afores'd to Answere what Shall be objected against her in their  Majests behalf refering to Witchcraft & to do & receive that w'ch by   Said Court shall be then & there injoned her & not depart without  licence then the Above Recognizance to be void or elce to remain in  full force & virtue Capt & Recognit Die prediet Cor.[Ja: Russell] _russell_james   JP:  [Samuell Hayman] _hayman_samuel  (Reverse)  [Bethya Carter] _carter_bethia_sr  , Recognizance  appear at Middlesex Ct. ( Suffolk Court Files, Vol. 32, docket No. 2697 Page 22. )

title: SWP No. 029: Elizabeth Cary
content: SWP No. 29.1(Complaint of Thomas Putnam & Benjamin Hutchinson v. [Elizabeth Cary] _carr_elizabeth  )[May 28, 1692. ]Salem, May 28'th 1692. [Mr. Thomas. puttnam] _putnam_thomas_jr  & [Benjamin Hutchinson] _hutchinson_benjamin  both of Salem Vilage  Yeomen Complaine of [Elizabeth Ca[rey]] _carr_elizabeth  the wife of [Capt Nathaniell Carÿ] _cary_nathaniel  of Charls=Towne Ma[ri]ner, on behalfe of theyr Majestyes, for  Sundry Acts of Witch craft by hir Comitted upon the Bodys of  [M[ary] Walcott] _walcott_mary  , [Abigall. Willyams] _williams_abigail  & [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy  all of Sa[lem] Vil-  lage, whereby great hurt & dammage is done them and therefore Crave  Justice( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 no. 109 )

title: SWP No. 029: Elizabeth Cary
content: SWP No. 29.2( Examination of Elizabeth Cary, as Published by Robert Calef)[++ May 23, 1692]I having heard some days, that my Wife was accused of Witch-  craft, being much disturbed at it, by advice, we went to Salem-  Village, to see if the afflicted did know her; we arrived there, 24 May, it happened to be a day appointed for Examination; accord-  ingly soon after our arrival, [Mr. Hathorn] _hawthorne_john  and [Mr. Curwin] _corwil_jonathan  , etc., went  to the Meeting-house, which was the place appointed for that Work,  the Minister began with Prayer, and having taken care to get a  convenient place, I observed, that the afflicted were two Girls of  about Ten Years old, and about two or three other, of about eight-  een, one of the Girls talked most, and could discern more than the  rest. The Prisoners were called in one by one, and as they came in  were cried out of, etc. The Prisoner was placed about 7 or 8 foot  from the Justices, and the Accusers between the Justices and them;  the Prisoner was ordered to stand right before the Justices, with an   Officer appointed to hold each hand, least they should therewith  afflict them, and the Prisoners Eyes must be constantly on the Jus-  tices; for if they look'd on the afflicted, they would either fall into  their Fits, or cry out of being hurt by them; after Examination of  the Prisoners, who it was afflicted these Girls, etc., they were put  upon saying the Lords Prayer, as a tryal of their guilt; after the  afflicted seem'd to be out of their Fits, they would look steadfastly  on some one person, and frequently not speak; and then the Justices  said they were struck dumb, and after a little time would speak again;  then the Justices said to the Accusers, “which of you will go and  touch the Prisoner at the Bar?” then the most couragious would ad-  venture, but before they had made three steps would ordinarily fall  down as in a Fit; the Justices ordered that they should be taken up  and carried to the Prisoner, that she might touch them; and as soon  as they were touched by the accused, the Justices would say, they are  well, before I could discern any alteration; by which I observed that  the Justices understood the manner of it. Thus far I was only as  a Spectator, my Wife also was there part of the time, but no notice  taken of her by the afflicted, except once or twice they came to her  and asked her name.But I having an opportunity to Discourse [Mr. Hale] _hale_john  (with whom  I had formerly acquaintance) I took his advice, what I had best to  do, and desired of him that I might have an opportunity to speak  with her that accused my Wife; which he promised should be, I  acquainting him that I reposed my trust in him.Accordingly he came to me after the Examination was over,  and told me I had now an opportunity to speak with the said Accuser,  viz . [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  , a Girl of 11 or 12 Years old; but that we could  not be in private at [Mr. Parris's] _parris_samuel  House, as he had promised me; we  went therefore into the Alehouse, where an Indian Man attended us,  who it seems was one of the afflicted: to him we gave some Cyder,  he shewed several Scars, that seemed as if they had been long there,  and shewed them as done by Witchcraft, and acquainted us that his  Wife, who also was a Slave, was imprison'd for Witchcraft. And now  instead of one Accuser, they all came in, who began to tumble down  like Swine, and then three Women were called in to attend them.  We in the Room were all at a stand, to see who they would cry  out of; but in a short time they cried out, [Cary] _cary_elizabeth  ; and immediately   after a Warrant was sent from the Justices to bring my Wife before  them, who were sitting in a Chamber near by, waiting for this.Being brought before the Justices, her chief accusers were two  Girls; my Wife declared to the Justices, that she never had any knowl-  edge of them before that day; she was forced to stand with her  Arms stretched out. I did request that I might hold one of her  hands, but it was denied me; then she desired me to wipe the Tears  from her Eyes, and the Sweat from her Face, which I did; then she  desired she might lean her self on me, saying, she should faint.Justice Hathorn replied, she had strength enough to torment  those persons, and she should have strength enough to stand. I  speaking something against their cruel proceedings, they commanded  me to be silent, or else I should be turned out of the Room. The  Indian before mentioned, was also brought in, to be one of her  Accusers: being come in, he now (when before the Justices) fell  down and tumbled about like a Hog, but said nothing. The Justices  asked the Girls, who afflicted the Indian? they answered she ( mean-  ing my Wife) and now lay upon him; the Justices ordered her to touch  him, in order to his cure, but her head must be turned another way,  least instead of curing, she should make him worse, by her looking on  him, her hand being guided to take hold of his; but the Indian took  hold on her hand, and pulled her down on the Floor, in a barbarous  manner; then his hand was taken off, and her hand put on his, and  the cure was quickly wrought. I being extreamly troubled at their  Inhumane dealings, uttered a hasty Speech (That God would take  vengeance on them, and desired that God would deliver us out of the  hands of unmerciful men.) Then her Mittimus was writ. I did with  difficulty and charge obtain the liberty of a Room, but no Beds in it;  if there had, could have taken but little rest that Night. She was  committed to Boston Prison; but I obtained a Habeas Corpus to  remove her to Cambridge Prison, which is in our County of Middle-  sex. Having been there one Night, next Morning the Jaylor put  Irons on her legs (having received such a command) the weight of  them was about eight pounds; these Irons and her other Afflictions,  soon brought her into Convulsion Fits, so that I thought she would  have died that Night. I sent to intreat that the Irons might be taken  off, but all intreaties were in vain, if it would have saved her Life,  so that in this condition she must continue. The Tryals at Salem   coming on, I went thither, to see how things were there managed;  and finding that the Spectre- Evidence was there received, together  with Idle, if not malicious Stories, against Peoples Lives, I did easily  perceive which way the rest would go; for the same Evidence that  served for one, would serve for all the rest. I acquainted her with her  danger; and that if she were carried to Salem to be tried, I feared she  would never return. I did my utmost that she might have her Tryal  in our own County, I with several others Petitioning the Judge for  it, and were put in hopes of it; but I soon saw so much, that I under-  stood thereby it was not intended, which put me upon consulting  the means of her escape; which thro the goodness of God was ef-  fected, and she got to Road Island, but soon found her self not safe  when there, by reason of the pursuit after her; from thence she  went to New-York, along with some others that had escaped their  cruel hands; where we found his Excellency [Benjamin Fletcher] _fletcher_benjamin  ,  Esq; Governour, who was very courteous to us. After this some of  my Goods were seized in a Friends hands, with whom I had left them,  and my self imprisoned by the Sheriff, and kept in Custody half a  day, and then dismist; but to speak of their usage of the Prisoners,  and their Inhumanity shewn to them, at the time of their Execution,  no sober Christian could bear; they had also tryals of cruel mockings;  which is the more, considering what a People for Religion, I mean  the profession of it, we have been; those that suffered being many of  them Church-Members, and most of them unspotted in their Con-  versation, till their Adversary the Devil took up this Method for  accusing them.Per  [Nathaniel Cary.] _cary_nathaniel  ( Robert Calef, More Wonders of the Invisible World [London 1700] pp. 95-98. .)

title: SWP No. 030: Sarah Churchill
content: SWP No. 30.1(Confession of [Sarah Churchill] _churchill_sarah[June 1, 1692][Sarah Churchwell] _churchill_sarah  confesseth that [Goody pudeator] _pudeator_ann  brought the  book to this Examin't and she signed it, but did not know her at  that tyme but when she saw her she knew her to be the same and  that [Goody Bishop] _bishop_sarah  also Olliver appeared to this Examinant & told her  she had killed [John Trask's] _trask_john  Child, (whose Child dyed about that  tyme) & said [Bishop] _bishop_sarah  alias Olliver afflicted her as alsoe did old [George Jacobs] _jacobs_george  , and before that time this Examin't being afflicted could not  doe her service as formerly and her s'd [Master Jacobs] _jacobs_george_sr  called her bitch  witch & ill names & then afflicted her as #[before] above and that  pudEater brought 3: Images like [Mercy Lewis] _lewis_mercy , [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  , [Eliza' Hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  & they brought her thornes & she stuck them in the Images  & told her the persons whose likeness they were, would be afflected  & the other day saw [Goody Olliver] _bishop_bridget  #[sitt] sate upon her knee,Jurat in Curia  by [Sarah Churchill] _churchill_sarah  This Confession was taken before [John Hathorne] _hawthorne_john  and [Jonathan Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  Esq'rs 1' o[f] June 1692, as attests [*Tho Newton] _newman_thomas  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 1 no. 262. )

title: SWP No. 030: Sarah Churchill
content: SWP No. 30.2( Deposition of [Sarah Ingersoll] _ingersoll_sarah  and [Ann Andrews] _andrews_anna  for [Sarah Churchill] _churchill_sarah )[? June 1, 1692]The diposition of [Sarah Ingelson] _ingersoll_sarah  Aged about 30 yers: saith that  seing [Sarah Church] _churchill_sarah  after hur exsamination She came to me Crieng  and wringing hur hands seming to be mutch trobeled in Sparet I  asked hur what she ailed she answered she had undon hur self I asked  hur in what she saied in belieng hur salfe and others in saieing she   had seat hur hand to the divells Book whairas she saied she naver did  I told her I beleved she had saet hur hand to the Book she answered  Crieng and said no no no: I naver, I naver did I asked then what had  maed hur say she did she answered because they thratened hur: and  told hur thay would put her in to the dungin and put hur along with  mr Borows and thus saverall times she folowed one up and downe  tealing me that she had undon hursalfe in be lieng hur salf and others  I asked hur why she did #[not] [word illegible] writ it she tould me be Cause she had stood  out so long in it that now she darst not she saied allso that If she told  [mr Noys] _noyes_nicholas  but ons she had sat hur hand to the Book he would be leve  her but If she told the truth and saied she had not seat her hand to  the Book a hundred times he would not beleve hur:[Sarah Ingrsol] _ingersoll_sarah   [*AnnA. AndRuSle] _andrews_anna  ( Essex County Court Archives, Salem -- Witchcraft Vol. 2 no. 113. )

title: SWP No. 031: Mary Clarke
content: SWP No. 31.1(Complaint of [Robert Swan] _swan_robert  and [John Swan] _swan_john  v. [Mary Clarke] _clarke_mary  )[August 3, 1692]The Complaint of [Roburt swane] _swan_robert  and [John swane] _swan_john  of Andevor against  [Mary Clarke] _clarke_mary  the wife of [Edward Clarke] _clarke_edward  of #[Haverhill]: In behalf of  Their Majesties: for themselves and severall of their neighbors: for  High suspition of sundry acts of witchcraft by hir latly commited on  the bodys of [Timothy Swwane] _swan_timothy  of Andevor and [Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  and  [Ann Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  of Salem village wherby much hurt hath ben don the  afore said afflicted persons and theirfore they crave justis[*Robert Swan] _swan_robert  This Complaint was brought to me (by [Robert Swan] _swan_robert  of Andov'r)  the 3'd day of August Anno Domini 1692 & bond given for the  prossecution thereof before, the Worship'l justices of Peace att salem:  upon which I gave, a writt of Apprehension: * [Dudley Bradstreet] _bradstreet_dudley  Just's Peace ( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 156, Boston Public Library -- Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts )

title: SWP No. 031: Mary Clarke
content: SWP No. 31.2(Warrant for the apprehension of [Mary Clark] _clarke_mary ) [August 3, 1692]Essex To ye Constable of Haverhill:This day Complaint being made to me ye Subscriber; by [Robert Swan] _swan_robert  of Andover in ye County of Essex, against [Mary Clerk] _clarke_mary  of Haverhill in ye County aforesd, (that the wife of [Edward Clerk] _clarke_edward ,) that she is Highly suspected to be guilty of severall acts of witchcraft. & more lately some committed on ye bodys of [timothy Swan] _swan_timothy  of Andover: & [Mary Wallcutt] _walcott_mary : & [Anne Putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  of Salem Village in ye County aforesd: Contrary to ye peace of or Souereigne Lord & Lady William & Mary King & Queen of England Scotland &c: & to ye statutes in that Case provided, & sd [Robert Swan] _swan_robert  having given bond according to Law, to prosecute sd Complaint (as he desires) before ye Worshipll [Bartholmew Gedney] _gidney_bartholomew  [John Hathorne] _hathorn_john : [Jonathan Corwin] _corwil_jonathan  & [John Higginson] _higginson_john  Esqs: their Majests: Justices of ye peace in Salem [word crossed out] These therefore require you upon sight hereof, to ---- apprehend & siese ye body of sd [Mary Clerke] _clarke_mary  & here her ---- forthwith safely convey to Salem, before ye abovesd Justices of ye peace there: there to be examined, & proceeded with according to Law, for which this shall be yor warrant Given undr my hand & seal this 3d day of August Anno Domini 1692: & in ye 4th year of their Majests reigne &c[Dudley Bradstreet] _bradstreet_dudley  justice of peaceBy Vertue of this Warrant I have Seised the Body of [Mary Clark] _clarke_mary  and Brought her down wth mee [Wm: Sterling] _stacy_william  Constable of haveril(Reverse) [Mary Clark] _clarke_mary  Of Haveril 4: 6.-92MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 244. Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts, Boston Public Library

title: SWP No. 031: Mary Clarke
content: SWP No. 31.3(Examination of [Mary Clark] _clarke_mary  )[August 4, 1692]4't Agust 1692. The Examination of [Mary Clark] _clarke_mary  . of. Haverhill Taken before. [Jno Hauthorn] _hawthorne_john  Esq'r and other their majesties justices of the peace. The  accused [mary Clark] _clarke_mary  being called, it was enquyred of [Mary walcot] _walcott_mary  if  ever [Clark] _clarke_mary  had afflicted her, she answered yes, that is the very wom-  an, and upon [mary Clarks] _clarke_mary  #[afflicting Of] Lookeing upon [walcott] _walcott_mary   and others of the afflicted they wer. str[u]ck into fitts. -- The Jus-  tices haveing used severall arguments (for the good of her soul ) to confess if she knew her self, guilty . she absolutely denyed And then  the constable of #[Andover] Haverhill was called, and being asked  of what fame & reputation [mary Clark] _clarke_mary  was off; He answered they  had [had] heard #[guilty] she was or had been guilty of such things,  but as to anything in particular he could not say. The justices. asked  mary walcot if she wer not mistaken in this woman/.[Walcot] _walcott_mary  answered this is the very woman I saw afflict [Timothy swan] _swan_timothy  ,  and she has aflicted me severall tymes and after a fitt she was then  Imediatly in, she said she saw the above [mary Clark] _clarke_mary  afflict [Betty hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  & [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  The said [mary Clark] _clarke_mary  Lookeing upon [Wal- cott] _walcott_mary  , [hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  putnam, [warrin] _warren_mary , they wer in fitts.[Mary Walcott] _walcott_mary  haveing a pinn run into her arme suddenly: said that  [mary Clark] _clarke_mary  did it, At the same tyme [mary warrin] _warren_mary  had a pinn run  into her throat under her chin which [Mr Noice] _noyes_nicholas  took out, [Susanna Shelden] _sheldon_susannah  upon s'd examination had 4 pinns taken out, of her hand  sayeing that s'd [Clark] _clarke_mary  put in two of them & Mr usher the other two.[Richard Carryer] _carrier_richard  a former confessor said he beleeved he saw the  s'd [mary Clark] _clarke_mary  with some others and himself baptised at Newburry  falls. [Betty hubbard] _hubbard_elizabeth  was struck down by her lookeing upon her It  was asked if she could say the lords prayer perfectly she erred much.  Ann putnam said that s'd [Clark] _clarke_mary  had afflicted her by pincheing choak-  eing & stricking her in the face, & told her, that her name was  [Mistriss Mary Clark] _clarke_mary  , but that people used to call her [goody Clark] _clarke_mary  .  [Ann putnam] _putnam_ann_jr  said further that She saw the s'd [Clark] _clarke_mary  stabb [Timothy Swan] _swan_timothy  with a square ragged Speare as long as her hand(Reverse) and being asked why she called it a Ragged speare, she  said #[it] because it was ragged like a file.[Mary post] _post_mary  said she saw this [mary Clarke] _clarke_mary  Spirit at the village witch  meeting & that she did eat & drink There as the rest did And fur-  ther she has seen the s'd [Mary Clark] _clarke_mary  afflict [Timothy Swan/] _swan_timothy  I under-  written being appoynted by authority to take the within examin-  tion in wryting Doe testify upon oath taken in court, that this is a  true copy of the substance of it, to the best of my knowledge.(Vertically in right margin)  [Mary Clarks] _clarke_mary  Examinan( Salem Selections, Massachusetts Box, Essex Co., Manuscripts & Archives,New York Public Library )

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.1(Warrant for apprehension of [Rachel Clinton] _clenton_rachel , and Summons for Witnesses v. Rachel Clinton, and Officer’s Return )[March 29, 1692]To the Constable of Ipswich -- Whereas There is Complaint Exhibbitted to the Honored Court now  holden at Ipswich -- In Behalfe of their majesties. against [Rachell] _clenton_rachel  -- Formerly the Wife of  [Lawrence Clenton] _clenton_lawrence  of Ipswich on grounded Suspision of witchcraft,  & whereas Recognizance is Enterd, for prosecution --You are hereby Required in their Majesties names forthwith or as  soon as may be to apprehend seize & bringe before the Honored  Court to be holden at Ipswich the sayd [Rachell Clenton] _clenton_rachel  on the next  morrow morning at Eight a Clock In order to an orderly Examina-  tion, & Conviction & hereof fail not at Your perrill & for so doing  this shall be your warrant of which you are to make a true returne  as the Law derects:Ipswich  March 29'th 1692)   P Curiam [*Tho's Wade] _wade_thomas  Cler

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.12To the Constable of Ipswich You are hereby required In their Majesties names to Sumons warne  & Require to appeare at the Court to be holden at Ipswich on the  morrow morning Viz't [Mary Fuller sen'r] _fuller_mary_sr  & [Mary fuller Junior] _fuller_mary_jr   & [Allexsander Thomson jur] _thomson_alexander_jr  & [Richard fitts] _fitts_richard  & [Doct: John Bridgham] _bridgham_doc_john   & [Thomas Maning] _manning_thomas  & [Nathaniel Burnam] _burnam_nathaniel  all of Ipswich & [Thomas Knowlton jur] _knowlton_thomas_jr  & [Mary Thorne] _thorne_mary  To Give in their severall Evidences be-  fore the Court to Cleare up the Grounds of Suspition of [Rachell Clenton] _clenton_rachel  Being a Witch & hereof faile not at Your perrill but make  a true returne under Your hand as the Law Directs --P. Curiam [Thos Wade] _wade_thomas  Cler. I have served this warrant and read it to [Rechell Clinton:] _clenton_rachel  this morning : and sezed hur Body: and Left hur in the hands of [Samuell Ordeway:] _ordway_samuel  [to] have in the Court house Against your honoures shall  Call for hur and I have Red the severeall warrants one the other  sid written this morning save only [Richard fitts] _fitts_richard  and [Mary Thorne] _thorne_mary   and [Richard fitts] _fitts_richard  I could not find and [Mary Thorne] _thorne_mary  is not well: as  witness my hand [Joseph Fuller] _fuller_joseph  ,  Constable of Ipswich: Dated this 29'th March 1692  ( Suffolk Court Files, vol. 31, docket 2660, p. 140.)

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.2(Summons for Witnesses to the Examination of [Rachel Clinton] _clenton_rachel )[April 21, 1692 ]To Sarje't [John Choate] _choate_john , sen'r. To [Jonas Gregory] _gregory_jonas , To [James Burnam] _burnam_james , all of Ipswich, [Mary Andrews] _andrews_mary , [Sarah Rogors] _rogors_sarah , [Marguriet Lord] _lord_margaret , [Sary Halwell] _halwell_sary  you & each of you are hereby Required in thair majesties names To make Your personall apperance before ye Worshipfull Maj'r [Sam'll Appleton] _appleton_samuel  Esq., & ye Clerk of ye Court to be at ye house of Mr. [John Spark] _spark_john  in Ipswich on ye 22d Day of This Instant aprile, at two o'clock afternoon. Then and There to Give in Your severall respective Evidences in behalf of [Rachell Clentons] _clenton_rachel  being a witch, who is Then and Thair to be upon further Examination. Therefore So make Your apperance according to this Sumons fail nott at your perril.Ipswich,  Dated aprill 21st, 1692 Curiam [Tho's Wade] _wade_thomas , Clerk.Ye Constable of Ipswich is alike Required to Give notis to ye said person, & to make returne as ye Law Directs. Curr [T. W.] _wade_thomas Clk.According to this within written I haue Sumonsed and warned them: to Apere According to Time & Place by me [William Baker] _baker_william , Constable.Dated this 22d of april, 1692.Thomas Franklin Waters, Ipswich in the Massachusetts Bay Colony (Ipswich, MA: Ipswich Historical Society, 1905):461.

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.3( Deposition of [Mary Fuller, Sr.] _fuller_mary_sr  , v. [Rachel Clenton] _clenton_rachel  ) [+ March 30, 1692 ]The Deposition of [Mary fuller sen'or] _fuller_mary_sr  Aged About 41 years Saieth  About the 23 or fouorth of Last March: 1691/2 About Tenn of the  Clock [Rachell Clenton] _clenton_rachel  cam to our house and Charged me with  Raisen Lies of hur About my Daughter and [Mary Thorne] _thorne_mary  and whille  she S'd [Rachell] _clenton_rachel  was drawing: my Brother [Joseph Fuller's] _fuller_joseph  boy Com in  and said their Betty was fall Downe Ded and this was as shee S'd  [Rechell] _clenton_rachel  pased by: hur: A comming to our house and further Run up  to my Brothers [Joseph Fullers] _fuller_joseph  house for the space of Three hours  with out any motission [motion] of Life. #[deponent testifief] spake I Get hur hold up hur hand  If S'd [Rachell] _clenton_rachel  was the caus of it and shee ded: and when shee could  Speke shee S'd The womman with A white cape pased by and  struck hur: on the forehead:( Suffolk Court Files, vol. 31, docket 2660, p. 140. )

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.4( Deposition of [Thomas Boarman] _boarman_thomas  v. [Rachel Clenton] _clenton_rachel  )[+ April 4, 1692 ]This Deposition of [Thomas Boarman] _boarman_thomas  sen'or aged 47 This Deponent  testifieth and saith that som wimen of worth and quality: Desired  me To Aquaint the seven men that [Rachell Clinton] _clenton_rachel  was a great Diss-  turber unto them in the house in hunching them with hur Elboo: as  they went by hur s'd [Clinton] _clenton_rachel  , and then the same Day ther I the  s'd [Boarman] _boarman_thomas  : Desired the seven men to take som Cear the [Rachell Clenton] _clenton_rachel  : might be for warned: not to com in to Thoes wimens house,  no more to Dissturbe them, and as I the s'd [Boarman] _boarman_thomas  was Riding  whom: that night after I had bin, Before me Like a Cat as I Apper-  prehended: and then I looked wistfully upon it; and it Semed to be  sumething Like a Littell Doge: and then I pursued it: and it Kept  the same Distance in the parth before me: all though I Road heard  after it I could not over take it, then I looked once [to] my right  hand: and I saw a Grat Turkle that moved as fast as I Roud a Long:  and Then I thought of [Rachell Clinton] _clenton_rachel  then the Littell Creature and  the Turkle vanished away: and further saith not.( Suffolk Court Files, vol. 31, docket 2660, p. 140. )

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.5( Deposition [William Baker] _baker_william  v. [Rachel Clenton] _clenton_rachel  )[+ April 4, 1692 ]The Deposion of [William Baker] _baker_william  Aged 36 years Saith: About 10 years  Agoo: I living with my Master Rust: There was a Barrill of strong  beer brewed & the Day it was Brewed [Rachell Clinton] _clenton_rachel  came there,  & was with sum small Thing:  But what it was I can not tell: & the Day  morning the Bere was put in to the Berrill: & that day said [Rachell] _clenton_rachel   went bakwords and forrowords, 6 or 7 times: up & Dow the lane  that Leds to our house & Did not com in to the house that Day:  & that night following: [hannah Rust:] _rust_hanneh  went Downe to see whether the  Bere worked or no: & Puld out the tape & could find no Bere in  the Barrel: neither was there any appearance of wet upon the flouer:  and presently after we fild the Barril with worter and it was in a  night and Day and Did not Leke any of it out as we could see And  after that we our folke Brued another Barrel of Bere and put it in  the sam Barrill & it Did not Leke tall after that And further Saieth  not:( Suffolk Court Records, vol. 31 Docket No. 2660, p. 140 )

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.6( Testimony of [Mary Edwards] _edwards_mary  v. [Rachel Clenton] _clenton_rachel  )[+ April 4, 1692 ]Ipswich April the 4'th 1692 The testimony of [Mary Edwards] _edwards_mary  ageed about 52 yeres testifieth  & Saith that abought the 27'th day: of: this Last Dissember 1691  that  [Rachell CLenton] _clenton_rachel  came to our houes & was very importinat with me  the s'd [Mary:] _edwards_mary  to have Rome in our house to kepe share but I tould:  har the s'd [Rachell] _clenton_rachel  that there were no wages: provided to acommedat  har tharfore she -- must Rest har seat contented:)& at: this time: I  the s'd [Mary] _edwards_mary  was mackeing of BLood pudens: and she the above  s'd [Rachell] _clenton_rachel  siting by the fier) by: her discorse had a great dissire to  have sum of that pudens: saying that it was very good foode:  & that she loved it very: well: so I the s'd [mary] _edwards_mary  gave: her: the s'd  [Rachell] _clenton_rachel  one of the pudens: the which she Reseaved vary: sCornfully:  & quickly after rose up: out of her seate & went a way: muttering  but what she said I coulld not tell: but about the Latter end of Jin-  nywary: the s'd [Edwards] _edwards_mary  : had nine pigges: that ware a bout eight  weckes oulld that ware: tacken suddenly: five of them: &: died  & a bout a fortnight after that the s'd [Edwards] _edwards_mary  : had thre: yerelings  tacken sudently that semed to be very harty: & was: in good: Case:  but sudenly was tacken with unusuall fittes: Jumping & Roreing till  thay tumbled downe with in a Littell tim after one a nother) as: to:  the Latter part of this testymony Releating to the death of my pigges:  & yearings I can attest two[John s edwards, sen'r] _edwards_john_sr  his    mark:: & furthermore [mary: edwards:] _edwards_mary  heard sum of her Children aske the s'd  [Reachell] _clenton_rachel  how har hands ceame so: be Scracht: & swelled so & she:  made: This answar & said that she: had two or thre: Roges: catts:  that when she put downe her hand would scratch it: ( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 60, Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts )

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.7( [James Fuller, Jr.] _fuller_james_jr  , v. [Rachel Clenton] _clenton_rachel  )[++ April 4, 1692 ]The deposition of [Jeams Fuller Junier] _fuller_james_jr  aged about eighteen years  saith that on the 15'th Day of march Last: 1692 or there a bouts:  as to the Day: A bout 9 or 10: of the Clock: I was talking with [Good- man Perry] _perry_goodman  & telling him how the s'd [mary Fuller] _fuller_mary_jr  my sister & [Mary Thorn] _thorne_mary  wer taken last night: & in the mene while, whilst he and I was  talking [Rachell Clinton] _clenton_rachel  Cam in to our house & sat Downe by the fier  I asked hur what shee came bother for at this time of night, & shee  said shee Came to see what Lies them were that we raisd of hur  & I tould hur I Ded not know as I had Raisd Eny of hur: Presently  my onkles Boy Cam in & told me that ther Betty was Ded, and as  soon as Ever she s'd [Rachall] _clenton_rachel  Herd them words: she run out of Dors:  and I followed hur as herd as I could & when I Came to the Dore I  could see nothing of hur: & it was a very Cler mone light night & I  Run up to my onkles: [Joseph fullers] _fuller_joseph  House: to see what the matter  was: & ther I found the Gerle Dede as the boys told me; & s'd onkl  fuller & I took hur up & Carried hur in the house & so shee conti-  nued for the space of 3 or 4 hours: before ther was any Apperance  of Life in hur; & the next Day I asked hur whoe mad hur so Last  night & she told me: She See Sumthing stare up at the Corner of  the [Stope] & Shee went a little way towards it & it Loced So Basly  she turned A bout to Run a way from it & it followed her & Knocked  hur Down( MS Ch K 1.40, vol. 2, p. 68, Boston Public Library, Dept. of Rare Books and Manuscripts )

title: SWP No. 032: Rachel Clinton
content: SWP No. 32.8(Deposition of [Thomas Burnam Jr.] _burnam_thomas  v. [Rachel Clinton] _clenton_rachel )[+ March 30, 1692 ]The Depsition of [Thomas Burnam] _burnam_thomas  junr aged: 48: years who testifieth & saith yt som years sinc one sumer one of my Cows was very often milked & som times tow of them in my yard by my house: & thinking to Cach ye milker: I took paines & watched & one with me & thos nights yt I watched my Cowes were not milked & I arose one night a Litele before day: & stood in my indien Corn near whare my Cowes Lay & sone I saw a female stand in ye midele of ye yeard. whar ye cowes ware which by hear atier I thought was [Rachell Hatfell ^Clenton^] _clenton_rachel  which as I thought uanished  a way: & a nother night I a rose before day & walked in ye street & just one ye breaking of day Came sudingly to my yeard wheare my Cowes Lay & that Cow that was most comonly milked stood & a parson a milking which presenly glanced from ye cow in ye Lickenesse of a gray Cat & run up ye back side of my house Scraching upon ye Shingells a bought fourty foot: & so ouer ye top of my house & furthersaith not=(in a different hand) Except yt ye Spring following the same Cow was found dead on ye Common, not mired nor Cast. nor throw poverty, or any Disease yt we know of.Collection 77, Box 1, Folder 19, Maine Historical Society, Portland, ME.

title: SWP No. 033: Sarah Cloyce
content: SWP No. 33.1![Figure S012v   ](archives/Suffolk/small/S012v   .jpg)(Indictment No. 1 v. [Sarah Cloyce] _cloyce_sarah  , for Afflicting Abigail Williams)[++ January 13, 1693 ]Essex in the Province  of the Massachusetts  Bay in New EnglandAnno RR's & Reginae & Mariae Angliae &c  Quarto Annoq'e Domini 1692.The Jurors for our Soveraigne Lord & Lady the King and Queen  doe present That [Sarah Cloyce] _cloyce_sarah  Wife of [Peter Cloyce] _cloyce_peter  of Salem --  in the County of Essex Husbandman upon or about the n'th Day of April -- In the yeare aforesaid and divers other Days and times as  well before as after Certaine Detestable Arts called Witchcraft and  Sorceries Wickedly Mallitiously and felloniously hath used practised  and Exercised At and in the Towne of Salem in the Country of  Essex -- aforesaid in upon and against one [Abigail Williams] _williams_abigail  of Salem --  aforesaid Single Woman -- by which said Wicked Acts the said Abi-  gaill Williams the Day & Yeare -- aforesaid and Divers other Days  and times both before and after was and is Tortured Aflicted Con-  sumed Wasted Pined and Tormented against the Peace of our Sov'r  Lord and Lady the King & Queen theire Crowne and Dignity and  The Law In that case made and Provided(Reverse)  Ignoramus  [Robert Payne] _payne_robert   foreman( Suffolk Court Files, vol. 32, docket no. 2677b p. 8. )

content: SWP No. 33.3(Indictment No. 3 v.
